description:
Staying nearby and a friend recommended this place over the other Chinese restaurants in the close proximity. Ordered the potstickers and Mongolian Beef (piks attached). The potstickers were totally underwhelming and I would certainly not order them again, but the Mongolian Beef was terrific, I've had so many poor versions over the years in so many places, I forgot what it tastes like when it's done well. And the portion was very large, plenty of good size pieces of beef. Definitely recommend it... 

4 stars is fair, or maybe 3 1/2 due to the potstickers, but it's definitely on my recommend list, regardless... :)
author: Steve M.

description:
Potstickers were amazing. So good forgot to photograph them. 
Sweet and sour pork was good but more batter than meat. 
Decently priced and very fast service
author: Nellie P.

description: My grandparents and my dad were grew up in a Hakka village, and this Hakka restaurant is my dad's favorite, authentic dishes like stuffed tofu and house special stir fried are highly recommended by most of my relatives and friends. I deducted one star of rating is because of their two major issues, first is the SUPER limited parking, second is they are obviously understaff (there are only 3-4 servers included the owner herself, and all of them have to be multitasking.
author: Weng C.

description:
Came here and was able to walk right in on a Sunday night for dinner. There's an upstairs so it's actually pretty spacious. One thing to note. The service kind of sucks. They got our order wrong, gave us catfish when we wanted sea bass. They also forgot one of our orders. They proceeded they were super sorry, and they would fix the bill.....by charging us for the price of the catfish instead of the sea bass....that was it. I was very disappointed by that

For a party of 5 we got the Typhoon Shelter Clams with Spicy Salt and Black Bean Sauce, half baked chicken, house special pan fried tofu, chinese bacon with preserved veggies, kong xin cai, and catfish.

The clams. They were my favorite. They were a little breaded and fried. They reminded me of the crabs at PPQ where it's a bit salty, has a lot of garlic, and was clearly fried. I actually really enjoyed the flavor in it and really wished there was more to share (there is actually a decent amount).

The baked chicken reminded me a lot of peking duck in the sense that they clearly rubbed 5 spice powder inside the chicken, let it bake and then the dipping sauce is just all the fat + spices dripped down. The chicken was quite juicy though. Nothing wrong with it, definitely not as light as the steamed chicken.

The pork belly with preserved veggies. It was pretty tasty. The pork was very soft and fatty. Feel like it's hard to mess up pork belly and they didn't mess it up. It's exactly how you imagine the dish to be. It is a little salty and so I would recommend eating it with rice. 

The catfish was pretty good too. Very sizable portion and they give you the whole fish (head, body, tail, everything). It was pretty oily so it's not the most healthy thing, but it was also very tender.

The kong xin cai was standard. Goes well with the salty dishes. They clearly added something else as the sauce was a bit more yellow than I'm used to.

Food was good, not too expensive (25 a person). The service was very disappointing in how they handled mistakes.
author: Victor D.

description:
One of the must Chinese restaurant in outer Richmond district you gotta go! 

They served a soup , boiled with pork rips and chicken may be with Chinese herb as well, as a starter

Their Hakka specialties were rigid, all come with fresh ingredient. My fav dishes were pan fried tofu stuffed with pork and bitter melon and catfish in a clay pot and so on to try ! 

After finishing the meal, they served with a cup of Chinese dessert, red bean with sago. It was so great! 

Never upset here
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: Let me just start off by saying the food here was amazing.I had the lamb clay pot & shrimp fried rice.This is the only reason I rated them 3 stars ( I try to be fair). I usually am not as obsessive about customer service,but this place has the worst I've ever seen.It wasn't as if the place was packed, I was the only one there, & the waiter still ignored me.I had to call out for him a few times, though someone that worked there just sat their gossiping with him from time to time, I had to ask for all my silverware,even water, & he never checked on me, except to give me the check.I was really conflicted about leaving any tip,but I've always made it a rule of mine to do so regardless of service.Unfortunately,I will probably never "eat in" at this particular location again, but probably just do "to go" orders.I highly recommend the lamb.
author: Harriet A.

description:
I don't know what happened to this place but this is one of the dirtiest restaurants in the City.  Yes it's basically a hole in the wall but I expect it to be somewhat clean.  The "white" table cloths had some nondescript stains on it that reminded us of poop.  Then a cockroach carcass was found on one of place settings.  So yeah we were somewhat grossed out about sitting there for dinner.

The food was ok.  Smaller portions but ok.  What I cannot forgive was the waiter.  I really suggest you review your bill before you pay.  The waiter double charged us for a dish.  After we pointed it out, he kept denying it and said, "I'm right.  I'm right.  I've been doing this for years."  It wasn't until we challenged him to do a line item addition (yes we whipped out paper and he did so too and we actually did math!) that he realized his mistake.  No apologies nothing. 

I don't know if it was on purpose or not but we can never show our faces at this place again for fear this jerk would spit on our food for calling him out on his shenanigans.  All I can say is be careful and vigilant about the bill!
author: Wendy H.

description: Probably one of the best Chinese restaurants I have ever had in the US. Several dishes and the complimentary soup all reminded me of my mom's cooking. It's authentic and delicious. Service wasn't that great, which I didn't expect much anyways. But the food came out in a decent amount of time. Love the food, service meh. Would definitely order take out if I live around here.
author: Ava Z.

description: Food was so so.. We had the salt roasted chicken, honey walnut shrimp, veg with preserved egg and the lamb and beancurd claypot. My favorite was the lamb, which was very tender and well cooked. The chicken was decent. There was no issue with any of the dishes but also no wow factor for me.
author: Charley T.

description:
Been here several times in the past 8 months. And while the food is fine. I detest their service--whether sit down or take out. 

The last three times they really pissed me off with their rudeness and argumentativeness. 

The first time, they didn't tell us about the price of an item we had ordered. It was a $35 item! (We found it later under another name, different from the Chinese description.) 

The second time, we waited 30 minutes outside for a take out order, when they told us it would only be 15 minutes. Mind you, they were carrying a conversation amongst themselves as I was trying to order. 

The final straw was when I ordered with Eat24 for pick up, and the prices were inaccurate (prices had gone up but apparently not reflected on Eat24 menu) and they pointed it out to me and expected me to pay the difference. If I would've had their physical menu handy at the time, I would've noticed it.  But for me to order $40+ worth of food, walk to pick it up and then to have them argue with me about it.  Unacceptable. 

We haven't eaten there in a few months because I don't feel like supporting their business when there are 3 other nearby Chinese restaurants with comparable food (and better in some instances) and I don't have to deal with such rudeness.

I grew up in the Chinese restaurant business and understand how much work goes into it and treating your customers like they're bothering you is definitely not the smart way to go about doing business.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Positives:
Seated Quickly
Good Service
Fast turn around from order to receiving food
Clean
Huge Portions
Cheap

Negatives: 
Food was not the greatest 
-General chicken seemed like it was microwaved chicken nuggets simmered in sauce
-Lamb with celery was questionable 
-Eggplant was soggy 


Takeaway: 
Good for a quick bit, but don't expect the food to taste great
author: Gaurav B.

description:
Ignored the low food safety score (who cares, I'm still alive!) because the family wanted authentic Chinese food.

Highly recommend:
Lamb in clay pot - so good! Lamb was perfectly cooked, and they give a lot of lamb in the dish 
House special chicken - cheap and delicious
Westlake beef soup - I love this soup, and it's hard to mess up
Sweet and sour pork - surprisingly really good

Do not recommend:
Veggies with preserved egg - this was one of the recommended dishes. It was honestly kinda gross because there was a runny egg with the veggies

There were tons of locals in the restaurant, and I didn't get food poisoning or anything, so definitely recommend if in the area.
author: Joy L.

description:
Came here tonight for dinner and was very disappointed  with the food and services. Ordered the egg yolk crab but half of the dish was with pumpkin. Charged us 44$ for it. Asked the waitress and she had the nerve to tell me that's how it's served!!! Crab was so small that they used the pumpkin As a filler that's what!!Service was poor and did not even bother with refilling the tea pot or clearing our plates. The squabs tasted funky as if it was spoiled (just not fresh)! The owner rushes you to pay the tab for another turn over. Doubt I'll ever come back even though I live in the hood
The quality of food did not worth the amount I paid for. 

-star for the ripoff crab with no meat 
-star for the services
-star they don't not care if you're satisfied or not 
-star dirty ass place
author: Jaine L.

description:
First time here.

Enjoyed the HAKKA cuisine. What follows is a group of eight hungry Chinese food lovers ordered a plethora of delights. We ordered the Pork Belly, Gai-lan with wine sauce, baked chicken with sticky rice, a salt baked chicken, claypot of frog legs, lily bulbs and rice.

The pork belly was super flavorful, comes on a bed of lettuce and some preserved mixed vegetables.

Gai-lan sauteed with fragrant wine was cooked just right and scented wonderful.

Baked chicken with sticky rice: a masterpiece of delicate cooking and a magnificent Chinese recipe. The details: your mouth meets the crispy chicken skin, then settles and savors the delicate sticky rice, small pieces of sausage and other herbs.  A delightful taste; recommended. This dish alone is suitable to be shared with at least six people. $39.00 is a bit pricey but worth it for exotica.

The Salted baked chicken was flavorful as well and moist and meaty.

The claypot of frog legs was fragrant; it was a genius mix of wine, black fungus, lily bulbs and frog legs. Honestly, it was tasty. I am not sure if frog legs are slightly chewy; but it was very tasty.

We devoured two big containers of their quality cooked steamed rice!

I thought all of the food was above average quality and you pay for it.   :)

Customer service: excellent and attentive.

Parking: street

Bathrooms: ok
author: Bert K.

description: They were open, even though it was a Monday and Labor Day. I went in and ordered some fried rice to go. They were quite busy and I was pretty grungy, but they were polite and quickly filled my order. When I got home, the fried rice was good. I have no complaints and will no doubt return.
author: Robert H.

description: I took my 2 elderly aunts (85 and 90 years old) to lunch and they chose this place.  There are many Chinese restaurants in San Francisco serving similar dishes so I was expecting the same kind of food.  This restaurant is a step above; the food was exceptional and the portions are generous.  They also offer a family special where you can choose 3 dishes for under $30 (including rice and tea).  We ordered beef and green beans, peking spareribs, and tofu clay pot.  We also ordered chow mein made with thin noodles.  Everything was great, but if I had to pick a favorite, it would have to be the Peking spareribs - the flavor was amazing and the meat was so tender it melted in our mouths.  The service was also pretty good, the waitress walked around constantly to make sure all the patrons were satisfied.  This might be my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco!
author: Antonia M.

description:
Hakka Restaurant is a very family-style restaurant. This means large tables for 6 or more, large dishes, and lazy susans.

I came here with 2 other people after a stroll at land's end and was starving. We sat upstairs at a corner table (the only non-round table up there) and received a delicious lotus beef soup while waiting. Among the three of us, we shared a lamb dish, a white chicken and veggies dish, green beans and minced pork, and the sticky rice in lotus wrap. Everything tasted pretty good but I was not blown away. We had a hella leftovers (about 4 meals worth for one person).

-lamb dish & chicken dish:  lamb tasted just like beef (probably was beef) and came with veggies that were mostly identical to the white chicken and veggies dish. I had hoped for different veggies between the two since the picture seemed to suggest that. However, both were well-cooked (crunchy veggies, tender meats) with a variety of ingredients. 

-sticky rice: was not sticky and had a lot of really greasy peanuts (small pieces of everything else) but the flavor of the leaf was well infused (subtle) which added to the somewhat dry rice. Not bad. I wouldn't order this again since everything came with rice so the sticky rice was a little unecessary. 

-green beans: really good--preserved veggies and minced pork flavors were on point ( a little salty) but I enjoyed it. 

I'm only giving it 3 stars because the veggie/meat dishes were both too sauced up which left me really dehydrated. While the texture was bomb, the flavors didn't come through enough in these two dishes. The other ones were decent but not amazing. 

Basically great serving sizes, lots of well-cooked food with OK flavors, and come with a large group!
author: Lydia Z.

description: Hidden gem in a quiet neighborhood. Food is pretty good and decent. Nothing too special for chinese food. Parking can be a bit difficult and challenging depending on the time.
author: JADE L.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the bay area. I would come here more often if it wasn't all the way towards the ocean. Service is always friendly and the food is good. It all very flavorful. Great for family dinners or when you and your friends want to pig out with good food that wouldn't break your wallet. 

My favorites and recommendations: 
**Crab with Salted Egg (the BESTt!!) 
**Clams with Spicy Salt and Black Bean Sauce (like peppercorn) 
**Chinese Bacon with Preserved Green
**Fu Yu Ong Choy
author: Sandy B.

description: I liked this place right away.  A neighborhood restaurant, fully immersed in the middle of a comfortably middle class Asian neighborhood, not a major commercial area.  Many of the people who eat here are likely, I figure, to live nearby and aren't likely to put up with bad food.  A quick glance at the photos on the windows registered another plus on my quality meter: tasty looking beauty shots of the food, but better were the quaint misspelled words that indicate to me the place isn't all that twisted by our anglo culture.  Hang onto your Asian heritage as long as you can, folks.  In my book it's more often good than not, that you find "salter pepper prawns" or "x and y with bran curb" on the menu.  So, this meal we had the freshest seafood won ton soup ever, delicious braised pork belly with preserved vegetable, and perfectly cooked pea vines.  The rest of the extensive menu will take more than a few visits, but somehow I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Bob S.

description:
Beware: As of March 2017 the Food Safety score is a very low 62.
.
My friends from China tell me this style is authentic to Southern Chinese.  Many photographs of popular dishes decorating the walls made it easier to narrow down our choices. 

For us the service has been great. To begin, a complementary Winter Mellon and dry Bok Choi Soup was brought out. Then our plates were replaced with fresh ones half way through and at our conclusion chilled orange wedges were a welcome sweet surprise.

The food:
At $12.95 the Cold Marinated Half Chicken was juicy and the $10.95 Stuffed Tofu was deliciously different. Their $15.95 Basil Clams were definitely basil, a little spicy and not at all rubbery. The $10.95 Pineapple Pork Rib was bite size and easy to eat. I loved the onion family veggie that came with it. And, the $9.95 Mustard Greens with Preserved Egg was a personal favorite.
.
All and all this was a great value for the price. If Im not killed by food poisoning, I look forward to trying more dishes.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Great Chinese food in the Outer Richmond district of SF.  The staff are fast, friendly, and speak English well.  There's also an upstairs when the place is packed.  For Chinese New Year, it's the perfect restaurant to have a family feast.  Parking can be a challenge, especially at dinner time, as with any SF neighborhood.  They bring out complimentary soup and dessert.  There's always plenty to take home for seconds the next day.  I love me some Hakka cuisine!  Get the pork belly, pan-fried stuffed tofu, eggplant, fish, fried pumpkin, and many more authentic dishes.  

This used to be owned by The Claypot House before selling it to the owners of Hakka.  Can't wait to have our Chinese New Year dinner here, extremely festive.  I can't hear anyone during dinner, they're hella loud, good way to avoid conversations with the family HA!  

Happy Year of the Monkey ~ prosperity to all =)
author: Christine R.

description: Look at the health score. 62? Not only do they not mind cooking with vermin present they will serve you food that was served to a previous guest.  Walk in there for a take out order? Only do that if you have special enzymes in your stomach AND you are of Chinese decent. They will ignore you if you are white.    Food was bleh and after reading about their health score I will never eat there again. 62 health score and it hasn't been inspected in almost 2 years?
author: Anthony R.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the food that we had at Hakka Restaurant. The dishes were large and quality was above average in regards to most Asian restaurants. We opted to order a la carte as opposed to a set menu, and I definitely recommend this as the way to go if you want to try a variety of menu items.

Favorite dishes of the night:
Whole steamed chicken - juicy, tender and had a flavor unlike the ginger/scallion
Ox tail clay pot - so much ox tail!
Sauteed pea sprouts - fresh and crisp
Pumpkin coated in salted egg yolk - salty, sweet....I didn't think I would enjoy this dish as much as I did

Least favorite dishes of the night:
Catfish and bitter melon clay pot - fish wasn't cleaned well, tasted fishy
Fried tofu and fried eggplant - though seasoned well...the fried eggplant just didn't hit the spot. It tasted like tempura vegetable.
Sweet and sour pork - apparently, they prep it exactly how hakka cuisine calls for it, but it was definitely on the sour side for me and nothing too special

Other orders:
Sticky rice in lotus leaves
Lamb with sauteed vegetables

All in all, it was a good meal
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Came here with a group of 8, and it was your traditional family style Chinese restaurant with giant pictures of the food displayed on the walls.  We called ahead and luckily didn't have to wait long for a table and were seated pretty promptly.

Since we had a big group we decided to go with the $148 pre-set dinner for 8, which is what I'll be basing the majority of my review on.  The seafood soup was good, its pretty standard for most Chinese places, especially with the white pepper which makes all the difference.  The next dish was salted/breaded pork, which had a strange flavor to it.  The picture might make it look like your standard salt and pepper pork, but the breading had an unfamiliar flavor -- maybe it's the style of the region, but I was personally not a fan.  The hainan chicken was decent, though hardly any meat on the bones at all.  Same with the crab with garlic glass noodles.  The bitter mellon stew with catfish was extremely bitter - one of my friends commented that he might as well have licked the floor.  The only dish I really liked was the chinese bacon, which was delicious since the fat melted in your mouth.

Overall, the consensus around the table was that the food was subpar, but it could be that we're not used to the region/style of cooking.
author: Roger W.

description:
Last night we tried Hakka Restaurant in the Outer Richmond of San Francisco. We arrived at 7:40 pm and the place was packed with large tables with a large table party waiting but my daughter was able to get the last available table. No wait.

Our waitress was very patient as we decided on our order. Service was excellent as our plates filled with shells and bones they were promptly exchanged. The food came out fast.
We ordered the following:

Surf Clam 4 stars

Minced pork and garlic clams 4 stars

Stir fried pea sprouts 4 stars

Crab with salty duck egg yolk batter 5 stars best dish of the night salty and savory a must order

Honey and black bean sauce pork ribs 4 stars 

Fresh bass with pork and pickled mustard greens sauce 2 stars the bass was over cooked and the sauce was strange It over powered the fish. 

Parking is not easy in this area. $141 before tip.
author: George F.

description: Oh snap this is off the wall. I came here for a lunch break and after seeing some Hakka food online I thought I give it a shot. They have a nice menu full of many choices that you don't see in your average Chinatown restaurant. I love the location here. It's very close to my workplace and all it took was less than 20 minutes for me to get here. I recommend the chicken, it's done the way I wanted and the taste is on point. I have some coworkers who are regulars here and they cannot take their mouths off this place. This restaurant is rather bigger than I expect and finding a seat here is not too bad if you cone here for a lunch break. Drinks are good as with any Chinese restaurant there is complimentary tea. I must say the tea is real good here. It's not bland and smells nice. All the food is worth the price if you work in SF
author: Michael W.

description:
The best salted egg crab I've ever had! A must order and we had two different orders of crab! The other one was okay, it was the chili one. Cannot compare to all the yummy goodness of salted egg crab and pumpkin mmmmm. I could eat an entire dish of the fried pumpkin that comes with the crab and turn into a little pumpkin myself.

Had my Grandpas 91st birthday lunch here with the fambam, aka the only time I find myself eating Chinese food. We ordered a ridiculous amount of dishes and had to box some up as soon as it got to the table because we had no room for it on the table and in our tummies. 

The seafood soup was amazing I had two bowls. Sticky rice was an all around favorite as well. Apparently my aunt is a regular here and staff was super friendly. Gave us extra soup and everything. 

There's a food safety alert on for this place but I didn't notice anything glaringly dirty and I am cursed with always finding hair and random bits of god knows what in my food. Very easy street parking. Food came out super fast. No complaints!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Food is great, one of our favorites in the city. Fried salty egg pumpkin crab, and Chinese bacon are my personal favorites.
author: Brian L.

description:
This was uh, pretty bad. We got the pork belly dish and a veggie dish and both dishes were sickeningly sweet. Both dishes were glazed with a layer of sugar infused sauce... Yuck. 
However, we did also get the porridge dish and it was good.
author: Melody Y.

description:
Came here after reading some rave reviews on yelp. I should have listened to the ones that pointed out the awful service and disgusting conditions. Our party of three was seated and not even glanced at again, for more than 15 minutes. No offer of water or any drinks. When we finally flagged down a waitress to take our order she really did seem like she'd rather be dead than serve us. Other people were desperately trying to get the attention of the servers the whole time we were too. 

Food was hot and tasted good but not worth the trouble at all. They threw the plates of food down and took off, startling all of us. The restaurant was not incredibly crowded either. We asked a waitress for drinks and when she brought the glasses my friend noticed a lipstick mark on the cup she was given. But, only as she started pouring the soda into the cup. She wasn't wearing lipstick, this was a dirty glass. 

They won't split a bill for your party, either. Usually not a big deal but really irritating by the time we were ready to pay. 

Give a different place a try instead, unless you are a fan of the type of service that kills your appetite.
author: Jenny W.

description:
This is one of the restaurants that's always on my mines. A place of my guilty pleasure. Their braise belly is just a mouth watering, umami packed, goodness. I also can never have enough of their pumpkin with salted egg yolk dish. Always bring a friend or three so you can order more dishes to try. Family style dinner is the way to go. One thing I'd say to sway from is their surf clam as they are expensive and are only mediocre. 

The decor of the place is not that great and the service is on par with a lot mid-tier Chinese restaurants (not the best service), but I'd say this is the place to be if you're looking for a flavor packed dinner. I've revisited a few times with months in between, the flavors/tastes of dishes are fairly consistent. 

Pro(s):
- Delicious (consistent) dishes

Con(s):
- Out of the way
- Only ok service
author: Alan L.

description:
Update: I came here for the 2nd time in a month, and I wasn't as happy as my previous times. Downgrading my vote. 

Why? 
- Grimy, dirty dishes. My plate had a ring of dirt around the edge and bottom
- In general, service wasn't that good. When I've previously come, it's been with people who frequent this restaurant, so we got attentive service. But when I was here with a different group, the service was rushed and impersonal.
- Let's be real... afterwards nearly everyone in my group had to go #2 in the bathroom. The food was pretty greasy and didn't sit well. One person said it just had an overall dirty feel. 

And now onto the positive-

The food still tasted good, even though it has that hole-in-the-wall feel. We liked the the steamed crab w/ green onion sauce atop vermicelli noodles, the popular crispy chicken sticky rice, the pan-fried tofu was tasty, and house special basil clams.  Though I wasn't a fan of how they cooked their gai lan (with a sweeter rice vinegar sauce). 

Another thing- it's all Chinese customers at this place. Hakka village food- this place serves authentic dishes.
author: Joanna L.

description:
The restaurant is well decorated and slightly cramped with extra tables and seating upstairs (it's behind all the tables next to the kitchen doors in case you don't know where it is)

The waitress was very nice and had a smile on her face the whole time and refilled our tea kettle numerous times and had a bright attitude but the service was quite slow. It took at least 10 minutes for them to take our order and bring soup and tea to our table and another 30+ wait time for our food to come out. But don't let that fool you because the food was delicious and full of flavor. It was definitely worth the wait.
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
But much to say about the service. The restaurant is clean enough to not be an issue; though the utensils did have that Ajax feeling to them.

The food was pretty good, especially the frog breaded with salted egg volk.
author: Ken T.

description:
~ Hozzie Bear says... ~

What do you get when you order fish bladder in your saucy rice?

Some Maw the Fukien Fried Rice!
Hakka hakka hakkaaa!

(-_^) Chinese Bacon w Al Green $11.95* (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hakka-restaurant-san-francisco?select=hnNvajkTa_nAwBcRui1dEA)
(-_^) Baked Crab w Yellow Submayolk $49.95* (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hakka-restaurant-san-francisco?select=Etu76oib86LLJdBpjDQnhw)
(#_#) Fukien Fried Rice #isathingbtw (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hakka-restaurant-san-francisco?select=7euqDaswEdvmuhGfp5VtQw)

Bring your family.
And your family's family.
Plus like 2 token white families.
That's how packed it gets.
Don't RSVP; I didn't & got a 5-top.

Wall posters have a few off-menu items.
3 1/2 rounded up for cray menu & "entertainment".

*Not menu price but receipt price, which they say includes tax.
author: Dan B.

description: Tasty Chinese food in the neighborhood. Steamed catfish, lettuce cups, and preserved vegetables with pork stomach were spot on.  A bit heavy handed on the oil was the only negative.
author: Peter T.

description:
Coming with a large group, you tend to expect some problems, particularly during the Lunar New Year.  But having to seat 16 people around a table with 10 chairs is really a bit problematic.  Extra chairs were brought in, but the table was simply too small for a 60% increase in dining capacity.  

The food tasted fine and as expected - a little oily, but generally OK.  Service was satisfactory, given the crowd.

Neighborhood street parking has always been difficult whenever we dine here, so be prepared.
author: Terence L.

description: Love it! Great egg yolk pumpkin and water spinach. Very popular with locals. Can be tricky to park.
author: Ian R.

description:
If I could give zero stars I would!!

Sequence of events in order: found a bug in our soup, obviously we were not happy about it so we placed our bowls back on the table, server approaches and says with a smirk on her rude face, "oh you're not going to eat that right?", had it taken away with no pause for our answer or even an offer for a replacement, found a rock (YES, a piece of ROCK) in our lotus wrapped sticky rice, which we passed along to the server who just inspected it and walked away with it, AGAIN with no offer of a replacement or even any sincere apology, then were given no complimentary dessert, got charged for the wrong amount on our bill, left with a bitter taste in our mouth for such a sour night, and currently paying for it all on the toilet. FML

PLEASE AVOID AT ALL COSTS!

Obviously this place does not take cleanliness or sanitation seriously. I've attached a notice that even YELP tacked on for this establishment.

Please reconsider if you even think about coming here!!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
WORST RESTAURANT IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!

in a nutshell: rude staff, bad health score, terrible food

I feel the need to update this because I live on the same block and am continually disgusted by the food poisoning they spread to their unsuspecting customers. Plus, the staff is SO RUDE to the neighborhood. They have actually intimidated my neighbor and yell at neighbors all the time. WHY WOULD YOU GO HERE?

My previous review: 

Wow, awful food and atrocious service. How can this place always be so crowded?? Save your time and money and eat at Hunan Cafe just down the street, that place is WAY better and the owner is so sweet and helpful. 

The staff at Hakka is ruder than I've ever experienced at any restaurant in the city. Seriously, do not go here. They yell at their customers and litter cigarettes in the street outside the restaurant. How delightful for the nearby residents.
author: June L.

description: It's okay but I would have liked the place to be a little bit cleaner the people here are really nice however the food is very mediocre but I gave it a three-star maybe I should have gave it to stir cuz it just looks like a dirty Chinese restaurant but foods not bad at all.
author: Michele T.

description:
I wasn't wowed, but would still recommend this place.  Here's why: the food tastes exactly what I eat at home with family.  For me, it's too ordinary but it's also a good testament of how authentic the food is  
Ordered all their signature items: Stickey Rice in Lotus Lead ($12.95) Pumpkin Strips with Salted Egg ($7.95), Turnips & Spareribs in Clay Pot ($8.95), Chinese Bacon with Preserved Green ($10.95).
No complaints with the food and it seems the local loves it as well.  My aunt loves coming here and its' been a weekly thing for her recently.  The boss lady has a great relationship with the customers as well.  She was so sweet in coming over to talk to us and even gave us a slight customer loyalty discount.  
Like I said, I get this food at home often, but I would recommend it to others to try.
author: David W.

description:
Always satisfied when I come here. Food is delicious to the point where its definitely a go-to place if I can't decide what to eat in San Francisco and you need to accommodate to the taste buds of your elderly Chinese relatives. 

I havent tried anything i didnt like so far but im going to call out the Lotus fried rice and quail because it is on point. So personally I feel like you can't really go wrong with anything you order here. Complimentary piping hot soup and dessert is great for a cold day.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Great Hakka food (a type of Chinese food different than Cantonese food and other regional specialities). The place is no frills and seems like your typical humble Chinese restaurant but rest assured the food isn't typical. Prices are reasonable for chinese sit down.

The specialty is "stuffed chicken" which is really whole fried chicken skin on top of sticky rice cooked with Chinese sausages. It will taste greasy and indulgent but it will different from anything else you've ever had. There isn't as much chicken as I would have liked and it's mostly rice but definitely an experience. It normally requires advance ordering (I think the day before) but we managed to get it on the spot.

There was also a giant clam with glass noodles inside the shell that was excellent. Comes in two shells.

The fish and tofu clay pot is excellent too.

Service is prompt but don't expect any of that non Chinese restaurant smile and friendliness!
author: Victor W.

description:
Awesome chinese food

Pork belly is a must!!!!

If you don't know what to order their menu has pictures

Clean, casual atmosphere 

Don't expect fancy service. It is a chinese restaurant that focus on their awesome food;)
author: Carol Y.

description:
The food here is really good. The flavors are on point and well seasoned. The short ribs with black pepper & honey sauce is insanely good. The house special steamed chicken is really tender and flavorful. The prawn with maggi sauce is also really good as well. Honestly, everything here is pretty good. 

My only gripe is that I found a few dead ants in my sautéed veggies. The veggies are really good but if you don't look closely you'll be getting extra protein that you didn't ask for.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
attention : this restaurant has a 62/100 food safety score that's a d- .  why would you take your children and family members here? why?? 

rude staff. bad food.  scurge on the neighborhood.
author: Bryan C.

description:
Yeah... neither did we order the Chinese hangar (kau yuk) nor the other notable Hakkanese specialties.. 

but I did order for my folks the frog legs and kabocha squash fried in a batter of salted duck egg yolk, spicy sauteed pig intestine and veg, and the salted and pepper baked whole chicken (at $23, I was duped, cuz it was not good!).

the photos may look shiny, but something was amiss this time. We were let down, sadly. Tastiest dish ordered was the ever-encompassing peppery (laden with another layer of Sichuan reds) pig intestine with celery stir-fry.

Ken is right; order a day ahead and come get all of their regional specialties. that's the game plan for the next round, anyway.
author: Jana C.

description:
Easily one of the best and most affordable birthday meals I have had this year. Thank you B.T.E.C and ladies!! And special thank you to my gf Ronnie for making the reservation. 
I know what you guys are thinking - reservation at a Chinese restaurant, seriously? 

Yes, seriously.

If you have a big group it is highly recommended you make one. This place gets PACKED and it is a residential area. Parking can be tricky (Richmond District sucks but not as much as the Mission)

I lost count of how many dishes we had but we easily had more than 5, and it was about $25 a person.

Must order: 

salted egg yolk pumpkin & crab - SO DELICIOUS. good amount of sliced pumpkin too. this is one of my favorite crab preparations. Hakka is FAMOUS for this, and for good reason. Gritty from the salted egg yolk, a bit salty, a bit sweet from the kabocha pumpkin and crab meat... 

Hakka does clams with spicy salt and black bean sauce.. I swear it's called typhoon clams? I could be wrong. Either way it is damn good. Salty, spicy, slightly crispy... finger licking good.
author: Susy C.

description: Don't ever order takeouts from this restaurant. It will be the most dangerous thing you can experience. The to go box was melted! When I tried to take it out, the food spilled not only on the floor but also my leg. And it almost spilled on my three years old cousin's face. It almost scalded the little kid's face! When I called the restaurant, they did not even say a word of apology. They told me that I should not let a child touch the food. It made me feel like it was my fault to be scaled. Although they served me with new food, it did not worth it.
author: Jiaqi P.

description:
A group of 16 or so of us came in on a Friday afternoon and got two tables. I kind of felt bad for the woman who was the only server working at that time of day. She wasn't the most friendly, but she served our tables well. (Like my mom tried to ask her to bring some forks and a few glasses of water, and when she came back bringing out food without forks or water, my mom gently reminded her, and she said [in Chinese], "I know, I know! Food more important!" ... which was actually kind of funny.) 

She also tried to be helpful and told me which dishes were vegetarian, although there ended up being only one dish I could eat because the other vegetarian/vegan dishes she pointed out contained wheat (not her fault, as my uncle didn't make clear to her what I could eat).

But my uncle has been ordering take-out from here for years, and he has always been able to get me this delicious Gai-Lan (Chinese broccoli) dish made with a white wine sauce. He made sure to get that again here, as well as a Chinese mustard greens dish with garlic. Both were quite good.
author: Barbara C.

description: The one thing I wished we had ordered was the salted crab and pumpkin, but I guess you can't have everything. Everything else we ordered, however, was pretty dang good, and the price point wasn't steep at all. If you speak Hakka, and are from the area, you know this is legitimate food. They have this dish that takes a day to make. So, the normal glutinous sticky rice dish that comes in banana leaf has a Hakka variation. You take the sticky rice and pan fry it so that the edges are all crispy and brown. You then fashion and decorate the entire dish to look like a whole fried chicken, except when you cut into it, it's actually "no mai gai". Soo good. They do some classic variations too, like wok-fried fish with pickled vegetables and frog legs. Reminds me of home cooking. It's still gruff and dirty, like all good Chinese restaurants, but you'll have a good time here.
author: Danny C.

description:
One of the nicer Chinese restaurants I've been to! We came here to celebrate mothers day with my whole extended family and they graciously allowed us to reserved 3 tables! This is not a really big restaurant too, so 3 tables is a lot! At my table we had:

E2. BLACK & PEPPER PORK CHOP*
E6. SPICY SALT & PEPPER SPARERIBS*
F9. HONEY WALNUT PRAWNS
I6. BRAISED FISH FILLET & TOFU IN CLAY POT
J3. STRING BEANS*
L8. PAN FRIED SEAFOOD NOODLE
S3. HOUSE SPECIAL PAN FRIED TOFU
S2. CHINESE BACON
L10. HOUSE SPECIAL SEAFOOD YEE NOODLE
M6. FUKIEN FRIED RICE

I think we had a couple more dishes but I forgot which ones. Everything was delicious but L10 and M6. were just AMAZING! I pretty much love all fukien fried rice so thats a gimme, but the house special seafood yee mein is wow.... you guys need to go try it. Overall I had an amazing experience! The waiters were nice and service was fast. 5 stars!!!!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Just had dinner with with my families here, 2 tables, 20 people, and spent $400 plus. 

Conclusion: food is ok and average. There is better quality all round the city.

Service is horrible: 

Asked for a high chair twice. Server never bothered to bring it. When I got pissed and got up to get it on my own and only to find out that the server we asked was toying on his smartphone in the back!

2 dishes we ordered never came. They tried to overcharge us for a whole ginger chicken which in reality we only had half ($16 difference). Charged $18 for a veggie dish where it actually says $12 on the menu. Charged us $13 where it says $9.95 per item. Too many coincidences on one bill or their practice to overcharge u hoping u don't check your bill? 
      This is my second time eating here with the families, and it will sure be my last.

Not recommended.
author: Larry W.

description:
Why are so many people eating at this place?

Service:
We needed 2 tables but the waiter was very rude and wanted our party of 14 people to sit in ONLY one table. 

Ambiance:
There are almost-torn down posters of food items (with the wrong names) hung on the walls of this restaurant. 

Cleanliness:
Very very dirty despite a very large number of people walking in and out of the restaurant every minute.

Food:
Soup appetizer: There was a GIANT piece of wire in my soup! 
Spicy salt and pepper spareribs: Too much breading! A huge no no!
Clams with spicy salt: Too spicy for my taste buds
Fish fillet with XO sauce: Just meh; nothing special
String bean with minced pork in XO sauce: The only thing notable is its spiciness level 

Maybe Hakka food isn't my thing and I'm more used to Cantonese food but this restaurant definitely does not meet my expectations of a great restaurant. There are WAY better  Chinese restaurants in the area with more amazing options.
author: Chel C.

description:
After stuffing my face at the restaurant, I'm sad to say my overall impression was one of "meh". First of all, almost everything at the restaurant is very heavy on the salt, that just kills it for me because it overwhelms all over flavors. I think if they didn't employ the "when it rains, it pours" method with the NaCl, I would have enjoyed the food a lot more.

We shared the pork belly with preserved veggies, the hakka tofu, the crab, the clams, the bean sprouts, the house steam chicken and the lotus wrapped rice.

My favorite, surprisingly, was the pork belly. The meat were perfectly tender and didn't taste fatty, and it wasn't too salty. If anything, I would expect that dish to be heavier on the salt (due to the preserved veggies), but the sweetness of the preserved winter vegetable balanced out the dish.

The hakka tofu was disappointing. This is the quintessential Hakka dish and it was just run of the mill stuffed tofu. There was nothing special about it, just salty meat stuffed tofu with some salty nondescript sauce. Booo!

The house steam chicken was tender, well, let me rephrase, the dark meat portion of the chicken was very tender and flavorful, although continuing with the theme through out, salty. The breast meat pieces tasted over cooked like your average chicken. Pass!

The lotus wrapped rice was deceiving... the leave was for presentation only. I could not taste a hint of the lotus leaf flavor in the rice. The rice was also pretty one note, the only thing in there were the rice and Chinese sausage, no mushrooms or dried shrimp. The sparse sprinkling of scallions did add some flavor, but it needs a lot more scallions to make up for the one-note flavor of the dish. 

The crab was salty and the crab is small. I guess it's not crab season, but I just had the crab at R&G Lounge a few weeks ago and I swear the crab there is 50% larger than the one tonight. It had good flavor, although too much salt. They did a good job of cracking all the shells, though, to make it easier to eat. would be nice if they give us some utensils to help us dig out the meat and some wet toilets to get the fishy taste off our fingers. Would be a nice dish during the crab season.

The clam was probably the saltiest dish of the day. It had a thin batter and is fried. I've never had clam cooked like that before. Like the crab, the flavors are there, but it needs less salt. I'm neutral on this one.

Lastly, we also got the pea sprout. I really enjoyed it. The seasoning level was right and it tasted fresh. Just garlic and the pea sprouts, something lighter to go with the other artery blockers that we ordered.

All in all, I don't think I'll come back here. I can't believe it has a 4 star rating!! Generally in a neighborhood as competitive as the Richmond, a 4 star rating means something. I usually don't like a lot of salt in my food, but the other people at my table agreed that the food was too salty, too. I think if there was less salt, I would give it 3-3.5 stars. Sigh..
author: Alice W.

description:
Each time I come here with my family there's always at least a 10 minute wait, except for today because we went earlier than normal. 

Atmosphere: The tables here are sort of crowded , but that's because they have to accommodate high volumes of customers. I would say, the decorations and ambiance is like any other typical chinese restaurant: Asian art and picture, etc. I like that they have pictures of their popular dishes posted on the walls along with the chinese and american name of the dish.

Service: great and fast service with food. they greet you when you come in and thank you on the way out. 

Food: The food is very tasty and of course authentic and flavors definitely do not disappoint. The only down side to their dishes was their oily-ness. All their dishes are a bit too oily for my taste except for a few dishes we got. 

But overall a great place to check out if you're looking for a new asain restaurant to try out. I'm pretty sure my family will be back sooner or later for another meal!
author: Samantha F.

description:
I love this place and I mean it. No restaurant can cook Chinese food as legitimately and consistently as Hakka, not even Koi blergh Palace or Asian ew Pearl. I've never been disappointed each time I've come here. It can get packed for weekend dinner, but the lunch deals here are just as good and the same portions and even cheaper!

Hakka serves very homey, comfort Hakka Chinese food--steaming fresh straight from da wok and very favorful. I highly recommend the yolk-coated fried pumpkin slices, the pineapple sweet and sour ribs, and the pork belly. Pretty much everything is good here, but those 3 are just my favorites.
author: Cheri S.

description: Very authentic hakka cuisine, which is very rare. The complimentary soup served is always super, unlike a lot of other Chinese restaurants. The entrees are huge and good for the entire family. Have tried more than 10 different entrees here and non of them disappointed. Try the pork belly and lamb claypot!
author: Alan C.

description:
Solid overall experience. 

The frog leg and bitter melon was a great dish, and the frog legs were fresh and flavorful -- most places have a "previously frozen" taste to them. The balance of frog legs (too few) to bitter melon (too many) was the only issue with it.

Our other dishes were good too, although less notable. Portions are huge ad prices are low. The food is sometimes on the greasy/oily side, although this is pretty par for the course.
author: David C.

description:
4 of us went for dinner. Ordered the following:

1.Spicy Salt & Pepper Eggplant w/ Bean Curd - a bit bland..it needed more salt

2. Salt baked chicken (half order) - takes 1/2 hour to cook - too salty, but the chicken was moist

3. XO Sauce Pig Stomach w/ Mixed Mushrooms- yummy and had a good spice kick

4. Spicy Salt & Pepper (Bay Fung Tong) Clams - Very tasty

5. Oyster w/ Honey Sauce - not bad, just ok

Prior to your meal, you're given a  complimentary (big) bowl of soup with pork, carrots, and potatoes for starters. For dessert, we were given complimentary cut oranges.

I will definitely be back to try the pork belly, chicken stuffed with sticky rice (which has to be ordered in advance), and other items on their menu.

Pros:
Inexpensive 
Dishes came out fast
Service was decent

Cons:

Parking sucks
Gets packed at 6pm

If you plan on coming with a large group, make reservations!
author: Candice H.

description:
We stopped in for a late evening snack and really enjoyed the experience.  Always a good sign for Chinese food when most of the clientele are Chinese!  We had the fried Tofu and house special hot sauce with lamb.
You get a big bowl of the house soup.  Nice broth but lacked a depth of flavour.  The lamb was very tender however we had trouble tasting the lamb.  Almost like the flavour was steamed out?  The sauce was nice.  I asked for extra spicy and while it had a bit of a kick, I wouldn't call it spicy.  The Tofu was well done however it was a bit thin with accompanying veggies.
Very efficient and friendly service.  Glad we stopped in.
author: Gary H.

description:
Came here this past Mother's Day weekend and it was PACKED! Now I'm not Hakka but I am Malaysian and being that I've spent quite some time there, there are quite a bit of Hakka descendants in the country and their food is DELICIOUS which brings me to this place.... such a let down...granted we really ordered 2 dishes that were Hakka-specific.

We made reservations for 7:30pm but still had to wait about a half hour.... Once we finally settled in, we ordered a bunch of dishes: pork belly with preserved mustard greens (hakka dish) and this sticky rice dish (hakka dish and my mom ordered it), lamb & bitter melon clay pot, 2 orders of steamed meat in tofu, walnut shrimp, ginger green onion crab, ginger green onion lobster, sweet n' sour pork, garlic string beans, garlic pea shoots, soup, and chicken with ginger sauce. I think that was all of it.... quite the order but there were at least 10 of us there.

Anyways, the pork belly with preserved mustard greens was sweet... not salty and had a funny taste...definitely not authentic. They have Americanized that dish like most dishes at panda express. The sticky rice was alright.... my mom says it may have been an off-night because it's usually more flavorful and the rice is softer.... The walnut shrimp was by far the worst plate, it was overly dressed with mayonnaise and had a very unpleasant taste, definitely something I would never order again. As for the rest of the dishes, they were decent...basically as expected from any other Chinese restaurant but nothing outstanding.

I'll go here again if it was another obligated family dinner but not something I would go out of the way for... it's literally at the far-end of town in comparison to where I live. Oh and can I mention the parking.... it is all residential and terrible! We circled around for 20+ minutes before we found something. So if you want to come to this place, get here early for parking and possibly the long wait as I've read on other reviews but based on my case alone of still having to wait 30 minutes despite having reservations...yeah... get here early.
author: Mark L.

description:
I really can't stop raving about the pork belly here. It's a bustling myriad of flavors! Pork belly has become a pretty popular cut to use in the foodie scene, but very few places make it right. Sometimes you just gotta stick with the old fashioned stuff.

Do yourself a favor. Put down that Chairman Barf crap, and treat yourself to something that's actually good. Think the buta kakuni from your favorite izakaya place is tasty? Nope, come here. Oh, you've had the famous Glazed Pork Belly from Michelin-starred Redd in Yountville? You'll ask yourself, "Why did I pay twice as much for not as good pork belly??" Seriously. You get twice the amount at Hakka too.
author: Nei N.

description:
Service: Our server looked like she would rather be lying in a ditch than serving us.

Price: What you would expect from a run-down Chinese restaurant.

Food: Everything is seasoned well, but the amount of oil they add to their dishes is vomit-inducing.. literally. I yakked 10 minutes after dining here. 

Conclusion: If you like interacting with rude servers and often down a pint of oil at every meal, this is the perfect restaurant for you.
author: Cass Y.

description: Tried out this restaurant.  Great place for large groups in the Richmond area.  Decent sized portions and unique Hakka-style dishes.
author: Adrian C.

description:
(Yelp - three stars is "A-OK"?)

Anyway, any place that doesn't pass health dept inspections should not get more than 3 stars. 

I really have a formula for a 4-star restaurant: clean kitchen, clean dining room, fresh ingredients, average service, average cooking skills. Am I asking too much.
author: YM L.

description:
You can order items a la carte or in a family-style set dinner.  I would highly recommend the set dinners.  You can substitute in the Egg Yolk Crab for a nominal charge and get a bevy of other eats (dishes include stir-fried fish fillets, stuffed tofu, veggies, house special chicken, Peking pork, soup of the day, and fresh fruit for dessert = $~70).

The star of the show is the crab.  Have you ever tried Chinese salted egg?  They dip the crab in the yolk and bake it.  The result?  Sweet, tender crab meat mixed with an almost buttery, savory flavor.  Words (especially mine) don't do it justice.  It was divine.  As in eat-every-morsel-and-crumb delicious. 

Try to visit at an odd time to avoid the long lines!
author: Sheila C.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night with my boyfriend because we were in the area. Service was fast. They gave complimentary pork/veggie soup which was nice.

We ordered the pork belly with veggies, fried rice, bean sprouts with garlic, and garlic clams. All the dishes were quite big so we had to take half of it to go. Pork belly was pretty good but eating chunks of fat is best when it's cut up into smaller pieces! The veggies were great (had great flavor and was nicely prepared), and I think I enjoyed the clams so much because of the fried garlic/pieces rather than the clams themselves.

Would come back if in the area, and would maybe try the egg yolk dishes.
author: Siv L.

description:
Inexpensive and delicious!  My extended family came here for our yearly Chinese New Year dinner.  I believe it was 10 courses with both lobster and crab for less than $200 per table of 10.  Yes please!  We basically took up half of the downstairs with just my family!

This place is definitely for those who want real Chinese food.  I saw mostly Chinese people while I was there.  One of my friends (who's Caucasian) is a little scared of this place since they post pictures of some of their dishes and they are a little too, I guess I could say, authentic for him.  So come here if you're in the mood for super Chinesey food!

Some of my favs were the Salt Egg Yolk Crab and the Ginger Scallion Lobster.  I have a pet peeve with overcooked seafood and both retained their juicy seafood flavor.  No rubbery shellfish here!

We unfortunately didn't get the braised pork belly, but we had the lettuce cups, fish, fried rice, etc.  I don't quite remember them all and I didn't take any pix to remind me, but I was super happy and satisfied after the meal.

We had an early dinner at 5:30pm, so we didn't have to wait for a table.  But after we were done, there was a crowd of Chinese people in the doorway and outside waiting for us to leave.  This is the only minus.  I'd definitely recommend an early dinner if you're coming here!
author: Elena N.

description:
I don't go to a lot of Chinese restaurant but came here since i got invited here for dinner. This place is good for eating in group with family or friends but you need reservation since this place can get busy during dinner time. 

Its the typical chinese food at this restaurant that you usually see at most chinese restaurant. Did the family style dinner. The foods that we had were average but still tasty. Had a lot food from the family style dinner. The food that we had were:
1. Lettuce wrap
2. Crab
3. Soup
4. Chicken
5. Spareribs
6. Seafood and vegetable
7. Fish
8. Abalone/mushroom and bok choy
9. Fried rice
10. Orange

Reasonable price

Good service....brought the food out quick and family staffs. 

Parking can be difficult especially during the dinner time.
author: Julie N.

description:
Local joint, good service, good prices, easy reservations.  Ordered over 15 dishes among 7 of us and had plenty of nice leftovers.  Highlights were sticky rice lotus leaf, salted egg kabocha crab, sweet and sour pork, yellow skin chicken, salt baked chicken.  Steamed fish and ginger scallion lobster could be better.  

Place where speaking Chinese will help since their Engrish ain't so good.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came here with my family for my grandfather birthday. Overpriced food. Food were salty and greasy, served in low amount. Service was so-so. Only pro I would say it's just convenient since we lived not too far from there.

Went there with my friends. They gave us wrong dish and were insisting that we ordered it. When we ordered catfish and bittermelon, fish came out to be mushy chopped in pieces. Couldn't even hold it with my chopsticks. Didn't taste that great either. Probably served us an unfreshed one.
author: Envy K.

description: Recently stopped in for lunch and something interesting happened. They gave us a lunch menu with the wrong prices. They stated that the new prices probably felled off and showed us the new menu. Switch and bait or an honest mistake? Can't prove it.... so before ordering from the lunch menu, asked them if the price is correct. If this has happened to anyone please post.
author: Roland F.

description:
The restaurant is packed at 6:30 pm on a Saturday evening. Most tables are big which serves about 10 people. If your party is 4 or less, you should get there about 6 pm to avoid waiting for a table.

I went with 2 other people. We had 4 dishes. Plenty of food with leftover too. 

What we had:
1) Pumpkin with salty egg: Good
2) Pork belly: Fine
3) Black pepper fried Clam: Very good but a bit salty
4) House special tofu: Good


Check out my pictures.
author: Viva_Epicure ..

description:
Authentic Hakka style food!
If you would like to eat their signature salt baked chicken dish, make sure you order in advanced with your reservation. I did order 3 chicken for our Chinese new year dinner. Our group only ate 2 chicken, and the restaurant owner ask us if we want the 3rd one since they are run out of chicken :)
So make sure you order in advance, since they occasionally run out of salt baked chicken!
author: Dan A.

description: The won ton soup, orange chicken, Chinese broccoli, chicken chow fun and Kung Pow Chicken were all excellent! The flavor was excellent and very authentic!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Chinese Village Food? LOVE IT!

My mom grew up in one of the villages in China and introduced me to this type of cuisine early on. Apparently, this type of cuisine has a name, Hakka Cuisine which is what Hakka Restaurant (opened in January 2010) is named after; I learn something new every day. 

Hakka Cuisine can be attributed to environmental influences. To make up for the huge loss of salt content in their body from farming, Hakka migrants added more salt to food which also preserved the food longer. These qualities meet the nature of the Hakkas. This is why you will find several salt baked and salty egg yolk items on Hakka Restaurant's menu. 

Being the typical non-American born Asian, my mom believes in penny pinching and even a $5 bowl of wonton noodle soup she considers expensive. Needless to say, the only restaurants we went to were Chinese ones that offered $2.99, $3.99, and $4.99 main entree dishes (it's no wonder I now have severe allergies to MSG). Some of the Hakka-type dishes at these restaurants were not very authentic to say the least so Hakka Restaurant was a real treat for me. 

On Sunday, 11.13.11, my friend and I came to Hakka for dinner at 6:30 PM with reservations. It's very busy and chaotic on weekends, so RESERVATIONS ARE A MUST!

F O O D
Hakka is NOT a place to order sweet & sour pork, kung pao chicken, or chow mein (not sure if they even have that on the menu). Please save that for PF Chang's or Panda Express. 

Their most popular dishes are the lettuce cups with squab, salty egg yolk pumpkin strips, salty egg yolk crab, salt baked chicken, pork belly with preserved mustard greens, and house special pan fried tofu. You can request NO MSG be made with you food (YAY!). Since it was just my friend and I, we ordered the following: 

*HOT & SOUR SOUP (6.95) - 4 STARS
Warm and comforting, the hot & soup had an assertive sourness but wasn't overwhelming. The heat was just enough to awaken our tastebuds and leave a subtle heat on our palate. Bits of wooden ear fungus and tofu gave the soup some texture.

*SALTY EGG YOLK LOBSTER ($25.95) - 4 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pknqZiaDbSNFUnJrOpkKcw?select=SjRBhrPYxhYA0QEtRPGwzA
They didn't have crab available that night so we went for the lobster instead. An unlikely combination, the fried salty egg yolk crust adds a crispy texture contrast to the tenderly moist lobster. Together, the egg yolk and lobster married together creating a mouth-watering salty and sweet flavor.

*BRAISED PORK BELLY w/ Preserved Mustard Greens ($12.95) - 4.5 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pknqZiaDbSNFUnJrOpkKcw?select=o4ly8CJ04DTJtE3xeRNdMQ
The thick slices of pork belly were perfectly braised to a soft, melt-in-your-mouth butteryness. The sweet soy braising liquid imparted a lip-smacking savoryness with a hint of sweetness into the intensely rich pork. The mild sourness of the preserved mustard greens nicely cut through the richness of the pork belly.

*BEAN SPROUTS w/Garlic ($8.95) - 3.5 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pknqZiaDbSNFUnJrOpkKcw?select=Ur8Cfx0CC7_iRyoZ34eKfA
Similar in appearance to spinach, the bean sprouts had a crisper texture and a milder flavor. The slices of garlic added a nice essence but were a little bland as we requested all our dishes to be made without MSG.

S E R V I C E
Fast and inattentive which is very typical of most Chinese restaurants. They were VERY busy so you had to wave your hand in the air if you wanted something. Hakka is a place where you come for the food and the food only so don't expect good customer service.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
LOUD AND CHAOTIC! Being part Chinese even I was in a bit of a culture shock when I walked into Hakka. People were shoving each other and anxiously awaiting their table. If you're unfortunate enough to be sitting at the tables near the entrance, expect people lingering and looking over into your table. There are two levels with mostly large round tables for family dinners. 

P A R K I N G
Street parking is VERY difficult to find since Hakka is located in a residential neighborhood. Do give yourself an extra 10-15 minutes to look for parking. 

Next time, I'm coming with a village of people so we can go on a Hakka rampage!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Six of us for dinner on a Saturday night.  

Where have I been?  I never heard of this place.  But it was worth making a drive across the park.  Not the easiest 'hood to find a parking space as it's in a residential area.  But we lucked out.

The place was packed already and it wasn't even 6pm yet.   We were seated upstairs.  After playing musical tables for a few minutes, we finally settled in at a round table with a lazy Susan.

Everything was yummy.  Not a bad dish in the lot.   

Yes to the salted egg coated crab and the salted egg coated pumpkin strips.  Yes to the basil broth clams and the stir fry fish fillet.  And yes to the sticky rice in a lotus leaf, and yes to the stir fried green beans and eggplant in garlic sauce.  

We can't wait to go back with our friend who couldn't make it.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I generally get takeout, maybe once or twice a month. I've eaten here but I'd prefer takeout mainly due to the long line + grimeyness of the place. But that's all good chinese restaurants right?! Peep the line! It says a lot about the place. It pretty much shut down the place that used to be on 45th and Balboa.

Bonus points cus the boss lady knows I'm always picking up.

My go-to order for me and my family:
- salt and pepper pork chops 
- salt baked chicken (this is bomb. - like, so bomb that I'm trying to make my own version at home)
- fried pumpkin with salted egg 
- waat daan ngow yook fan (I've never been sure what this is in English but it's pretty much a slimey egg + beef over rice)
- garlic gai lan 

Pro tip:
If you're picking up takeout, walk straight to the register toward the back and push your way up to pay. Only the boss lady handles the $ so don't try to pay any ol' waiter.
author: Jessica L.

description: The quality of food keeps decreasing. It was a bookmarked restaurant for me that I always bring my friend in. But NOT ANYMORE. The customer service was bad the last time I visit there. The fish was still raw when they served us. Disappointing.
author: Nicole M.

description:
You know when you walk into a Chinese restaurant and there are Chinese people at all the tables speaking Chinese, you're in a good place.

The pork belly was indulgently delicious.  Lots of fat, but also lots of awesome.  Very good flavor, and nice tenderness.  I enjoyed the pickled / pressed vegetables as well - a lot of our dishes had this, which I learned is common in Hakka cuisine.

The salt baked chicken was probably my favorite dish.  The sauce that came with the chicken was what did it for me.

Green beans were pretty standard.  Nothing special, but not bad.

The steamed eggplant with garlic was probably my least favorite dish.  Some people that I ate with enjoyed it, but I thought the eggplant was too mushy and the flavors didn't come through well enough.

We were surprised when they charged us $1 per person for white rice.  In my book, it should come with any Chinese meal.  Oh well.  The rest of the meal was reasonably priced, though.

The service was prompt.  Not the friendliest, but Chinese waiters at Chinese restaurants always seem busy and have no time for you.  Typical.

Overall, this place had a few stand out dishes (pork belly and salt baked chicken), but the rest of the experience was average.
author: Tim C.

description:
Good sign that when we walked in, a) it was PACKED and b) we were the only white people there. 

The hosts were kind, seating us quickly despite how busy they were. We ordered a seafood plate, spicy tofu in a clay pot and sticky rice. However, they also gave us a pot of tea, a giant bowl of soup and some kind of sweet bean dish for dessert.

 (I don't know the names of anything we got! Point at pictures or numbers kind of place if you don't speak the language.)

The veggies were crisp and bright. The shrimp, fish, scallops and squid plump and sweet. The tofu crisp and spicy on the outside, and steaming on the inside. And the rice! Steamed in a lotus leaf, bursting with crazy seasonings and bits of candied pork.

You truly get the sense that they have pride in their food. And I've never been to a restaurant that was so eager to share their other dishes...for free! Oh, and epic prices! It was an under the breath 'Yessss' and fist bump when the check came.

Only 4 stars because I'm pescatarian, and they snuck pork into the rice without notice in the menu. Evan obviously loved eating the bits I picked out.
author: Lili B.

description: I order steam fish and the bandage on the fish.....I want to throw up that time. I will post picture.
author: Oscar C.

description:
Another one of the many good, but not amazing, Chinese restaurants around the city. Alice L and I showed up late with reservations one night, having let them know we were running about 30 minutes late - to which they had no complaints, surprisingly.

When we finally arrived outside, we were slightly taken aback by how quiet the area was, and semi-jokingly wondered what sketchy middle-of-nowhere restaurant we'd decided on. Stepping foot inside the restaurant though, we were surprised by how busy and bustling it actually was inside - while there were no lines, almost every table was still occupied at 830pm.

Scouring over a fairly extensive menu, we eventually decided on the pumpkin chips, fish filets with XO sauce, and clay pot oxtail. The pumpkin chips weren't bad: simple, tasty, interesting/different when served up with the salted egg, and more enjoyable with each bite; the fish filets weren't bad either, but were also not amazing; while the oxtail, unfortunately, was just okay. We were also served a tasty complimentary pork and kale soup to start, and an okay, but also complimentary, pumpkin tapioca for dessert.

The total ended up around $32 after tax, with enough leftovers to last one or two people - and this was after having stuffed two to their limits, so, the food here is certainly affordable and of good value. Perhaps not worth trekking out here for often, but if you're in the area, or craving Chinese food that's a little different, Hakka is a safe bet.
author: Johnny W.

description: A very family style and traditional Chinese restaurant. The food are tasty, the place is clean, the service is ok.  One thing I want to mention is the food portion are huge!
author: Mei Y.

description: Needed a quick lunch, ordered online via yelp. 15mins and a quick walk over and I had my Mongolian Beef over Rice. decent amount of beef / onion with plenty of rice. Flavorful and filling.
author: Mike A.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Lo Mai gai 
2.) Pumpkin strips w salted egg 
3.) Spare rib roasted garlic 

These above dishes were noteworthy good, and the other dishes were very comical in novelty to me. The whole chicken inside, what was it, a pig's stomach inside the soup?? Where the waitress had to take it out and dissect it for us right in front of us haha. 


SERVICE:
Good

ATMOSPHERE:
Small typical chinese restaurant
author: Angela L.

description:
Don't leave here without the mei cai kou rou (braised pork belly over greens) or you'll be doing yourself a disservice. While I have not had the dish very often, this is the best one I've ever had. The pork is good quality meat and tender, while the veggies underneath complement the dish well. It's no wonder it's a signature dish.

As a large group we ordered a ton of other dishes as well. Some that were particularly good were the salted fish ginger gai lan, egg yolk pumpkin and crab, beef short rib (with bell pepper), and the pork stomach. 

Facilities are pretty typical for your average large Chinese restaurant: space is pretty tight, it's loud but homey, and cleanliness isn't the best but it's manageable.
author: Tony D.

description:
Cousin came from out of town. So we decided to try something new. Hello Hakka!

Food:
We had a couple of dishes, but what I have to rave about is the braised PORK BELLY!!! Savory, fatty, tender! The fat and the meat melts in your mouth! Mixed with rice, this is a dish to die for. Sure its probably gonna take a year off my life. But this is comfort food. If youre a bacon lover, then pork belly is right down your alley. Health nuts avoid, this is grade A Chinese comfort food!

Service/Atmosphere
Above average for a Chinese restaurant. Place was clean and service was prompt but not rushed. The place was crowded on a thursday night, so you know this place is the place be.

Verdict:
Ill have to return again for the pork belly again if anything. I have not eaten such tender and savory pork belly!
author: Jason C.

description:
This is my family's new go-to spot for large dinner gatherings, and last night was my first time that I was able to make it out. I wasn't blown away by the food as everyone else raves. It wasn't my first time tasting salted egg-yolk crab/pumpkin or braised pork belly and to me, it was just normal(grew up spoiled by good food obviously.) We also had the peppercorn crab, salted egg-yolk chicken and catfish covered with shredded chicken and bell peppers to name a few dishes that stood out. 

Maybe the cook was having an off day or maybe I was grumpy, being that our group got seated by the door even though we asked if we could change tables since we had my grandmother and baby cousin and that spot by the door was colder than a witch's tit. Our hot food literally turned cold the moment it was set on our table.

I will point out that the boss lady and some servers were super nice and I'm willing to come back again since my family loves this place so much, so hopefully I just came on an off day.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Coming to Hakka Restaurant during a weekday is definitely something to consider. We came on a weekday and there was barely any wait. 

Had the pork belly and preserved vegetables as most people recommend here and it was really good. We also has the fried clams and eggplant, although they were tasty I find them abit too oily. 

We will probably come back and try other dishes.
author: Da D.

description:
Been here a few times now. The food is CONSISTENTLY good - never met a dish here I didn't like. Plus a wait at 8 o clock on a Sunday says ALOT.

I've tried a few different things here and have yet to try MORE from their menu - so extensive! So far, my fav is the salty egg pumpkin and salty egg crab. Their menu has more variety than typical Chinese restaurants, so it's a breath of fresh air.

DO IT!
author: Emily C.

description: Great place with solid, very traditional Chinese food.
author: Joshua M.

description: Worst service ever . The boss of this restaurant does not respect their customer well. Never visit here. I requested for a cold ice water for more than three time but they forgot it . There were not too much consumer around . Fine, I gave up. Then I ask if I can have my left over food to go , but they told me to finish it up. This is so rude . My family and I was so mad. This restaurant does not treat their customer well at all.
author: Jin Hua X.

description:
We ordered Braised Pork Belly , House Special Chicken, X.O. Sauce Green beans and minced pork. 

Braised Pork Belly is a must! House Special Chicken, the chicken doesn't have much meat but the green onion oil sauce was good. The Green Beans was very spicy for me. They served complementary soup first and it was very good and I felt it didn't use much MSG. Definitely a place to go back.
author: H Y.

description: Came here for family style chinese dinner two days in a row. Endless dishes to order from. I like their protein dishes more than their veggies and most of the veggie were off tasting or not my taste. I love the sticky rice stuffed chicken but my cripsy chicken skin had been ovened and was way harder than the usual. This place can get super busy but also super slow. I think place offers a few special dishes that no other chinese resturant does. The pumpkin is good, the service is good, but parking can be difficult.
author: Cindy T.

description:
A quick search will discover that Hakka cuisine concentrates on the texture of food, and its skill lies in being able to bring out the flavor of meat without hardening it. Although uncertain if this is one of Hakka restaurant's tenets, its flavor focus is certainly differentiable from typical Chinese cuisine in the city.

The Sticky Rice wrapped in lotus leaf is my personal favorite at Hakka. Despite not being inherently unique, the rice's densely packed flavor and teeming, finely-chopped fillings would be arduous to replicate at home. The giant lotus leaf may be used to seal in flavor or may be purely decorative, but definitely adds to the fun factor either way.

The Dry Black Bean Clams are infused with millions of tiny, potent fried garlic bits that somehow do not obstruct the taste of the actual clam flesh but impede any essence of the black bean from settling in. When eaten atop the stick rice, rebellious garlic will jump overboard, creating the delightfully remixed Garlic Sticky Rice. This is what some dreams are made of.

The Half Baked Chicken is surprisingly well-executed. Usually, any order of a large amount of chicken results in neglected, dry pieces, but Hakka's version is devoid of such atrocities. The chicken pales in flavor when compared to other dishes though.

The Salt and Pepper Spareribs are juicy and neatly battered, resisting the ravages of sogginess that typically sets in when the oil cools down.

This is a small sampling of Hakka's diverse menu, but as far as Chinese restaurants go, its flavors are far from boring.
author: Andrew M.

description: Only one star because of terrible service.  The food comes out cold. Missed dishes. Not only this time.  But almost every single time. Table almost close to the entrance. It is a safety issue.
author: Ed Y.

description:
Solid Hakka style Chinese restaurant. It was packed on Mother's Day but their service was pretty good despite the crowd.
I recommend the green onion tofu, it was saucy and delicious. Their spare ribs were also yummy. I also recommend their clams! It was meaty, saucy and tasty! 
The crab was disappointing, the coat on the outside tasted funky to me. Stir fried sea food noodles were also just ok, though it had a nice spicy kick to it. Green spinach was dry and not as garlicky as I would like. I was very excited to try their braised pork (aka Chinese bacon) but it had an odd gamey taste to it and I couldn't finish one slice after a small bite.
They have an upstairs and a down stairs, and we were seated up stairs. The waiters were friendly and attentive given that we were upstairs.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I'm so glad my brother's coworker recommended him to this place when we were in San Francisco or else I would not have tasted the best Hakka dishes ever. I must say that this was truly a hidden gem. It's actually the only restaurant located in a residential area. It was a small and cozy restaurant...family own and the staff was super friendly...seeing that my parents were using canes they decided not to give us a table upstairs but cleared a table that was easy for them to sit in.

So now the food...the amazing tasting and delicious food. we ordered five dishes...even though we didn't really want left overs it was hard trying to decide what to order since everything looked so good. so this is what we ordered:

Hot n sour soup - the consistency and taste of this dish was just perfect. served in a generous size bowl too.
