Lobster with salted yellow yolk - this is a MUST TRY! who ever decided to make this dish is pure genius! I really wish that any of the Chinese restaurants here would make this dish. trust me this is a Must Try!

Chinese bacon with preserved vegetables - this is their SIGNATURE dish! and I totally understand why it is - the bacon was melt in your mouth tender and well fatty too but this dish isn't for those who are afraid to eat the fat from the bacon....so brace yourself - it's not a heart healthy dish at all...actually it's artery clotting - but hey once in a while I think we can all treat ourselves to a dish like this! also a MUST TRY!

Goose gut with black bean sauce - oi this is actually a very tasty dish however the goose gut was unfortunately just a tad chewy...but that is the nature of intestines...they are usually pretty chewy. but this was still a very good dish nonetheless. 

Fukkien fried rice - now this rice dish isn't your typical fried rice - I would describe it more of steamed rice with a tasty gravy - the gravy is topped with shrimp, shiitake mushrooms and other veggies. It's pretty good but I prefer fried rice dry and not wet but as a rice dish it was very delicious. 

I have to say I would want to go to SF just to eat at this restaurant.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Quick night out after a long day of work! My gf and I was really craving Chinese food and there's not much good ones in the area. Even though there is a lot of Chinese restaurants...This one is by far the best around the area. 

Service: Great staff, very friendly. 

Setting: Moderate size to fit a few round tables. I would say about 6-8 tables all together with exception of the 4 people tables. Very chinese like restaurant like many other similar ones. They do have a lot of their food items posted on every inch of space on their wall so you can see what you get. 

Food: Delicious. I tried the slice pork, I meant sliced bomb. My gf likes veggies so we order green beans with minced pork. That was really good too. The food their is pretty traditional. They even served you with healthy soup. 

Quick Tip: If you're a couple or with two - 4 people, order fast because families come in there by the twenties and prevent you from getting food fast...

Overall: Go here if you like Chinese food with a nice setting you can relax in. 

A must try? Try? or Hell no! 

TRY IT! :)
author: Minh T.

description:
Quite busy and smaller than I expected.  Atmosphere is that of a normal chinese restaurant-- rowdy, lots of families coming for group dinners, etc.  You might be asked to split a table on a really busy day.

The food was really quite good quality and generous in portions.  I had enough food to make leftovers twice.

Mei Cia Kou Rou (Pork Belly): Really solid, would be better if the flavor went in a bit better.  Not as good as some cooking I've had before at home.

Egg Yolk Pumpkin: Didn't go for the crab, but I got the idea of what the Egg Yolk breading was like from the pumpkin.  It was tasty, but I quickly got sick of it after the 4-5 piece.

Those were the highlights of a dinner, aside from a normal veggie dish we got and a complimentary soup that was actually quite soul-warming.

It's a bit of a trek to get out here, but I think it's solid.
author: Alice S.

description:
Got the 4 person set menu that had most of the traditional Hakka dishes on there. A few standouts are the braised pork with preserved veggies (best I have had in the Bay), and the fried tofu and zucchini dish! The fried tofu had substance and didn't feel greasy or unfresh. Their salt baked chicken was pretty good! It was soft and the skin had a slight crisp to it. The dipping sauce was a bit grainy, probably due to spices. I wanted to try the fried pumpkin, but they don't have half orders and the order is huge, so maybe when I bring more people next time I will order it.

The pork stomach dish was whatever. Wasn't really a fan. The beef dish was whatever as well - the beef was marinated way too soft that it seemed very fake. The 4 person set menu was a pretty good deal, so even if one or two dishes were whatever, it was still worth it. Portions are pretty big so plenty of leftovers!
author: Annie K.

description:
Decent quality of food. 
Having the pork belly was such a pleasant enjoyment of the whole night. 
PORK BELLY is a must try if you are not afraid of fatty part of meat!! 
Steam (yellow) Chicken was good too. 
Stir fry string green bean was really good. My husband wanna lick the plate. 

Overall, flavor are nice well seasoned. Not too salty, and oily. 

Service are okay, great smiles. Sometime it's hard to see servers with great smiles on face in Chinese restaurant. 

We were seated at the second floor. Seating are not so roomy. This is fine with me. Carpet floor is clean. I hate to step onto a sticky and stinky carpet. 

It's the first restaurant I see using Corelle plates! Smart, they are durable and light... 

I will definitely come back for more good dishes.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I'm sure most people have tried Szechwan, Cantonese or Hunan Chinese food and maybe if you're adventurous, you've even tried the Xinjiang hala-style cuisine. But have you ever had Hakka Chinese food? 

I'd been dying to try it since a friend of mine told me her favorite childhood food was Hakka Salt-baked chicken. Her father had owned one of the premiere Hakka restaurants in Hong Kong, but moved before main land China took over.

We ordered up the pan fried stuffed tofu, half salt-baked chicken, egg yolk with pumpkin Dungeness  crab, spicy salt and pepper eggplant and rice.  Oh, man was it good!

The salt-baked chicken is really tasty and juicy. It's a dish where you just want to keep eating until you are sucking meat off the bones. The pan fried stuffed tofu was delicious, when you bit into the stuffed meat, a burst of salt hits your taste buds, which is enhances by the flavor of the sauce on top of it. The sauce was so tasty that I was mixing it in with my bowl of rice. The egg yoked, pumpkin crab was really good, I just wish it wasn't such a chore to get to the sweet meat of the crab. The fried eggplant was good too and I'm not normally a fan of eggplant.

All in all, it was a great dining experience, eating, drinking and being with good friends who were also trying Hakka for the first time. Prices are reasonable, service was good, get there early for dinner because as we were finishing, it was getting packed with people waiting in line to get in.
author: Jim K.

description:
A restaurant sitting on the corner in a completely residential area?!  Who would've known...

Arrived at 5:50 on Saturday and with just our luck, all tables had just been filled.  On the upside, we were the first group on the list, yippppyyy!  After about 30 minutes of gawking at the food on the table by the window, we were called in and was seated upstairs.

Although people rave about the crab and pumpkin, I didn't find it to-die-for.  In my opinion, the batter was a bit grainy, which I didn't care for.  I much prefer the typical crab in scallion and ginger sauce.  

The six of us ordered:
pumpkin and salted eggyolk-slices of pumpkin dipped in eggyolk batter then deep fried.
crab with salted eggyolk-prepared the same exact way as the pumpkin
pork belly-slow braised pork belly sittin on top of a bed of greens. This was one of the better dishes; tasty and tender as f*ck (please excuse my french).
sticky rice - Tender sticky rice wrapped in a huge leaf.  Loved it,
salt and pepper tofu and eggplant - typical chinese deep fried food sprinkled with salt and pepper.
Fish with house sauce - tender pieces of white fish in a spicy sauce.

Total bill came out to be about $80.  Not bad for 6 people, but quite expensive for 6 people eating at a Chinese restaurant.  Workers are extremely patient even though they're busy.  Hakka is worth trying at least once!
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
First, a short history lesson:  Hakka Restaurant?  What is Hakka? Well, the Hakka are a subset of Han Chinese who long ago migrated from Northern China to the mountainous regions of Guangdong and Fujian provinces, and in more recent times spread across the world to places such as Southeast Asia, India, South America, and the Caribbean.  Despite the assimilation into diaspora, they've held onto their language and culture.  Nope, didn't consult Wikipedia for this: I'm proudly half Hakka and thus super excited to -finally- have a restaurant in SF serving my peoples' food!

Brought my mom in for lunch one Saturday, and the three of us ordered the set menu for $38 along with an extra dish and a couple of substitutions, wanting to try most of the authentic Hakka dishes.  

Sparse decor, but the food is cheap with large portions- we had enough leftovers for another full meal. Service was awesome- our waiter happened to be landlord of the restaurant and was incredibly enthusiastic and also helpful with recommendations and descriptions.

Must try classics: pork belly over preserved veggies, salt-baked chicken (if getting the set dinner, can choose this for $4 more), the salted egg battered kabocha squash "fries" (next time def. trying this with crab!).

All was incredible and best of all, my mom loved it too.  Definitely brought back lots of food memories of all the good things we ate in the Hakka villages a couple years ago, and even some of the amazing food my great auntie cooks up whenever I'm in Singapore.  Even the plain old Chinese soup and pumpkin tapioca dessert were so flavorful. 

Hopefully someday they'll add to the menu my absolute favorite Hakka dish:  http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Suan_Pan_Zi.jpg

Until then, go with the fried kabocha strips.  Beware though, they're addicting!
author: Joanne G.

description: Food pretty good, cursory service. Lamb in Clay Pot with Curb Beam (tofu skin) was very tasty.
author: Deane G.

description:
This has officially been the go to restaurant for my family in the past 3 years ever since we encountered them.  The food is great and its super easy to reserve a table for a large group.  Also, the prices are very reasonable and the staff is helpful.    

Some of our favorites:

- House chicken
- Salted egg crab
- Battered pumpkin
- House special tofu
- Pork intestine with celery
- Pea shoots
- Salt and pepper pork chop
author: Vincent K.

description:
Hakka is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. Thanks to Ken K. for the suggestion!

Come by for lunch to take advantage of the 3 dishes for $19.99 Economy Lunch Special which includes soup and rice! If you ask nicely, you may even be able to score 6 dishes for $40! ;)

Picks:
- Beef Brisket Clay Pot - Always delicious, flavorful, and tender. Bring it home and the flavor is much better the next day, or the day after! :)
- Rock Cod Clay Pot - Fish quality is mediocre, but the quantity and flavor makes this clay pot a great value!
- Salt & Pepper Pork Chops - Huge portions of pork chops to try to finish while dining in!
- Broccoli w/ Wine Sauce - The wine sauce removes any bitterness that comes naturally from the Chinese broccoli.
- House Special Pan-Fried Tofu Stuffed w/ Pork - Even though I'm not a Tofu fan, this one hits the spot.
- Honey BBQ Short Ribs - Tasty, but Korean restaurants do an even better job!
- Steamed Beef w/ Chinese Sausage - This one takes a while for the dish to come out, but this is a solid dish.
- Salt & Pepper Eggplant - Tasty, but there are other options for $7! ;)
- Pineapple Spareribs - Sweet and Sour sauce was good....but there were more bones than meat.

Misses:
- Salt Baked Chicken - This one comes out too dry...
- String Beans w/ Chicken & Black Bean Sauce - The black bean sauce is too overwhelming and makes this dish too salty.

I just realized that Hakka also has sticky rice stuffed Fried Chicken...just like Yum's Bistro...now this is on my must try list! ;)

Note: Hakka recently remodeled with fresh paint and new carpet! :)
author: Derek S.

description:
I'm so glad I live in LA, where good Chinese food is plentiful.  SF just can't compare.

I had high hopes for Hakka Restaurant but the pork belly/Chinese bacon dish fell flat. I've had better versions of this dish at quite a few places in the SGV with more meat, better veggies, and costs less $.

We also ordered the House Special Tofu dish with Stuffed Pork. For a tofu lover like me, this was heaven.  So good and so much better than the pork belly dish.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Great for a stop after visiting the park!

After walking around Golden Gate Park for several hours, we were looking to grab a late lunch rather quickly. Found this gem and were really thrilled!

Came in for a late lunch around 2, so it was pretty dead. We haven't visited too many authentic Chinese restaurants, but we weren't looked down on for having a few questions.

Great Cantonese Chinese food, and really fairly priced for lunch (~ $8-9/plate). Big portion sizes meant we were able to order 3 dishes and share between 5 people. The service was great and the food came out quickly. We loved it and will definitely be back next time we're in the area!!
author: Jarrod F.

description:
I came here for an early Sunday dinner with my family to avoid the wait. We arrived at 5:40pm and was seated immediately, which is surprising since the restaurant fills up pretty quickly. Anyways let's talk about the food. 
     We started off with a complimentary soup of potato and chicken. It was subpar- typical soup you would expect from an Asian restaurant. 
      Fungus sautéed vegetables- Omgawd I cannot express how much I live this dish! Def. absolute fave! The dish was colorful and crisp and it was really refreshing. I know a lot of people might not be used to the black fungus, but it honestly just absorbs the flavor of the dish and offer a nice crunch. In fact, it's my fave part of the dish. The veggies were also really fresh and crisp. 
       Spicy ground pork with string beans- This dish was actually something we never ordered before and it was pleasantly surprising. We all fell in love with it instantly! The ground pork was stir fried with diced jalapeños and fermented veggies and the strings beans were fried to crisp perfection. It was spicy, salty, and crunchy and meaty all at once. 
        Yellow skin chicken- This is a cold dish and it's half of a chicken served with a side of ginger and scallion dipping sauce. Typically, when we order this dish at other restaurants the chicken is dry and disgusting. However, here the chicken is tender and very flavorful. 
        House special pan fried tofu- This dish was also something we never ordered before but we decided to try it out anyway. First off, this dish was a complete disappointment. It lacked color, texture, and flavor! Hell, it didn't even look appetizing! The tofu was bland and there was barely and meat stuffing inside. The sauce that it was smothered in had no flavor besides saltiness. Def. would not order this again!
        Sweet and sour spareribs- This dish was presently beautifully. The chunks of fried spareribs was slathered in a bright red sauce and the bell peppers and pickled radish added a nice zing. It was delicious however, there was barely any meat on it since the chunks were mostly bones! I think next time we'll stick to the regular sweet and sour pork. Nonetheless, my sister killed the whole plate since she's obsessed with anything sweet and sour. 
        Eggyolk crusted fried pumpkin- This is def. the staple dish that we order every single time. It would be a crime if you didn't!!! It honestly looks like a plate of gold and it smells and tastes like heaven! Thick slices of Korean pumpkin is fried and encrusted in salted egg yolk. It comes out piping hot, but that doesn't stop us from devouring it!! Once you bite through the crunchy salty exterior, you are then greeted with a warm sweet velvety interior. 
       The "dessert" or orange slices are to avoided at all cost!! They're black and dry and absolutely disgusting! I'm not even sure if they're edible! We just left them at the table!
author: Celina C.

description:
Loooove Hakka. Went back last night =) 

This is more of a note for myself but...

My dear Yelp friend just told me to go for lunch next time for their 3 dishes for $19.99 deal! OMG! Love her for telling me that! I like Hakka, so I will definitely check it out for lunch. She also said that if you ask nicely you can do 6 dishes for $40...that is so awesome!! 

We ordered 3 dishes last night and it came out to $36...still pretty cheap in my opinion. But 6 dishes for $40 is karaaazay good.

The service is really great for a busy Chinese restaurant too. Our waiter last night was very nice! Even though there was a wait, we were seated within 10 minutes. He also told us that they give free desserts during the week but not on the weekends bc it's so busy. FYI.
author: Natalia H.

description:
had the family 3 dish for take out - online snapshots of the take out menu say 19.95 but prices have changed!! 

got the green beans and ground pork - super awesome. loved the spice and the oily-ness. true asian. tofu with fish fillet was "healthier", enjoyed that, as well; though i can see if someone would say it may be too bland for their taste. i happened to really liked the tofu in that dish. my friend got a chicken lettuce wrap entree and really liked it, though i didn't try it.

btw, don't try and walk down that hill and walk back up after dinner -- its a doozie.
author: Vicki T.

description:
This place is like a hidden gem that all the real Chinese food enthusiasts know about because they are always packed!  Make sure to get reservations if you have a huge party...and parking in the outer Richmond is no joke...so be warned.

Must try their salted egg yolk crab.  Everything in their menu is superb and we usually got with  fairly huge party so we can order more variety entrees to share.  This place is one of my go too Chinese, good eats, with fair prices.
author: Patrick C.

description:
The pictures on the wall helped a lot for what we were ordering. I recommend getting the clams with salt and black bean sauce. I have never had a dish made this way with clams. 

The salt baked chicken was ok. It took too long to come out all the other food came out fairly fast and it was about 10-15 minutes after we got all our food. I don't recommend ordering this if you are in a hurry. 

Our table ordered the braised pork belly which they said was very tender and good. A little on the sweet side. 

The service was just ok. We had a large group and we asked for water all around and we got 4. Had to ask again so they can bring more. Which had no ice in it so we had to ask for ice. 

I'd come back here just for the clams. The prices of the food are also a reason I would come back.

it got busy by the time we left. Probably good to make a reservation if you have a large group as it is on the tiny side.
author: Christina Z.

description:
my girlfriend tells me that we're given the white people menu when she goes there with me, but you know what? I don't care because it's SOOOooooo GOooooood. Here is my recommendation for comfort food (I didn't say health food) for your first time there: 
1. the pumpkin in salted egg
2. seafood chowmein with thick noodle
3. salt and pepper pork chops
Then try anything you want, everything I've had there is yumm-O.
author: Susanne A.

description:
The food here is great.  It is  worth the trip to the outer Richmond.
Not the usual greasy Chinese crap.
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Came here with the boyfriend and his family and overall it's not a bad place. I was sick during the visit so it may have thrown of my taste buds, but everything was average that day.

My favorite was the salted egg fried pumpkin dish. I only had 1 piece to save my sore throat but it was pretty good and i wish I was able to eat more.

House chicken -Pretty good, very flavorful

Sticky rice in lotus leaf - Pretty good, one of my favorite dishes the whole night

Fatty pork belly - Very fatty indeed. It was too salty to much liking, but everyone else seemed to enjoy it a lot

Pan fried steamed tofu - Had a piece of meat in the center and I quite enjoyed it. Also another favorite of the night

Fried clams - Way too fried and way too salty. Did not like this at all. It has bits and piece of minced meat in it and the boyfriend enjoyed it a lot though ( I think this was his favorite dish)

I think we had a few more dishes, but this is all I recollect right now. Overall, not a bad place for dinner, and it won't break your bank too much.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Hakka is in the middle of nowhere residential neighborhood way at the end of the Outer Richmond. There's almost no other shops or restaurants around (it's on Cabrillo for crying out loud!). It's practically in the ocean. Yet, as you draw close, you start hearing the muffled chatter and forceful intonations of impatient Chinese people. As you draw even closer, you see a crowd around the entrance to this place, peering in through windows, pouring out through the door. Aggressive gaggles of Asian grandmas and their families fighting for the attention of the servers, hovering over seated guests hoping to get a table sooner.

This is how you know this place is good.

We had been recommended this place and so expected it to be decent. But MAN, this place blew away all my expectations. So, I normally don't ever choose to eat at Chinese restaurants. It's not snobbery, it's not cultural trauma. It's simply that I don't really like the cuisine as much as others. Sauces tend to be too heavy, things all start to taste the same.

But this place! I can really get behind this place. Every dish we ordered was spot-on delicious, and not the usual dishes you can find everywhere else. The pumpkin with salted egg is ridiculous, the texture firm, but slightly cakey, the flavors rich and not too overpowering. The Chinese bacon is stellar as well, not too greasy and the perfect blend of salty and sweet. I would also recommend the clay pot ox tail and leaf-wrapped sticky rice! Each dish's flavor was unique, and pair really well with rice. The highlight of the night, though, was definitely the fried crab with salted egg. Absolutely amazing!!! The salted egg almost gives the crab a cheesy richness and the lightly crispy fried exterior just took it to the next level. Unreal.

Definitely call ahead so you don't get caught up in the mob of hungry people outside. It'll still take a little courage to worm your way through to actually check in, but it's worth it. Service is brusque and efficient, prices are very reasonable, and dishes come out as they're ready. Great place for big groups, and I strongly recommend going with a lot of people so you can order ALL the things!
author: Carol C.

description:
Horrible place!
Don't get fooled by the yelp review. I am Hakka and have been growing up eating "Hakka" dishes and this place is no where near that.  The famous braised pork belly is WAY too sweet.  The portion is good but the flavor is not. Service is not very good and it's not clean. I will not recommend this place at all.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Filled with Chinese families, Hakka Restaurant looks like your typical large Chinese restaurant with tables large enough for banquets. The menu has Hakka specialty dishes you don't see everywhere like the stuffed chicken with sticky rice, pumpkin strips with salted egg, and Chinese bacon. The glossy pictures of their specialty dishes on the walls look appetizing.

The meal started with a complimentary light broth with wintermelon...a nice start.

* Salt baked chicken ($11.95 for half): considered a house specialty, the chicken was chopped up and had a crispy skin, the dipping sauce didn't have much flavor (just seemed like oil), expensive and plain
* Lamb clay pot with "bain curb" (the way it's spelled on the menu): enjoyed the savory gravy, the slight sweetness of the sauce, the five spice flavor. The claypot came with soft bean curd skins, water chestnuts and lamb. The lamb was quite fatty; it was in big pieces with skin and bone left, and a thick layer of fat
* Pork with mixed mushrooms and zucchini http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6_2cxfjG_R1rBqmgOn35CQ/l.jpg: didn't taste bad but it was extremely oily and glossy looking, wouldn't order again

The meal ended with complimentary warm pumpkin soup with tapioca pearls. I liked the complimentary soups but the oiliness of the stir-fried pork dish was excessive.
author: Lolia S.

description: ordered out again trying to see if they'd make improvements, ordered the broccoli beef, good thing is the give you 2 veggies , think that the trend. broc & bok choy, meat was a bit tough with too much gristle. 2nd was the steamed porkcake with chinese sausage. Pork was nasty, I can see how it was made, chop up all the garbage pieces or remnants of pork, mix in seasoning & steam, again full of pork fat & gristle, i went to fork cut a piece of it & I can see strings of gristle. Chinese sausage are paper thin, tiring to show alot of it. sweet & sour pork was also a poor grade of meat, covered in batter & hidden in sauce.
author: david c.

description: One of those hole in the wall Chinese restaurants in San Francisco with very good food. Came here with my family for dinner and ordered the chicken lettuce wrap, pork belly over mustard, salt and pepper crab, string beans in x.o. sauce, and a stuffed chicken sticky rice. I would have to say the food is very good. The service here is pretty good with our server being very attentive at getting our food to us fast. This is one of the restaurants in the middle of nowhere by all houses. Would come back soon to try the other items on their menu.
author: Peter C.

description: Horrible service and even worse food. It took them an hour to make the food and the food was some of the worst Chinese food I've ever had
author: Eric P.

description:
From now on

Thy shalt be forbidden to use the word "HELLA" in everyday NorCal speech. 

When referring to seriously asskicking rustic regional Cantonese goodness from this restaurant, you are to use the noun adjective "HAKKA" instead.

Examples:

 "Their authentic salt baked chicken is HAKKA good!"

" Dat phat piece of pickled veg pork belly badonkadonk is HAKKA fine!"

" That deep fried salted egg yolk kabocha is HAKKA dope a$$, the non Chinese will HAKKA love it. Tell em its Hakka Fries!"

"They have herbal stewed soft shell turtle soup here for $58? Dat's sum HAKKA scary chit mon!"

You get my drift. I am however, not kidding about that soft shell turtle soup. It's on the menu (in Chinese only, not translated). 

Check Yelp pics...looks like pic voting shifts the links around :-o

1. Whole chicken stuffed into a pork stomach and stewed as a soup.

http://samfrancisco.me/2011/01/31365-good-bye-tiger-hello-rabbit/

Food poetry...to symbolize a phoenix reborn and rising from the ashes...

2 days advanced pre-order (likely as with the others) - $48

Also supposed to be an old school remedy.

2. Soft shell turtle stewed with Chinese herbs - $58 (supposed to be very good for you...)

3. Stewed fish head with Chinese herbs - $38

4. Stewed whole chicken with ham and veg - $45

Real a$$ kung food indeed. Mad RE$PECT for chef Li Jin Hua. A fockin Hakka Canto Chinese food genius.

But if that's too rich for your blood, might I recommend the following from the new and improved menu with pictures and names in English, assuming you are ready to graduate from pan fried stuffed tofu with magic sauce, Hakka Fries, salted baked chicken, basil chili clams.

Again, Yelp pic links shifted due to voting, just check em :-)

- House Pan Fried Vermicelli (L1 - $6.95) - stir fried rice noodles, village style. Asian Pearl dim sum should be ashamed of charging so much for a lesser rendition. This stuff is killer.

- Not Hakkanese but good ol' fashion Cantonese claypots. Braised fish (rock cod?) fillet/belly with tofu and a rustic lamb brisket claypot that will surely be wonderful during cold nights.

- Those feeling seafood adventurous might want to try "frog fried with salted egg yolk" or "stewed bitter melon with catfish claypot"

- Squab/pigeon lovers who want to experiment beyond the deep fried salted version could try the stewed one in claypot (with dried orange peel and ginger flavors)

-Love innards and pork stomach? Going back to your poor roots? This one might be for you, pork stomach with salted preserved vegetables.

There's a rendition that's spicy with XO sauce too.

Love sweet and sour pork but always ate the bullshit version? They have that here too, but probably done in a much better scale and more authentic Cantonese. But you might do better getting the sweet and sour spareribs, more authentic Cantonese version, known as "sahng tsau gwut", which they execute beautifully here (aka pineapple spareribs", less fattening than the SSP. Ordering this with some beers will give you that Hong Kong dai pai dong feel...

The best dish of my evening?

Home style steamed sea bass, a 1.5 pound black bass that was a bit under $30. It looks Hakka Fugly if you know what I mean, but it tastes like heaven. "Ga Heung Seung Mei Dzing Mahng Tsoe" or Countryside home double flavor steamed black bass....the double flavor is the pickled sweet veg and black bean sauce (dau see). The fish is pan fried first, then steamed. Then garnished with magic sauce and cilantro. It was one of the phattiest black basses I've had in a while. Sweet, a hint of sour, and good fish flavor and texture. Despite being pan fried initially then steamed, this was one of the best preps I've had in a long time. Asian Pearl's "country style auntie's steamed fish" is no match against this one. A very appetizing, almost transporting back to the old dayz when life was poorer and simpler.

Complementary house slow fire soup (2nd visit yet again was the delectable lotus root with pork bones) with the final encore of the performance being the pumpkin dessert soup (likely made with kabocha/Asian pumpkin), but w/o sago. I know what I want for Thanksgiving instead.

A complete symphony of a meal, no pretense, no bullshit. Come here if you like old fashioned hardcore authentic cooking that's not upscale but extremely delicious and takes you back to simpler times. If you are fooled by the likes of Michelin Hong Kong and need your ego pampered, massaged, and catered to just so you can say you are a true gourmet, then please stay away from this place. Thanks!
author: Ken K.

description: The salt-and-pepper spare ribs with string beans is amazing. Not sure if it's because of all the fried garlic this melded into the dish or something secret inside the breaking, but the dish is awesome.
author: Abe L.

description: We were craving seafood, specifically asian seafood, and we were not disappointed by this random Yelp search find. We came on a sunday evening, and it was pretty packed with asian families enjoying family dinner, but luckily we did not wait long for a table. We had chili crab, chinese broccoli, and half a "yellow-skin" chicken (wong mo gay) with a ginger scallion dipping sauce. The crab was market price of $45, a bit pricey, but it was a whole crab and we all got our fill. The crab was also wok fried with bits of chilies, scallions, and ground pork for extra flavor. Dinner also includes a house soup, which was lotus and carrots, and very much like my mom's! This is a great little place in the middle of the neighborhood, which means it's also kind of hard to find parking.
author: Rita L.

description: Good spot for the out of the area place to grab some food. I have only gone for the lunch time meal and so far my 5 trips to this spot is right on. Enjoyed every dish so far and portions are just right from the lunch menu. The quality is quiet well considering the other Chinese restaurants not to far from here. Not greasy, not to salty and the sauces are not the "over saturated with salt " kind. This food won't get you all sleepy after a meal like typical Chinese food restaurants do due to the amount of MSGs that the other places have. My suggestion is the 3 plate lunch special at 24.99. Considering it started at 21.99 4 months ago but then again, in SF the wages went up and so the prices at home restaurants like this one had to hike up the prices a bit. No problem, keep the food good and I'll keep coming...service is average, great serving of warm soup before your dish comes out is a nice treat. It does get a bit busy during the lunch hour and parking is sometimes a drag since its smack in the middle of a residential neighborhood. But all in all a good spot to take a affordable and filling lunch, without feeing the after lunch "hangover".
author: Jaime P.

description:
I was excited to try this place out, but honestly, it was kind of disappointing. The food was decent (we had salted egg friend pumpkin strips, chinese bacon with greens, chinese broccoli in rice wine sauce, house stuffed tofu, and sticky rice in lotus leaf), but not spectacular. The pumpkin and some of the other dishes were pretty salty, and the waitress was extremely stingy with the beverages--having run out of tea and asked twice for water, she finally brought one glass for the person who requested it. I'm used to brusque service at Chinese restaurants, but it felt a little extreme in this case. 

I probably would not go back.
author: Kristina B.

description:
How exciting to find a Hakka restaurant in the city!  The food is tasty - especially the pumpkin breaded in egg yolk, and the pork belly with preserved vegetables.  It's definitely worth a try if you're looking for a different flavor of Chinese cuisine.  

It's a little more expensive than your average Chinese restaurant, however this type of restaurant is hard to come by.  Next time I'm determined to try one of my favorite dishes, the Chicken stuffed with sticky rice (Naw Mee Gai), which needs to be ordered a day in advance.
author: Allegra H.

description:
Had a very nice lunch.  I was a little worried that the service was not going to be very good, but after an initial period of inattentive service that changed to very efficient and polite service.

Really enjoyed the noodles.  Next time I will have to try the pork belly as it has such rave reviews.
author: Bradley C.

description:
How is it that I hadn't written a review yet for this?? 

I have NOTHING but GOOD things to say about this place!!!

The owner/manager who occasionally stops by and sometimes works there, Danny, is extremely friendly and honest and he sure does know how to make you feel relaxed while ordering. He's so very knowledgeable about what to order. We've been coming in here for a few years now and always order some of the same dishes on a regular basis. Here's what we've tried, including our favorites:

-The strings beans in XO sauce, to DIE for, especially the Chinese pickle and minced pork. It's full of flavor and my #1 favorite wont go here without ordering dish!

-The stuffed tofu dish which is popular

-The Fish and tofu clay pot, again, very good!

-The Pumpkin strips-their fried in egg and would be a favorite also if they weren't overly salty tasting. Otherwise, try asking for it without the salty layer.

-The soup of the day which is always free is also very good-my favorite being the winter melon.

-The chicken and salty fish fried rice-another favorite that we like to order along with the Strings beans.

-The mussels with the black bean sauce are delicious and steamed just right. 

-Last but not least, they always serve you free dessert after your meal, usually it's a hot dessert such as red bean with tapioka soup, pumpkin tapioka or my favorite the taro with tapioka. I always get seconds and sometimes the Raymond sends an extra container home with me.

-The service is excellent thanks to my two favorite servers there, Danny and Raymond! You guys are the BEST!!! :)

But whatever you do and especially if you're out here in the outskirts of the city, you MUST try this place.
author: Petra S.

description: This piace it's great! When I order take out its ready in 10 minutes and they very friendly.
author: Ignazio L.

description:
Make reservations or go in very early. This place gets crowded.  Don't think that because it is the middle of nowhere (which it is) that it is going to be slow.  

Most of the dishes are rather tasty...although sometimes it is more on the saltier side, which works well with rice.  I like their preserved greens & pork belly.. probably because not many places serve this dish.  The salty egg yolk with crab is also very good.  I also like their mixed mushroom & beef dish.  

Service here is pretty good..at least decent for a Chinese restaurant.

============

Review #151
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Though I'm often in this area, I don't eat here often because its usually crowded around dinner time. 

My favorite dishes here are the Chef Special Tofu, Salted Yolk Pumpkin, and the Black Pepper Beef. The cost is a bit more than what one usually expects from Chinese food but its also better in quality compared to other restaurants, not to mention better taste. 

Most dishes range from about $10-13, and obviously specialty dishes cost more.
author: Connie C.

description:
This restaurant is way the heck out there, but dang was it good.

We ordered family style and thus got to try a lot of different dishes. My favorite was probably the hot pot with braised tofu and fish fillet. The restaurant was pretty basic in design, but it had a decent amount of seating and large tables. The bathrooms were clean, which is a MAJOR plus in my opinion. The free soup of beef broth with meat and veggies was surprisingly delicious.

Six of us ate for about $14 a head.

Not bad if you ask me, especially with the limited options in this area.
author: Audrey J.

description:
After reading the reviews from others, I chose this place (and also as R&G Lounge had been booked on a WEDS evening for a private party!).  Most of our party of 9 were late, though I had booked reservations ahead of time (thank goodness - and best if you make the reservation in Mandarin, but they do speak English, too)!  They gave us a HUGE table!  

While we waited, I perused the menu for the dishes mentioned in the reviews, and pretty much wrote down the "Coordinate Values" and the names (which later helped quite a bit, as the staff was SO busy - on a WEDS night! - and I was able to give the paper with the codes of each dish, making our order highly easy to make!  

We started with the egg yolk pumpkin strips - weirdly delicious!  My 11-year-old daughter said the outside reminded her of Cheetos.  Whatever.  They were a perfect appetizer as the rest of our group came inside.  

We ordered the Braised Pork Belly, Claypot fish and tofu, Bean sprouts and Garlic, Hong Kong style steak with green and red peppers, Lotus Wrapped Sticky Rice (one of the LARGEST I've ever seen!), Beef Stew Claypot (wonderfully tender beef and tendons!), Hong Kong style Crab (luscious and meaty!), Squid and Chicken with celery, Egg vermicelli, and one more dish that I cannot know remember, but nothing was bad, so it must have been good!  The surprise was the large soup tureen of beef broth filled with large pieces of beef, tendons, carrots, but mostly broth that was simple and delicious, not salty.  

Orange slices topped off our customized Chinese New Year dinner!  We slowly removed ourselves from the restaurant, carrying bags of our minor amounts of leftovers stored in clear plastic covered containers.   

The best surprise was how inexpensive this feast came out to be!  We averaged $17 / person for a 14-course dinner!

What also surprised me was how busy the restaurant was on a mid-week evening!  Parking is street only, and it's easy to find - corner with a bright yellow awning.  Several large tables that can seat up to 14 people each are available, giving the impression that crowds may be the norm for them.  

The wait staff and hostess were pleasant though running everywhere.  When it calmed down a bit, we were able to chat with them, and that was pleasant in itself!  

I can hardly wait to return again!  WITH a crowd next time!
author: jeannie l.

description:
The food here is solid. As in, it's hella good! We ordered:

- Braised pork belly
- Honey BBQ beef short ribs
- Lotus leaf sticky rice
- Spare ribs
- Cat fish clay pot

Everything was so delicious. I wasn't too impressed with the clay pot but it's not bad. I must say, the spare ribs came with these string beans and the string beans were out of this world! What? Did this girl just rave about string beans? I have to! They were fresh and crunchy. Not at all shriveled up and ... um, stringy. 

I think my top dishes are the pork belly (melt in your mouth goodness), honey BBQ short ribs, and lotus leaf sticky rice. 

The wait was super long because there are no set list; even though they gave us a number. The service was okay but it was very typical of a place like this. I will definitely come back again but will make reservation. I think it's quite of a drive to the outer Richmond for Chinese food but it's worth it.
author: LeTran B.

description:
Quick, fast, simple, delicious. 

Despite the not so presentable restaurant like any other chinese restaurant in the city, I'd come here on anyday to enjoy a good hakka style meal. Only on weekdays are there lunch specials. Regardless, I still always order from the regular menu on top of the lunch specials. There is always something different that I try that is almost always good. The preparation and flavoring are always great. Additionally, if you're in a hurry, this place is a great place for quick and easy meal. The food comes out hot, fresh, and fast.
author: Carolyn L.

description:
All salty egg yolk everything! Err frog legs and kabocha... it's awesome, don't be scared, get it. be happy.

The pork belly, rice wrapped in lotus leaf, and tofu with pork also stood out as being particularly good. Great place to eat with a group but get reservations cause their can be quite the wait.
author: Misha T.

description:
I'll come back!  The popular braised pork belly is their show dish.  Most items on the menu is tasty, this type of food quality is hard to find nowadays in restaurants. The best thing is they are still able to keep the pricing afforadable.  

There have lots of big tables, towards the back stairway and up the stairs you'll find the 2nd floor with smaller tables.  Although its split level, they do not lack in service.  Come early as the restaurant tends to fill up by 6:30pm.
author: Ju D.

description:
Very disappointing meal!
Only good item we ordered: garlic-sautéed pea sprouts
author: ColomboArgentino C.

description:
We were in the neighborhood, looking for a nice place to quickly grab a bite to eat. As this restaurant has mustered good reviews, we decided to give it a shot. Parking is a pain in the neck; we hunted high and low for a parking space for 10min, but in vain. So, I asked my husband to park in a corner with emergency lights on, so that I could buy to-go food for us. 

The menu had several food options which beguiled me into thinking that this is one awesome restaurant. I ordered the salt and pepper tofu/eggplant, short ribs and rice. Our boxes were ready in 15minutes and the food looked so yummy that I could not wait to treat my taste buds with it.

We drove to the Lands End, parked the car facing the beach and eagerly opened the boxes. The salty tofu/eggplant was good, nothing exceptional. Likewise, the short ribs was commonplace. It was bland. I guess we have had tastier food in other places that we really didn't relish this food.

San Francisco has so many good restaurants; so the food has got to be really good to motivate one to return to the same place. We certainly do not intend to eat from here again.
author: Anu M.

description:
There isn't much more i can say that hasn't been said about this place. the food is as good as what others are saying. The only thing i didn't see mentioned and i have to add is there is a special they have that has to be ordered 24 hours in advance. i myself haven't tasted this dish yet but i need to do that after trying this place.

  the special that was described to me by a friend is they de bone the chicken and stuff it with chicken fried rice and fry the whole chicken. i am looking forward to trying this dish out among the other delicious stuff they had.
author: John T.

description:
Good Chinese food and inexpensive. Gets busy so make a reservation unless you go before 6pm. Service is actually a little better than most Chinese restaurants. Yes, you do have to wave someone down to get something because they are a busy restaurant, but when they do things, they do it with a smile and correctly. I also liked how the server packed our food and labeled them on the top of the box in Chinese. I believe they use MSG because I was very thirsty after my meal. 

We ordered the 6 person dinner meal instead of choosing a la carte.

- Seafood Soup: good, nice chunks of seafood (fish maw, shrimp, etc), add pepper to make it taste even better
- Braised Pork Belly: pretty good, tender and cooked perfectly
- Steamed Crab: OK nothing special
- Black Bean Catfish: too salty and saucy, fish was OK otherwise
- Abalone Mushroom Greens: good, greens maintained crunch and mushrooms soft
- Salt & Pepper Fried Spareribs: really fried, not bad
author: Linda C.

description:
For the waiter: poor service, no greeting, no smiling, rude.

For the waitress: not bad.

Total: one star only, will not come back.
author: Tianchen L.

description:
Amazing place, very welcoming and authentic. Don't be fooled by the residential neighborhood, that just means it's a staple in this community. 

Enjoy!
author: Sam A.

description:
This place is awesome! 

My boyfriend and I always pass by this place when we go on our evening runs and it's always filled with people. With all the great reviews, we decided to try this place out - and we're glad we did! 

We ordered the sauteed fungus with vegetables and salt and pepper spare ribs. Our order also came with soup and ended with dessert (che in Vietnamese). We had to take our food to-go because we were so stuffed. The entire meal with a nice tip was only $25. 

They have some interesting dishes that we'll be back to try. The chicken and squid dish sounded interesting, but I wasn't brave enough then. Next time for sure!
author: Mimi V.

description: Very good service, price and quality. You should definitely check this place out when you are hungry! It's hard to find a good place like this place near the beach !
author: SynCity P.

description:
Not great, but better than what we get in the EBay, where the Chinese food is pathetic and getting worse all the time (sigh).
 
It's a lot easier if you can order in Cantonese. The menu has lots of photos, but the organization is all over the place. 

- Braised fish and tofu claypot: the best of the bunch. Very fresh, nicely fried tofu soaks up a great gravy with big chunks of saltwater white-fleshed fish fillet. 5-star dish!

- Catfish and bitter melon claypot: I don't like either one, but everybody else did. Catfish is just chunked up, complete with bones, BTW

- Chinese broccoli (gai lan) with garlic: Perfect

- Deep-fried spareribs: an indifferent version, but the green beans with them were superb. 

- Minced pork with dried scallop: I liked this as it's less salty than the usual version, but most Chinese are used to this being very salty (the traditional "one spoonful with a whole bowl of rice").

Overall, it might have ranked higher with us if we'd been able to order the crab and salt-baked chicken, but the relatives were paying and they didn't want the crab, and the chicken was going to take another hour before being ready to serve.
author: Jean K.

description: Yum yum yum! Salted egg crab & lobster, salt baked chicken, Chinese bacon with preserved vegetables, and prawns with maggi ? Yes to all! However, similar to all other chinese restaurants, be prepared to drink lots of water after the meal because they are really generous with their salt. If you are looking for a truly authentic chinese restaurant, this is the place! Be prepared to wait though, the place is rather small and only seats a few tables.
author: Jingi A.

description: This place is like a hole in the wall restaurant in the middle of no where hiding in the residential area. The place is kind of small but the food is delicious. Went on a busy Sunday night but our food came out quick. Be prepared for a long wait if you don't do reservations.
author: Anne H.

description:
So nice to meet you, my go-to for Chinese take out! Delicious food in delicious sauce in large portions. So delicious. Definitely worth the trek for some family style feasting.

They have THE BEST:
Combination seafood and tofu claypot
String bean with minced pork in XO sauce

SO VERY GOOD:
House special eggplant

VERY GOOD:
House special pan fried vermicelli
Mongolian beef
Chicken congee
author: Jennifer L.

description: The salted egg fried pumpkin strips were excellent. I've never had anything like them before. Kinda like sweet potato fries except even better. Unfortunately I couldn't try anything else because one order of the pumpkin was enough for two lunches and I didn't have enough stomach room to order more. I recommend coming here with a big group so you can order a lot of the dishes. I'll have to come back.
author: Jean K.

description:
Found Hakka on Yelp today when I was searching for a new place to try near the Cliff House.  Thanks for the map view, Yelp!

The reviews made me want to try it, and the mid-day Tuesday timing made me confident the dreadful waits would be easy to avoid.  The place is more than half banquet tables, which meant that the two of us got one.

We only had two dishes, Short Ribs in Black Pepper and Honey Sauce, and Chicken Fried Rice.  The ribs were sublime... maybe the best new dish I've had in years.  I would go back just for that.  The fried rice was fine... there's only so much you can do with that.  But there was a lot of it.

I'm very pleased to find such an authentic restaurant in a location I'll end up close to plenty of times in the future.  And despite the authenticity, the bathroom was really clean.
author: G M.

description: We were here on Friday night and it's packed. We had the pineapple spareribs, braised fish fillet and tofu in clay pot and salt baked chicken. All the dishes were delicious. The spareribs were tender, the tofu was really silky. I would love to try more dishes next time. Definitely a great place for family dinner and price was reasonable compare to some Chinese restaurants on Geary.
author: bebe L.

description:
Food - Very flavorful and salty.  I am normally the last one to complain about saltiness, But I drank 2 glasses of water during dinner and a full 16 oz bottle before bed.  Overall, good food!

Service - for a Monday, it's ok. They have a full house and it took 10 minutes to get the server attention and take our order.  Then they took our hot tea for refill and we have to asked 2 times and got it back when they bring us the check.  

Must try: Lotus Leaf sticky rice, Sauté pork stomach with XO sauce.
author: JC C.

description: Had a great dinner here with some friends. In terms of ambiance, definitely a typical Chinese restaurant -- crowded, loud, and not particularly fancy or nice -- but the food was tasty and comforting, and hit the spot. My favorite dishes were the crispy chicken stuffed with sticky rice and beef short ribs. I also liked the minced port lettuce wraps, "Chinese bacon"/pork belly dish, and the crab with egg batter, which was tasty but there was a bit of a difficulty-in-eating issue that I always have with seafood at Chinese restaurants. Overall a great meal for a chilly SF evening.
author: Shing H.

description: Got here an hour before closing. They were out of chicken and pea sprouts. Foodlooks good, a bit greasy, but  tasty
author: SmokeyB B.

description:
For context, I've logged back into my Yelp account for the first time in 3 years for this restaurant just so I remember it's name in the future. .

Listen, if you want decor, beautiful lighting, and fancy presentation then Hakka is not your place.

However, if you are stuck out in the outer Richmond and freezing, and you're hungry for Chinese then Hakka is where you need to be. Cheap, delicious, and good service. You really can't ask for more.

Get the glazed pork belly. They call it something different on their English menu, but they'll know what you're talking about.
author: Alexander H.

description: Chinese food will be chinese food. The one dish I would recommend is the braised pork belly (~$13). It's one of Hakka's most popular dishes for a reason, right? Right. When the dish comes to the table, it automatically becomes the star of the night. It glistens under the restaurant's lights, tempting everyone's tastebuds. Be careful to pick up the meat because it's delicate. But wait, admire the braised pork belly for a second. Appreciate the perfect ratio of fat to meat and how it is perfectly cooked and simmered in a delectable thick sauce. Take one bite at a time and notice how tender the meat is. Mmm mmm good.
author: Annie S.

description:
4 stars for the grub. 5 stars for overall experience.

Had a grand ole' time here last night. After a good 45 minute wait we were seated (2 of us).

Here's how the ordering began:

Me: The house special tofu, is it stuffed with meat?
Waiter: Meat on top, with some anchovies
Me: Ahh, is it good?
Waiter: Um, no. Not good. No.
Me: ...
Waiter: ...
Me: I used to live in Asia. I like Asian food.
Waiter: Oh! Yeah, it's really good!

Ha!

Salted egg yolk pumpkin strips were incredible. We also ordered the pork belly, strings beans with XO sauce and a snail dish that wasn't on the menu but we saw lots of tables ordering. Everything was solid solid solid plus. Place was jumping...for good reason.

Danny (a part time server who helps out occasionally) is the man! He chatted with us for a while about all the dishes and I would have mistaken his exuberance for sarcasm if we weren't in the cuuuuuuuts of outer richmond! A great time out.

5 dishes. 3 beers. $60 before tip.
author: Anthony R.

description: I have been here a number of times and it never disappoints! This is one of the rare find that I don't care about etiquette and eat like a beast. Literally every single dish is delicious and a friend of mine has made it a mission to come back to try every one of them on the menu.
author: Zhao L.

description:
Hakka is definitely not your typical Chinese restaurant. most of their menu does feature the typical American Chinese dishes but the chefs specials are quite different.  I got the pumpkin fries, pork belly with preserved vegetables, clams with spicy salt and black beans, and lotus bulb with black fungus and greens. 

the pumpkin fries were really good but after the third one, it started to taste really heavy. the soup (free?) was good. it was winter melon with white beans and chicken feet. I dug it because it tastes like something mom would make. the pork belly was gluttonous!!! Its absolutely not a dieter's food because all that pork fat goodness just melts in your mouth and you just want to reach for more. the clams were okay, a little tough and way salty and not spicy. the lotus bulbs and veggies was the lightest and "healthiest" dish we had but it glistened in oil. :) the dessert was white fungus with papaya. perfect!

it was a decent meal but for someone who isn't used to eating greasy and salty foods, Hakka is definitely a shock to your system. I felt like I was having a mini heart attack on the way home and all that food just sat in my tummy like a rock. it was all good going down but painful after.

honestly, I won't get those fries again and seriously not sure why everyone raves about them.
author: Sally T.

description:
Found this on yelp and LOVED IT.
Came here for my brother's farewell dinner. 
Great for families and our dinner was for 5 people.
**Make sure to make reservations ahead of time!! Waited an hour because we didn't.
--------------------------------------------------
Ordered the specials that were posted on the front of the menu and on the walls of the restaurant:

1. Salt and baked half chicken. (4.5/5)
     -Not a fan of chicken, but it was cooked to perfection, recommended!
     -$11.95

2. Bean sprouts with garlic sauce. (3/5)
     -Usually one of my favorite veggie plates, decent, nothing too special.
     -$8.95

3. Dried Scallops with Egg Whites Fried Rice.  (4/5)
     -Wish they had more scallops in it, but very good flavor.
     -$8.95

4. Signature Hakka pan fried stuffed tofu with magic sauce. (5/5)
     -Love Tofu and loved this plate.
     -$8.95

5. Pork Belly with Preserved Vegetables.  (4.5/5) 
     -Not a fan of pork, but pretty tasty. I even ate the belly fat.
     -$12.95

6. House Special Pan-fried Vermicelli   (5/5) 
     -AMAZING, they really spent time and pan-fried this dish.
     -$6.95

7. Sauteed Lily Bulbs & Fungus with Greens (4.5/5)
     -Spicy and delicious mix of veggies.
     -$7.95
--------------------------------------------------
Overall, I'm very picky about chinese food and this place surely surpassed my expectations. 
Final bill came out to be around $75. 
Make reservations ahead of time and order the menu specials!
author: Claudia C.

description:
thursday dinner at eight pm...difficult street parking...finding a wait and standing...mostly circular larger tables for big group dining...group of three to four sharing tables with others...one or two small tables seen in the back...beer first from tsingtao, heineken or one other...group of three and first-time visit...planning on leftovers and ordering five dishes...house soup complimentary to start...pork bone broth with black beans, carrots and lotus root...good herbal flavors...salt baked chicken half delivered first...salt and oil sauce accompanying...taste the salt in the skin and fairly simple dish chopped up small...cumbersome dealing with small and shattered bones...second, the vegetable stir-fry..perfection in seasoning with simple garlic and salt flavors...cooked excellent finding quite large in portion....braised pork belly and preserved vegetables...extremely thick cuts (too thick), but sinfully delicious...fatty belly soft and melting...balanced by tangy pickled warm chopped vegetables...a good dish for lust of fat...whole sea bass lathered in black bean sauce great...topped with lean pork strips even better...skin and fatty belly the best part....mutilating and bone picking dining...sticky rice last to come...requesting white rice due to delay...largest leaf wrapped sticky rice ever experienced...quite hefty to lift...enough for five...well seasoned sticky rice nonetheless...little more ethnic in preparation and presentation...heavy handed at seasoning and a full flavored experience...$hundred total for what was mentioned above...enough food to feed five to six....

mention that other various items good at hakka...great clams in crunchy toasty garlic...noodles and vegetables delicious...whole chicken stuffed in pig stomach good, but a very large soup and too much chicken...
author: Hen A.

description: Food was mediocre at best. Egg rolls were cold in the middle.  The broccoli was old because some of the flowers were yellow gray.   Service was not great, but maybe because we were not Chinese?  We felt a little like second class citizens. We won't return.
author: Kelly M.

description:
They easily took on all fifty of us for Saturday lunch, and seated us both downstairs and upstairs. I know nothing about Hakka cuisine but I know my Chinese food. This place has it down pat. 

Our table of eight ordered from the Economy Family Dinner ($19.95 for three huge plates!) which runs for both to-go meals and lunch. Note that you can't order the Economy Family Dinner for...dinner. We ordered twice from the fixed-price menu, and two extra dishes from the lunch-time special. $4.95 for rice places, yum! So literally, this whole meal cost a little over $60. 

Pros:
Clean venue, kind waitrers/waitresses, insane portions, constantly refilled tea, the starter soup (some tofu-corn concoction)
**Braised fish fillet and tofu: One of the "lighter" dishes; served in a clay pot and almost perfectly executed.
**Ma pao tofu with minced pork: I love tofu! Spot on. NOT SPICY AT ALL!
**Salt and pepper spare ribs with string beans: More meat than batter, surprisingly. 

Mediocre: 
**Black mushroom chicken with veggies: My mom can make this.
**Beef and broccoli: I can make this.
**Chinese sausage fried rice: I can DEFINITELY make this.

Cons:
Street parking
*Eggplant and tofu with minced beef: Not really a con, but since I was the only one who liked eggplant, I ended up eating most of it and I began hating eggplant... A little overcooked.
*Village style vermicelli: Way too dry!!!

AN IMPORTANT CHEAP CHINA WOMAN'S TIP:
A tub of rice is $5, so just order a plate that comes with rice for your group! 

Super cheap, good for groups, and pretty yummy. I will come back :)
author: Colleen M.

description:
3.5+ for this restaurant at which we had a family "winter holiday" dinner last Friday (something celebrated by Chinese families for the beginning of the winter season).  We were treated by a relative, and selected was a $168 set menu.  We had seven people at the table for by the size of the dishes it was probably meant for bigger parties.  The portions were huge.  I loved the large bowl of seafood fish maw soup that came with the set meal.  I also very much enjoyed the crab dish, it came with two crabs but seems like each one was pretty big sized because we didn't finish even though I ate so much from that plate.

The waitress was pretty nice and talkative in general, and the owner seemed nice also when she pointed him out during part of the conversation.

For me, it's a place worthy to go more often if given the opportunity for family-style dinner.
author: H K.

description:
I came here on a Friday at 6 and got seated quickly. The restaurant was pretty packed already

We ordered
Hakka steamed tofu which has a unique flavor I think they used salted fish
Walnut and prawns which was done right
Pea sprouts and garlic was good
Mushrooms and beef the beef was very tender
Salt baked chicken it was ok

This place is pretty much on top of their game. Service is quick and the chefs
 cooking is so authentic .

I would come here again to try the specials pork belly :)
author: DOM d.

description:
I got to try this restaurant 2 Fridays ago (Sept 28) with my Mom and we both loved it !!! We were lucky to have a waiter named Raymond who was very corteous & accomodating, (very different from the "normal" waiters that you'll find in other chinese restaurants) ... and on top of that Raymond can speak English and gave us GREAT recommendations on what we should order.

So, to be able to try more dishes, I gathered my whole family (party of 10) to go try this restaurant out again the following Monday (Oct 1) ... and we have ordered the following:

-Pumpkin Strips with Salted Egg 
-Frog Fried with Salted Yellow Duck Yolk 
-Minced Pork with Lettuce Wrap 
-Chinese Bacon with Preserved Greens 
-Mushu Pork 
-House Special Clams 
-Egg White Fried Rice 
-Fried Rice with salted fish
-Honey Walnut Prawns with Vegetables 
-Sweet and Sour Pork 
-Braised Tofu with salted fish
-Seafood Chow Mien 
-String Beans with Minced Pork in XO Sauce 
-House Special Spicy Sauce Pork Stomach 
-Steamed Sea Bass 
-Salt and Baked Chicken 
-Salt and Pepper Spareribs with String Beans 
plus 
-Wintermelon soup (Free)
-Warm Pumpkin Dessert Soup (Free)

Love ! love! love! this restaurant .... too bad that they didn't have crab that night :(
although they have lobster .... my mind was all set that night ... I ONLY wanted Crab with salted egg and lobster was not a good substitute !!! 

Hakka Restaurant is now my new favorite Chinese restaurant !!! ... same top position on my list as  R & G Lounge in downtown SF !!! but since this place is closer to my Moms' and price is so much cheaper .... we will be coming to this place a lot more often !!! Give it a try ... it will not disappoint !!!
author: Elsie L.

description:
first time at the hakka style restaurant.
I really like the food here.
salt egg pumpkin
salt fish tofu clay pot
pinapple pork rib
A vegetable
hakka style rice noodle

all really good , wants to go back soon to try other dishes
author: Rina C.

description:
Typical outer Richmond/sunset restaurant. Grumpy service ugly decor hole in the wall. Food is awesome. Pork belly is heaven!! 
The hype about the pumpkin fries is overrated! More of a greasy fry! Everything else was good!  Parking is hell!
author: robbie l.

description: If its not busy go, else this isn't worth the wait.  The food was average and the service was typical for a Chinese Restaurant.  I'm sure if you're not Asian, your service would be better - again, typical for a Chinese Restaurant.  We ordered the Garlic Eggplant, Honey Walnut Prawns, and Sweat Spareribs.  The prices were reasonable.  They're just not my 1st choice given that this is in San Francisco.
author: Jeremy D.

description: Not bad.  Food is good.  They have big tables great for families.  Service was good.  Got the about 8 to 10 dishes.  Only thing that disappointed me was the dessert.  Just orange slices.. :(
author: Lizzie C.

description: Fantastic pork belly (chinese bacon). Also had clams with salt and black bean sauce.  $30. Fed 3 people. Stuffed.
author: Patrick L.

description:
4.25
Fairly small chinese restaurant that can fit maybe around 50 people. 

Disclaimer: I dont really like egg yolks or cilantro
 
Their specialty includes their egg yolk crab and frog. We got the egg yolk crab and Id have to say it wad delicious and one of the better crabs Ive eaten. I hate all forms of eggs besides scrambled but it was their signature dish so I had to try it. The egg yolk batter on the outside gave the crab a lot more flavor that complimented the juicy hot crab well.

Other notable dishes included their fish stomach soup and seafood fried rice that were both saturated with cilantro. Being lazy, I didnt want to pick out the cilantro despite my detest for them. To my surprise, the cilantro mixed pretty well and I barely tasted it which actually enhanced the flavor of the dish. For the most part 80% of their dishes have cilantro in them.

The pork catfish was an interesting combination but it worked well. The catfish was half deep fried and the pork on top lessened the fishy taste in my opinion. They also added sour mustard greens.

The beef spareribs, seafood vegetable dish, baked chicken, abalone mushroom with mustard greens, and squash sago dessert were good but nothing exciting to report about them.

Overall a very nice chinese restaurant and an upgrade over the usual places I go to. I wouldnt mind coming back especially to get the egg yolk crab
author: Robert Y.

description:
We walked into Hakka restaurant in the middle of the afternoon feeling hungry after a long day at the Golden Gate Park. The first thing we saw was a picture of a pork stomach dish on the wall: a good sign of authenticity.

It was only my partner and I. So we didn't get to try much from the menu, most of which sounded very appetising to us. We ordered the holy grail of Hakka cuisine--pork belly with preserved vegetable--and a claypot of tofu and fish fillet. Pork belly was served on a bed of lettuce which is very normal but it was rather bland. Dare I say, old? I could tell they didn't make that on the very day, perhaps just steamed to warm it up. Preserved vegetable had some hard bits in it and a slight grittiness in the sauce--and indication that they didn't wash the veg very well. Pork and tofu claypot came with big pieces of fried tofu and fish fillets (that didn't taste fishy) and smothered with brown sauce. I quite enjoyed this actually, especially when it came to our table piping hot.

Overall, the food was a hit or miss but I would love to come back to try their other dishes. Less than enthusiastic service to say the least, with zero smile whatsoever. Then again, it's quite typical in a Chinese restaurant. What bugged me the most is that I had to pay extra for rice. WHO EATS CHINESE FOOD WITHOUT RICE?? Most of these dishes are meant to be eaten with rice, unless you're in a banquet. By not including rice with the entrees, they are taking an important part of the experience from the customers.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
delicious hakka/canto style chinese restaurant
decent service

kau yook- braised pork belly with preserved veggies- yummy
deep fried golden pumpkin- really good, savory goodness
giant clam with garlic and vermicelli- delicious 
stir fry pigs intestines with mustard green, celery- so good one of my favs!

overall very good quality and value for what you get 
clean
not too overly loaded with msg
reasonably priced

will be back!
author: Petri Y.

description: Food is not bad, we ordered a set dinner portions were big. Few minor issues - parking is horrible but expected in San Francisco. Staff were funny in Cantonese way. Soup came with a strain of hair on the side of the bowl but nothing serious.
author: Martin N.

description:
4 of us went for lunch last Saturday. Ordered the following:-

Pork Belly-very good. Even the next day!
Salt baked chicken - takes 1/2 hour to cook - tasty.
Crab+pumpkin baked in salted yolk batter - yummy-even the next day.
Clams in a ginger broth-ok. Have tasted better back home(in Malaysia).
Steamed tofu stuffed with minced pork+salted fish-good.
Mixed vegetables -basic.
Sticky rice - very good - even the next day.
Sweet n sour pork - as good as the ones back home.

FYI, you get complimentary (big)bowl of soup w pork for starters. And since they only have desserts during dinner, we were given complimentary cut oranges ( which were so good!)instead.

The extra star is for the bustling ambience of the place which was almost full although it was only 12pm on a sleepy Saturday! Will go back to try the other dishes - one that says goose gut sounds tempting!
author: Renuka V.

description:
Would I come back? No, there are too many restaurants in the world to waste my time here.

Food: Sticky Rice was pretty good.
Sweet & Sour Pork, Steamed Clams were ok.
The Pork Stomach w/ Preserved Veggie was pretty nasty. The pork stomach was obviously ran through water/soaked in water for an extensive amount of time.

Service: Male waiter was super condescending while we tried to order. 
He also forgot 2 of our dishes and he didn't say sorry. He only said: "Oh there's a party downstairs. You have everything now, right?" This was his response after we waited another 20 minutes after we asked about our missing items. So in total it took about 40 minutes for the missing items to come out.
He also didn't bring us the orange slices, just the bill.
So, if you have the male waiter...good luck  to you.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Packed on a weekend! Make reservations for large groups of 6+

They forgot one of our dishes because it was so BUSY! Lots of noise, lots of food choices and lots of sexy looking Asians :)
author: Sam Y.

description: Major MSG alert! You have been warned. It tasted pretty good when we were there. Then I know why after we left the place. I was so thristy and it gave me headache. If you are used to MSG and/or OK with it. This place is for you. If not avoid it.
author: Vivi C.

description:
dinner review...

great service. with waiters that actually speak english? what's this world coming to? lol. parking kind of sucks though... come early. or make reservations. even though they have 2 floors, they get packed really quick. by 6pm, there's already a wait out the door. 

soup - they ALWAYS start you off with soup. we had the carrot w/lotus. not as watered down as other places. 

salt baked chicken - first time i've had chicken from a chinese restaurant and it was NOT dry! this was perfectly cooked and the sauce was perfectly paired with it.

minced seafood lettuce wrap - seafood is actually better than the minced pork! less fatty and very flavorful!

pumpkin strips with salted egg yolk - OMG. FREAKING DELISH!! this is a MUST try. def going for the crab with salted egg yolk next time.

sticky rice - cool presentation and pretty good. i've had better sticky rice though. 

chinese bacon with preserved cabbage - not my forte. but dad and my bf loved it.

tapioca and taro dessert soup - all i have to say is it's so much better than red bean dessert soup. 


total bill for the 5 of us... less than $80. so, not too shabby. can't wait to switch up our family gatherings and come here for a change!
author: Ann T.

description:
The things that caught my eye were the red carpet, the many pictures of the food  and the well lit authentic Chinese atmosphere. The Chinese atmosphere consisted of many families, family style eating and the fact that you could hear the conversation of a table, a few tables down. 
Food-4/5
Service- average 
Atmosphere 4.5/5 
My family and I ate here for my fathers birthday and we were pleasantly surprised by the delicious meal we would be exploring. 
Ordered
Chinese Bacon with Preserved Greens
-really good. There wasn't that much fat on the bacon which i really enjoyed and so did my parents.
Pineapple Spareribs
-delicious. I was adamant at first to get this since I don't usually like bone in but my mother convinced me otherwise and I don't regret it! The sauce was sticky and thick and sweet. The portion wasn't too skimpy either!
House Special Steamed Chicken
-My father rates this 4/5 and I would have to agree but the chicken seems too yellow and my mother seems to think that they painted or added food coloring to Make it seem more "yellow."

Overall experience was okay. The food was not as oily as expected and I would definitely be coming back if I'm around. The parking was very difficult but there's purple kow right across the street! I'm satisfied.
author: Wesley W.

description:
Great food at a bargain price and friendly staff.

I'm a regular taker-outer here. I don't dine in because it's almost always crowded (It's always a good sign when an ethnic restaurant is filled up with the customers of the same ethnicity, thus I will only eat at Chinese restaurant filled with Chinese, Indian restaurant filled with Indians, Thai restaurant filled with Thais, and McDonalds full of fatties, but I digress). 

When I'm done surfing the gnarly waves of Ocean Beach, or bench pressing 250 pounds for 30 reps at the local gym, I like to quell my appetite with favorites such as the Hong Kong style seafood noodle, salt and pepper ribs, Chinese bacon with preserved greens, and whatever else on their menu tickles my fancy- order whatever you want, you can't go wrong.

My food is always ready in 15 minutes. 

Thank you Hakka.
author: Donovan V.

description:
Picked this place for our family Chinese NY dinner.  Made reservations & preordered our dinner.  Upon arrival, all was in place!!!  

We ordered 2 Lobster dishes.  Pumpkin strip & the other cooked the old fashion Chinese style - green onions & ginger.  The latter was the favorite.  Not a fan of deep frying a lobster.  It had no flavor!  

We had the stuff chicken with sticky rice.  This has to be ordered ahead of time.  It was very good!  

House clams, house chicken, walnut prawns, oxtail clay pot, clams in shells, pea sprout n garlic, house Tofu, & seafood soup.   Everything was good, but not amazing!  

Service was amazingly good.  I would come back & try other dishes.  
I can see how difficult it would be to park!  We came during a week night & at 7:30pm.  Parked along Fulton.   Great - only a block away!
author: Marie E.

description:
Found this place on yelp. . It caught my eyes because of the fatty pork!  Hahaha
I have had a few in the Bay Area but never had something good. This one is good but I wouldn't call that melt in my mouth.   It has a good texture but the lean part is still a bit dry.  

Salt egg crab is good.   Crab is fresh but my dear didn't like the batter cuz is not crispy  I think it's ok cuz that means it's all salt egg not flour.

Salt egg pumpkin is good cuz the pumpkin is soft and that melt in my mouth.

Tofu is just ok.  The steamed eggplant was a disappointment cuz we didn't expect its fried first than steam.   Its too oily for a steam dish. 

They also have goose intestine and pig stomach.  If I live closer I might try again but not a place I will bring friends and family to.  However it is a good deal for set dinners with good quality.
author: Jo L.

description: Great place for family dinner. Small restaurant so have to call in early for a table to be there. The food is very good. This place is more of an American Chinese place. So lots of ABC (American Born Chinese) will be there. Get the sticky rice with chicken. It's very good. Super crunchy. And try out the clam that is deep fried with garlic.
author: Nick F.

description:
food: 4/5
service :2/5

This is a great chinese restaurant in the outer richmond which served Hakka style chinese food. It is something different than the standard canton faire you get all over the bay area. My party had the pork belly, squash with salty egg, and tofu. We tried to get all the hakka specialty dishes and it did not disappoint. I would definitely come here again.

I really liked the atmoshphere too. The place is very clean. There are several large tables which seat 10 and some small 4 people tables. And this place gets loud, which i really like. I am most comfortable at places where I don't have to be demure. The clientele is asian families and friends. There is a mix of families, younger, and older crowds. The only thing lacking is the service. I had to flag down 3 waiters to get my check. They seem understaffed.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Once upon a time, in a neighborhood FAR FAR FAR AWAY, there was a young man and a band of friends who met at a certain place. A place where a Chinese restaurant existed. Okay, it's not that far away, but if you're a native San Franciscan the Outer Outer Richmond darn near seems like a trek through suburbia. I mean this neighborhood should be reserved more for the Zoo or the wave breakers. But nevertheless, this Hakka style restaurant appears out of nowhere among other residential homes.

The converted two story Richmond home has a large front room with approximately 4-5 large 8-10 person tables. It is not readily noticeable, but there are tables on the second floor that are accessible by a stairway in the back, through the kitchen. These tables are mostly for smaller groups. My group was seated on the second floor after an hour wait. We were constantly thinking of ways to slip the head waitress some money so we could eat sooner.

The food was good as expected, in terms of Chinese family soul food. The Pork Belly is an essential dish for any meal here, it was so juicy tender and delicious, pinkish to the core still when served. We had an order of Eggplant with Garlic, Dau Miu, Shrimp Walnuts, Fried Pumpkin chunks (?), Clay Pot Tofu, and Sweet and Sour Pork. Top that off with lots of rice. The dishes were large enough to serve 8 people for our group.  

The reservation system is a bit disorderly, but this is no knock on the service provided by the waitstaff and cooks. There really is no room in the front entrance to respond to waiting customers, and throw on top of that the way most Chinese families are, they will walk right up to the head waitress even if she is in the kitchen and continue to ask how much longer the wait is for their table.
