The most important part of this experience, the whole meal cost  $88 that includes tax and tip. So $11 per person! It was an incredible value. I was stuffed at the end.

A important tip, if you are interested in eating here with a group, MAKE RESERVATIONS! You will be waiting for an hour or hour and a half for a table. There is no place to stand in the restaurant due to the crammed front quarters, so you must stand outside to wait. You can try your luck with K&L (a block up from Hakka), but I guarantee it will be the same type of wait.
author: Michael C.

description: Most terrible Chinese restaurant I've ever been to- and that says a lot considering I'm of Chinese heritage. Their food is bland, completely lacks seasoning and salt. Though their menus are full of variety, don't be deceived- their cuisine is either one of the two (maybe both) 1. Too dry or 2. Overlooked. Never coming back and as far as their service goes, their waiters are forgetful, and service is slow.
author: Karissa K.

description:
I've had one dinner and one lunch here so far. It's pretty good! My siblings and mom kept saying how they we're famous for their roe battered crab. It was okay. I mean, I'm going to love anything to do with a fried crab so I wouldn't be so hard to please there. But with the way they were telling me that this was a must order dish, I didn't really get it. The batter was kind of cake-y, a little strange.

The braised pork belly is the dish to really try. Your heart and arteries won't thank you but it's so tasty! 

What was a really nice touch at the lunch we had here, the waiter noted that there were 2 kids at the table, under 6 years old, and had the kitchen make the dishes we ordered (one of which was listed as somewhat spicy) more mild. We didn't notice till we were served that they had done this. That was very thoughtful as the 2 kids loved it.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Best time to go to Hakka is at 6pm when there's not a lot of people, not to mention you still have a chance to find parking! 

When you go to Hakka, be ready for a cholesterol laden feast! But every single bite is definitely worth it! 

Must try: 

- The pork belly 
- Crabs and pumpkin in salted egg yolk batter
- Sauteed clams in chili & black beans
- Steamed & stuffed tofu
author: Gordon O.

description:
So much good food here and I don't think you can go wrong with anything you order. This place is big and good for groups, which is why you get large tables filled with chinese families. Be warned, noise level tends to get loud. Wait can be long if you walk in at dinner time without a reservation. We have waited for about an hour for a group of 10.
Their menu is very extensive and their popular dishes are pictured all over the restaurant. If you're ever at a loss for what to get, just close your eyes and point to a wall. Chances are you're getting something tasty.

We have tried:
Salted egg pumpkin or frog legs (very interesting)
Salt and pepper ribs (so crispy and good)
Claypot catfish (OMG)
Steamed sea bass (could be better)
Claypot tofu with fish
House tofu (very unique Hakka dish)
Glutinous rice wrapped in lotus leaf (MUST-try)
String beans (do not underestimate string beans, these are delicious)
Fried vermicelli (a friend swears by this)
Seafood noodle (I swear by this)

...probably more but I can't remember and will need to go again to refresh my tastebuds.
author: Sarah L.

description: it's okay only because when you claim it's Hakka food then i expect very very authentic Hakka food.  we are Hakka and when i ask my mom about the food, she made a "eat shit" kinda face and shook her head.  they had food that weren't bad tasting but you can get anywhere else, any non-Hakka restaurant.  either get some real Hakka food or change your name.  wouldn't go back again and wouldn't recommend even to try.
author: Ben L.

description:
I have been a regular since day one...even before when it was Tai San Restaurant.  I always have high ratings for Hakka...not anymore.  Ever since Danny left, the service and food quality have suffered.  

We have a reservation for 14 and we didn't get our table til 1 hour later.  In addition,  they were going to give us only one table for 14.  We originally booked for two tables.  The math doesn't work...you can seat 14 in a table built for 12.  We are not freaking sardines.

Sad to say that they are going to be another restaurant statistics of making it and about to lose it.

Million dollar question....would I go back?  Maybe take out only until their quality level declines further.
author: MickYee M.

description:
This is easily one of the best restaurants serving Chinese cuisine in the city. Their menu caters to both Chinese nationals and mainlanders from Indiana like my mom, but it leans pretty heavily toward Hakka cuisine. I don't think you'll find a disappointing dish on the menu. I've been a few times, and everything I've had has been wonderful. 

It's clear that the chef here has carefully chosen the menu and ingredients. Even their hot and sour soup is top-notch. Obviously, you should try one of their special dishes like salt-baked chicken or the battered pumpkin or frog, but even their char siu chow mein (the thin noodle variety; they have thick, also) blew me away with it's flat-out tastiness and simplicity. The only thing that bored me was the pot stickers, but this isn't a dim sum restaurant so who cares; skip the appetizers and get right down to business.

I went there on Thanksgiving last year, which I recommend because it's one of the few nights of the year these folks aren't crazy-ass busy. Get here early because it can become a bit of a madhouse on a weekend night.
author: Casey C.

description:
"This place is Hakka Good!" Hakka restaurant is a great alternative to more common Cantonese restaurants. Some signature Hakka dishes here are the salt baked chicken, pickled vegetable with intestines, and my personal favorite, the melt in your mouth pork belly with preserved vegetables. For the most part these dishes reflect the ability to pair sweet and savory while using relatively inexpensive ingredients to create well balanced dishes that Hakka people are known for. 

On the more modern side of things, the salted egg yolk frog & pumpkin dish was also excellent as the frog legs were super moist and the salt yolk texture went perfectly with the sweet/soft pumpkin.  Clams are also excellent here.

Give Hakka a try and venture to dishes you haven't tried before. You won't regret it.

Enjoy!
author: Byron C.

description:
Good place for filly, homey food that is not overcooked.  The signature tofu dish is good, though surprisingly heavy.  The meat and mushroom stirfries are, on the other hand, refreshingly light.  

The restaurant tends to get busy at dinner time - move away from the front doors and gather at the waiting space in the back.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT! BEST Chinese food in SF. 

This restaurant is right across from my mum's place. So we go there at least twice a month. It's crab season right now, so you should totally go try their salty egg yolk crab.. it is SO good!
author: Zee Z.

description:
Came in here with a friend on a Thursday afternoon and the place was a total dead zone, which was kind of freaky. However, their menu has a lot to offer and the prices are reasonable, so no complaints here. 

I especially loved the deep fried prawns and hot and sour soup. I thought their chow fun could have been more flavorful. Still, since the place was totally empty, we were completely ignored for a really long time (even after it was pretty obvious we were done eating). The staff just sort of disappeared? 

Anyways, it's not bad if you're in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't travel to get here.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I got really excited when I heard about this place since my mother's side of the family is Hakka, so it was a whole new experience looking further into my roots. I must say, the place is pretty well designed for a Chinese restaurant. I especially enjoyed how they put high quality pictures of the foods on the walls. Also expect a loud environment since most people who eat there are Chinese families or old people so it's natural. Another thing to look out for is if you go there for dinner, it make be packed. So making reservations is necessary, especially if you're going to bring a big party or have a family dinner. 

The waiter who served our table was really friendly and welcoming. His English is really clear because he is ABC just like me. Overall if he serves your table, consider yourself lucky since we all know how Chinese service usually are even if their food is great. 

What I recommend: 

-Fried egg yolk Frog with Fried Pumpkin
-Pork Belly with preserved veggies
-Ngiong Tew Foo (Tofu stuffed with meat)
-Salted Baked Chicken (Pricy though)

The fried pumpkins do complement the fried frog and the fried outer layer is fried with egg yolk which gives it a nice flavor. The pork belly is fatty but really good to eat once in a while, a lot of different flavors go on in that dish. The tofu stuffed with meat has a nice smooth texture and is glazed with yummy sauce that also compliments the tofu and meat combo. The salted bake chicken has a nice golden brown skin and does taste salty, but not too salty. 

The orders I recommended are Hakka foods, whereas many other things on the menu are the typical American Chinese food or Cantonese. 

The price may not be as cheap as other Chinese restaurants but it's worth trying, especially since there aren't many Hakka people here. So if you are tired of the typical Chinese foods in the Bay Area, Hakka cuisine is totally different if you order the right things.
author: Victor Q.

description:
3 1/2 stars. This place really surprised me for a small neighborhood restaurant. This place gets packed fast, even on a Monday night. Food is good, portions are decent, and price is cheap.......the only bad thing is that the AC is blasting and can get super cold

My dad wanted to come here for a very early Father's Day dinner. He ordered:

The salty bake chicken-I am not the biggest fan of chicken, but this dish was super good. So juicy and had alot of flavor

Salt and pepper spare ribs-comes with some green beans. Loved the flavor, but too many fatty pieces.

Honey pepper spare ribs-comes with bell peppers. This dish was super flavorful

Dao Mui-Vege with garlic. 

Hakka Tofu with minced pork-needs a little more meat, but sauce was good.
author: Karen H.

description:
I love this place. They make food the way my grandmother would have. Portions are huge and the price is decent. My fave is the fried frog legs with salted yolk. Their pork belly is better than most people's and the wait staff is always on it. This last time I went on a tuesday night at it was packed, people were waiting for tables at around 7:30 still. Everyone is very attentive and friendly. Must try!

Be warned, it does get loud when it's full.
author: Brian J.

description: I went here couple times, food was ok. But what makes me giving them one start is the price!!!!  .. The price for a  crab porridge on the menus says marketing price which I can understand,but I didn't think the price will go very hight ,cuz I know how much per BL for the crab in that season. But when I checked out, I can't believe That I got a crab porridge was $40 ish...I asked the owner why this porridge is so expensive. She said cuz there is one crab and the crab is $30 per BL!!!!! ( $6.99/BL at the Ranch 99)..Woooooo! I didn't say anything back ..cuz I know she won't give me the reasonable price .. I won't come back again...
author: Yueqi Z.

description:
i noticed that a lot of the chinese places in Richmond/Sunset district area are Hakka food... their signature dish is the chicken, get it and you won't regret it. Also, their pork belly with perserved vegetables is good. It's one of the dishes that will make you eat bowls and bowls of rice. Their deep fried frog with salty egg yolk is also good. They make this with the kabocha pumpkin also and that's a winner too!

The only downside is hard to find parking. If you're lucky, you'll find one within a few minutes. If not, be prepare to walk a few blocks!
author: Kapo T.

description:
Nothing impressive. I don't understand all the ranting and raving about this place... I ordered all the recommended dishes on yelp. My friend and I walked out there very disappointed due to the following reasons:
1. too much MSG, both of us had a bad sore throat and felt the dryness around our lips
2. Crab - missing a claw!! so i asked about it... the chef came out and said something about they were chopping so hard the claw was missing.... they took off $1 dollar off the bill...! $1 considering the I paid $30 for the dish and the most important part was missing...

I gave them 2 stars because service was actually acceptable, especially considering this is a low end Chinese restaurant.
author: Danika Z.

description:
Best place to get authentic Chinese Hakka food in SF... I've traveled far and wide from the twin peaks to the valleys of sunset, richmond, chinatown, and south SF...

GET HERE BEFORE 6!! Seating is best suited for small tables, they have an upstairs available. 

Food:
Can't really go wrong! This stuff is done right. From the pork chops being crispy and meaty (not too fatty and not too lean) enough to get glazed over with just the right sauce. To the beef short ribs thats glazed with honey and served with bell pepper. Of course the star of the show at this place really is the Fried Salty Egg Yolk Pumpkin!! Crispy, Salty, Rich, and Sweet all rolled into one golden looking piece of heaven... Price is definitely reasonable $10 (+/- $2). Service is good for a chinese restaurant and quantity and quality is all accounted for! 

The only complaint is the parking~ But they, it's San Francisco! No surprise. 

~~~GET THE 
FRIED SALTY EGG YOLK PUMPKIN~~~~
author: Dustin T.

description: Best clams I've ever had in my life and the crab was phenomenal.  I got food poisoning, but I forget easily.  Give me a few weeks and I'll be back.
author: JW C.

description: Passed by many times and wanted to try some of the foods here and finally I did. I did not like what I ended up with. The dishes main ingredients were salted pork and pickled vegetables. The fish we ordered was fried, steamed and that stuff toss on top; and did I mention underweight.
author: M C.

description:
Yes, it is authentic Chinese cuisine with giant pictures of the dishes on the wall for decoration. Yes, there are lots of Chinese people. Yes, the prices are reasonable, and yes there are the ubiquitous noisy eaters and wait staff busily buzzing around you. 

That said, do you want to be barked at upon entering about where you should sit? Do you want your dish to go to the wrong table, sit there for twenty minutes, be brought back to the kitchen, and then brought to your table as you are finishing your meal? Do you want to be given the hard look when you calmly say that you no longer want the item in question, as it is too late, not calling into question the health issues of what just took place. Do you want the waitress to act like she is doing you a big favor when she serves you the soup?

 I should have walked out when the host tried to force us to sit a large table for 12 when we were just 5. Overall they are busy so the feel they don't have to be courteous.   BTW, we weren't the only customers who were treated poorly about where to sit  by the host, and the guests were Chinese, so it's wasn't racism. Perhaps if you are a regular the staff treat you better.
author: paul m.

description: Excellent service, excellent food, excellent prices.  Thank you Hakka Restaurant for providibg such high quality Chinese food in this neighborhood!
author: Teresa H.

description: 4.5 stars. Authentic Chinese food, no frill environment. Like mongolian beef & lamb and tofu skin casserole. I even loved all of the thick skin, tendon, and muscle of the lamb dish. The longer one leaves the leftover of the lamb dish in the fridge, the better it tastes.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The place always seems to be packed with cheery Chinese folk. Try to avoid getting seated upstairs since it's downright depressing up there with just a few tables a banquet area. Food is middling tasty, as in the chicken could have used a little more marinating. It's weird to depend on the dipping sauce to get your chicken up to par. The pork belly here is amazing though, but I guess you have to take into account that it's hard to go wrong with throwing sugar, soy sauce, and fatty fatty meat together along with some bitchin' dried veggies. I could probably eat a whole bucket of rice with the sauce alone. We were feeling the cholesterol that day so we had the pork belly stir-fried with sea cucumber. Strange combo that didn't really quite come together. The latter seemed more there for texture than anything else.

I really like their fish and tofu clay pot though. Fresh slices of fish are battered up and then cooked in broth with scallions, mushrooms, and then all the sauce is soaked up with big chunks of juicy tofu. The sauce again alone is delicious with rice and really rich with garlic, ginger, and a soy tang.

Great location since it's a block from the beach and you always get the sense that its perched on a cliff by the ocean, sea fog blowin' round.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I like food.

I like Hakka.

I like the food at Hakka Restaurant in the Richmond.

For lunch we had prompt service, lots of chef's Hakka specials and really affordable. This place is good for a big group of friends that want to try a number of alt Chinese dishes that are not the regular fare. 

I look forward to coming back for diner and trying the lamb and the fungus. At lunch we had the boiled chicken with ginger, clams and Chinese broccoli. 

It was great.
author: Joe Bob J.

description:
Ha-cha-cha! I've eaten here at least three times, every time I consumed some amount of whiskey or scotch. The food is amazing, my favorite is an appetizer called salted pumpkin strips. 

Along those lines, go for their salted crab, clams and pork belly dishes. Also, don't be afraid to offer a drink to members of the establishment-they work hard to make that food.

Beware, the word is out that this place is good so if you decide to dine friday, saturday or sunday-best to call ahead for a reservation or show up around 5. We got there at 6 and we got to be seated upstairs just barely!
author: Joh W.

description: We have been to this restaurant a few times. The food here is decent but not epic for sure. The service can be good or bad depending on luck. It has a comfy and not stuffy environment.  The prices are not as high as Hong Kong Flower Lounge or Mayflower but the food is fine.
author: Jennie W.

description: Wow, this place is great! Found it on Yelp and thought I would take my elderly mom there after a doctor's appointment on Geary St. She is hesitant to go to places she is not familiar with, but we both really enjoyed the food. The first sign that comforted her...a full house filled with Chinese folks prompted her to say, "must be good."  We peeked at what the others were eating and noticed that the rice plates served at lunch time looked tasty and were served in generous portions. We opted to order off the regular menu: Mongolian Beef, Plain Soy Sauce Chow Mein and one of the Fried Rices. Everything was delicious and there was enough food to take home for two more portions. What a gem!
author: Debbie S.

description:
A very low key Christmas dinner for us.

We had our extended family get-togethers either on Christmas Eve, or the day after Christmas.  That left the the day of Christmas pretty much free.  Instead of staying at home and cooking, my folks wanted to head out for dinner with my brother's and my family.  On Christmas Day, most, if not all Chinese restaurants are open for business, so we pretty much expected to go out for Chinese food.

Hakka Restaurant is the third restaurant at this location, after Taishan and Happy Immortal.  Though located in a relatively remote location in San Francisco, these restaurants have been very successful as evidenced by the full capacity of the restaurant, and the difficulty of parking in the surrounding areas.  For different reasons, the previous tenants closed, but not for lack of business.

That evening, I didn't have much luck finding any quick parking.  Took me at least 20 minutes.  Fortunately, most of my family were already seated, and proceeded to order while I tried to find parking.

By the time I found parking, the food came out a few minutes later.

We ordered a lot of dishes, and it was a blur towards the end of dinner.  Food came out fast, and unfortunately, I didn't have time to snap any pics.

Here's what I remembered what we ordered (may not be in order):

-Pumpkin Soup:  Fish maw and crab.  Never had this before.  Slightly sweet, yet savory, with an orange tint from the pureed pumpkin.  Nice pieces of fresh, sweet Dungeness crab.

-Fried pumpkin with salted duck egg yolk:  They were like wedge-cut sweet potato fries, nicely contrasted with the salty dried duck egg yolk.

-Baked crab with Salted Duck Egg Yolk:  Battered crab, wok-fried with salted duck eggs.  The crab was hot, sweet, and meaty, and again, nicely contrasted with the duck egg.

-House Special Clams with basil sauce.  Arrived hot off the wok!  Yum.  Perfect with white rice.

-Fried tofu and eggplant:  cube pieces of tofu and eggplant lightly battered and fried.  Tofu was crispy on the outside, but soft in the middle.

-Braised Pork belly with Preserved Veggies:  So good, yet so bad.  Yes, artery-hardening goodness!

-Spicy Eggplant and Minced Pork

-Salt Baked Chicken:  A house specialty.  Chicken was very moist, even the white meat.  Came with a side of plum sauce.

-Chinese Broccoli with XO Sauce: Gotta have some veggies!

-Tofu, minced chicken, and salted fish in clay pot:  Another dish you have to eat with rice.  Love the pungent, saltiness of the fish with the soft tofu.

-Short Ribs with Black pepper and honey sauce:  Quickly cooked in a wok, arrived hot to the table.  Very good.

-Lamb with Dry Bean Curd in clay pot:  Another one of the house specials.  Pieces of lamb with bone, cooked in a clay pot with dried bean curd.  Very tender pieces of lamb, and the sauce in the claypot was nice over rice.

I probably missed a few dishes, but needless to say, were quite full by the end of the meal.  I would have love a little more time to sit and let the food digest, but there were a few people standing, staring at our table, wondering if we were done.  I wouldn't have paid much attention to them, but we decided to vacate so they could enjoy their holiday dinner with their family.

Comfort food at it's best.....
author: Steve L.

description: Friendly people big variety of food like the chicken dishes there especially..................
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Pumpkin strips, get in my mouth.

Sauteed eggplant? A+. Pork belly with fermented vegetables? A+. Frog with woodear fungus and lily buds? A- because of all the tiny bones, but you can't blame a restaurant for frog anatomy. Pumpkin strips? SWEET MOTHER OF GOD, STAY WITH ME FOREVER. There is no letter grade for these things. They are so far beyond normal levels of tastiness that you might explode, or weep, or eat three orders and still want more. Thanks, Hakka! I'm going through pumpkin strip withdrawal already (so much worse than opium withdrawal, guys).
author: Corinna K.

description: The food is amazing and authentic!  Prices are reasonable and the service is efficient and friendly.  I highly recommend the pork belly!  The place is packed during peak dinner times so bring a jacket and prepare to wait outside since there's not much room in the restaurant to sit/stand while waiting.  There's residential parking all around but you may have to walk a few blocks during peak hours.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Overall a disappointment for me and my wife. The dishes lacked flavor starting with the complimentary soup. Looked great with a golden stock color. Very little chicken flavor though.  As my grandmother said, if there was chicken put in that pot, it must have gone though on stilts. (You had to have been there.)

Many of the reviewers mention how crowded the restaurant is with Chinese families. Absolutely true. Noise level is not that bad, but the restaurant is crowded with no place to wait for your table. In a residential area a ways out there. Nothing else in the area. OK cleanliness. Parking is non existent and we ended up two blocks away on a cold night.

We went with a group of nine, so we had a good variety. Best of the dishes was the asian broccoli. Nice garlic, crunchy, perfect.

Worst was the clams. Tons of oil and spices and way too much salt. Close to being inedible.

The noodles with barbecued pork had precious few slivers of pork that were actually thinner than their noodles. Noodles were in a huge pile, but very little BBQ pork or flavor.

Sweet and sour pork was very good. The pork was soft and had a great flavor. Not much pineapple or green pepper and a relatively small portion.

Sticky rice had a great presentation being wrapped in lotus leaves. But it was not hot, only warm. Edible but no wow factor.

We paid about $16/person but we over ordered and others took the left overs home.  Probably should be under $12 or so with tip.

I could go on, but why? I will never go back.

Summary, food was cheap and plentiful. We think that is why it is full.
author: Gene M.

description:
Been here a couple of times. Once downstairs and once upstairs if you care?!

The salted egg crab and pumpkin strips are worth the trek across the city alone. We havehad that both times and loved it and typing it out is making me drool and think about it again. That dish is worth 6 stars!

However, the other dishes ordered (salt baked chicken, fried rice and an eggplant dish) were forgettable. This may just be what we ordered but it tasted a bit too salty for my liking so if you don't particularly like uber salty food then this place is likely not for you.

But....did I mentioned the salted egg crab and pumpkin strips?! Wow! Yummy! See you there right now then!!
author: Nick L.

description: Chinese bacon with preserved veggies and pumpkin strips with egg yolk breading. This is what gave me an orgasm last night. I ate it, then I orgasmed. That's not even a word but it's completely true. The Chinese bacon is just pork belly but it's authentic Chinese pork belly. Not the tiresome SF pork belly that you see around the city. The baked chicken wasn't that great but the other dishes made up for it. Can't wait to go back and try more dishes. Bring a big group!
author: Michael S.

description:
I was disappointed to see frogs featured so prominently on the menu at this restaurant. The practice of eating frogs depletes wild amphibian populations and introduces nasty infectious diseases into our local environment, particularly the chytrid fungus that is wiping out so many frog populations. More information can be found at http://www.savethefrogs.com/actions/frog-legs/.
Restaurants need to learn that this practice is not acceptable.
author: Patrick S.

description: This is a very difficult review to write.  I can't say one dish really stood out.  The food is all good so I guess high marks for quality and consistency.  Their service could probably be a little more attentive.  It's not deplorable or anything but i definitely did not leave thinking "wow, what great service."  Plate sometimes get flopped down.  They will look at you when you don't play your part in the table plate Tetris mini-game that frequents Chinese restaurants.  Good ones, the waiter does all the Tetris work for you.  This place is almost always packed with hordes of Chinese people so you may have a short wait for a table from time to time.  Some dishes are salty, but they are meant to be eaten with rice which might not be obvious so if you don't expect or know that, it could be a bit of a surprise.  Check it out and make your own decision.
author: Nat L.

description: Great little place, gave us free soup which was delicious.  The food came out hot and fresh.  The fish fillet tasted like it had been frozen but was still decent.  They give you hot sweet desert bowls for free too.  Service was good.
author: Jon L.

description:
My family dinners are ALWAYS at chinese or vietnamese restaurants. So needless to say, we are super picky. My grandparents would be hated on yelp if they could review all the chinese restaurants in the bay area. So brace yourself for a harsh review.
The cousin and I chose this restaurant for a family dinner just to venture out of our parents' comfort zone. But since we chose the place, we were forced to order too.
I decided to choose the lettuce wraps with seafood. It was good. But  I didn't like that some of the lettuce was actually soggy and wilted. And I like my fresh veggies to look fresh :(
My cousin ordered the rest. She had the walnut shrimp. The kind that has mayonaise slathered all over it. I don't know about you guys, but I'm used to the walnut shrimp to look more pinkish. The ones we got were golden brown like the color of Mickey D's chicken nuggets. They tasted good though.
We also got a lamb dish that as stir-fried with snow peas and zucchini. It was alright. Nothing special.
We also had the chicken and cuttlefish stir-fry. It had celery in it. It was pretty good but it had this after taste that was like sa-tay sauce (the kind you eat with hot pot). It was a little spicy.
I forgot what the last dish was...something with mushroom or fungi...it was stir-fried too. 
The stir-fried dishes basically all tasted the same. Except for the sa-tay after taste in the chicken and cuttlefish.
I mean, it's not like I won't come back here again. But I'm not dying to go there again either.
Also, we were super thirsty after dinner. So maybe there was MSG or there was too much salt.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Where else can you find lunch specials for 4.95?!? 

Despite the price, the food here is actually very good. After going to KL, a block away from this restaurant, a friend told me to try this place. 

I am still surprise that there are restaurants in outer Richmond. This is on 45th and Cabrillo..................my gawd this area is dead. The restaurant is your typical Kam's, Golden river, Superior type establishments. Very atypical. 

We ordered filet fish with vegetables, bitter melon and spare ribs and we both split a clay pot curry beef brisket. After hearing Euge l ordered I will need to come back and try the rest of the food. 

Everything was very well cooked. Bitter melon wasn't overly sweet which I hate, the fish was cooked well, the curry beef brisket is exactly how I like it. A good go to place if you are press for time, broke, and hungry.
author: jason g.

description:
in my opinion I thought the food is very authentic home style Chinese cuisine, very similiar to the type of food I grew up on, if you like Toisan foods you will also like Hakka Chinese cuisine.

the service was excellent, they were very attentive and fast to get your food out, also very friendly servers

and you know it's good when you see a restaurant full of old school Chinese customers, they always know where to get good , fresh authentic dishes

this restaurant seems to be very popular for groups, I didnt see many small tables for single diners, maybe a couple, but they mostly had the large round family sized tables

dont worry if it looks full , because they also have a hidden upstairs dining area , at first I thought it was a full house then they told me they have another table upstairs

the prices are reasonable and the servings were generous

if you enjoy authentic home style asian cuisine you wont be disappointed
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
Our family of seven came to Hakka for an early Mother's Day Lunch on Saturday.
Found parking one block away from the restaurant and it must have been our lucky day.  There were several tables available so we were seated immediately.

We had bbq pork won ton soup, lemon chicken, double mushroom chicken, broccoli beef, gai lon with salted fish, yang chow fried rice, minced chicken in lettuce wrap, dry chow fun.

Our waitress Maisie was very attentive although the restaurant got very busy while we were there.  Asked for water (once) and it was brought to us right away.  

It is now our favorite go-to restaurant.
author: el h.

description:
After 3 visits, every item I tried under Chef's Special is recommended. Salt-baked chicken is a must-try item. 

It is refreshing to have good and attentive service. Management appreciate their patrons. A novel concept most Mom-n-Pop business fail to understand.

Note: The establishment is now serving beers.

=)
author: DAVID N.

description:
Off in a residential area, hidden between on the north side of Golden Gate Park and the Golden Gate Bridge, is this restaurant. I wouldn't say it's a gem... but rather, smooth stone.

Okay, enough with the ambiguity and metaphors. Hakka is much like your typical Chinese restaurant. Mediocre furniture and utensils, too many pictures of dishes on the walls, and the same 100-200 dishes available on the menu. I didn't find much out of the ordinary here.

Here's what I had (with my family):

I had the Sticky Rice Wrapped in Lotus Leaf, and it turned out to be cold. I think they prepared it beforehand, and tried to steam it back up. (A certain lamb dish). Frogs with Vegetables, which I highly recommend. This one was my favorite out of all of them.

Fried Rice with Dried Scallop and Egg Whites. This dish was good, I recommend it too. 

Baked Salt and Pepper Chicken - I would recommend a HALF chicken for this dish. The chicken smells great and tastes pretty good too, but only in moderation. After a while, the chicken cools and the smell isn't as strong. By then, the chicken just turns dry.

It was a busy night for these guys so service was a slightly slower than usual. For 1 of our dishes, we had to ask a waiter 20 minutes after the 2nd to last dish came out where that last dish was. It was brought to us immediately after, and the waiter said that they're short 1 cook for the holidays. Oh well... water under the bridge.

It's not likely that I'll come back here again. Not because I has a horrible experience, but because nothing about my experience impressed me. Whether you choose to give them a chance is your call...
author: Morgan P.

description:
This is not just one of the best Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area, but one of my favorites too. I had read some reviews that described the cooking here as "heartfelt" and it's true. 

Knowing nothing about Hakka cuisine, but always wanting to try new regional cuisines, I went here very excited.

They gave us an excellent soup with some type of greens to start. We ordered the salt baked chicken, deep fried pumpkin, and Chinese bacon with preserved greens.

It was not necessarliy as "clean" as I'm used to authentic Chinese food being, but it was sitll absolutely all fresh and delicious - I like to think of this more as Chinese comfort food.  

The salt-baked chicken was just all right - i've heard that it's better if you order it in advance. The fried pumpkin and Chinese bacon were absolutely delicious - the portion was absolutely obscene - and pure fat:)

Was served a complimentary red bean soup as dessert - could have been a little sweeter, but not going to complain about free dessert :)

Jai Yun is still in my opinion the best Chinese restaurant in San Francisco - but its very hard to recommend to other people besides of its numerous quirks, and this is the restaurant i've started to recommend to people looking for authentic Chinese food in San Francisco.
author: Mark A.

description:
I'm not really a huge fan of Chinese food. The only time I ever have it is if we're having a big family dinner (which is why we came here). I will say that this is definitely better than your average Chinese restaurant!

I'll spare the details since everyone pretty much knows the common dishes, how Chinese restaurants are, etc. but things to note include:

-If you have a party of 8+, definitely make a reservation. 
-If you have a reservation, definitely make sure your party is there to call dibs on the table you reserved. (Another group tried to swoop on one of our two tables... I don't know WHY they thought they could have a reserved table and that our party would be perfectly fine with half our party seated.)
-The walnut prawns dish is different... more fried and less mayo-ey but still pretty decent.
author: Miss H.

description:
Great little mom and pop joint to get some Hakka food. We made reservations to avoid the waiting game and pretty much got seated on time. Very easy to read menu with pictures of the dishes. 

We started off with the lobster with salted egg yolk and pumkin, we wanted the crab but no luck. I gotta say it was a nice change of pace from the norm and the pumpkin was a nice touch. Would love to try the crab though. Next we got the salt baked chicken. Very good dish, skin was crispy, baked just right, just wish there was more meat on the bird. Next we got the stringy spinach looking vegetable with garlic. Super good would order again. We also ordered the pan fried stuffed tofu. Very good dish I would also order this dish again. We tried to order the sea bass or the rock cod but they didn't have it, so we got the black bass. Not memorable for me it tasted a little muddy. We joked that they caught this fish themselves from the delta (LoL). I almost forgot Da Dish, The pork belly! Super tender and great flavor, this is the must try dish here. We heard their clams and frog dishes are good. Maybe next time. 

It can get very packed in here so reservations are helpful. I would have given them 5 stars if they had the dishes we wanted plus they didn't have the tapioca dessert. You also might enjoy the 3 items for $20.
author: T L.

description:
Order the chef's special dishes on the menu instead of your typical Americanized Chinese food for an interesting experience on taste and flavor. That being said, my family and I ordered dishes we would never think about eating. Some of the dishes if I can recall:

-Stir fried frogs with salted egg yolk. It actually had the pumpkin fries some of the reviews were talking about. The frogs were very tasty. The pumpkin was SO good. So yummy...
-The pork belly dish with preserved vegetable. I did not eat the pork belly, but the preserved vegetables were delicious with the flavors from the belly.
-Steamed eggplant with garlic. Rather light and tasty.

My main complaint on nearly all their dishes would be that they are WAY TOO SALTY. Just too salty that when we order the Honey Walnut Prawns which came with some boiled broccoli, it was salted! Not a good way to eat your veggies.

Service wise, it got so busy that I was so thankful taking advices from yelp reviews on making reservations because if we didn't, we may not have the chance to experience Hakka cuisine.
author: Kim L.

description: I'm Asian but I eat Chinese food like a non Chinese food eating person (if that makes any sense). I ordered lemon chicken, sweet and sour pork, chow mein and green beans. Best part of the meal was the green beans. The chicken and pork were very DRY....couldn't even finish it. If you like Americanized Chinese food don't waste your time here. Perhaps I will try some more authentic options next time.
author: Erin C.

description:
Yes for cheapness! Yes for accommodation! Yes for service! Yes for food!

I went here with the big group of 50 with fellow Yelper, Colleen M. I didn't sit at the same table as her but it was all fun in there with 50 of us and them being able to accommodate us just fine.

Our table ordered two sets of the $19.95 deal for three huge plates. We also got a plate of chow fun and congee. Rice comes with the economy family dinner ($19.95). It was just enough (and a bit more) to fill 8 hungry stomachs. The total was $7 PER PERSON including tax/tip!

Some of my favorite dishes we ordered:
+ Ma pao tofu (mapo doufu) - Really delicious. Went well with the rice. Only a bit disappointed that it wasn't spicy at all. But loved the taste!
+ Salt and pepper spare ribs with string beans - I think my favorite of the day! Really good, highly recommended!

I definitely will come back if I'm in the bay area again. It's a great restaurant. Good service and has a family feel with overall noise of chatter.
author: Angela K.

description: Pretty pathetic service. Food was OK; the only good item was sliced pork. Waste of calories.
author: Konstantin G.

description:
Came here for a family dinner.  We were a little late so i didn't even get to see the menu or contribute to the dinner, but oh well, sometimes that's how it is with family.  

I think we had a set dinner with the addition of a few vegetable dishes for our vegetarian guest who was with us.  The food was pretty good and very fresh.  However, i was disappointed in the selections ordered.  i don't believe my uncle ordered anything that was truly Hakka-nese, so it feels like it defeated the purpose of coming to this restaurant. 

We did have a crab dish and clay pot dish that were awesome.  Since i did not see the menu, i don't really know what they were called.  The steamed chicken was good, but i would have preferred the salt-baked one.  The food was a little oilier than i like, but not nearly as oily as some Chinese restaurants.

i can only give this place three stars because i didn't get to try a lot of the other dishes offered.  I will definitely be returning here for a more intimate family dinner.
author: Denise L.

description:
This is my new favorite Chinese food joint! I'll admit, the trek from SoMa is a tad far, but well worth the drive. 

I can't really comment on the authenticity of the Hakka dishes, as I'm not certain if what my (Hakka) grandparents prepared were authentically Hakka or not. 

Their hot & sour soup (definitely not Hakka) is flavorful & packed with ingredients. The beef in clay pot, chef's special clams, & mushrooms + veggies were all extremely fresh & nicely prepared. Nothing lacked flavor or overly greasy. 

And a bonus to Chinese restaurants in SF... they speak fluent english & take credit cards!
author: Catherine L.

description:
We had a decent meal here, but nothing I would rave about. I ordered the baked breaded crab and my husband had a pork dish with vegetables and the non-descript sauce with which so many Chinese dishes are served. The crab was tasty and unique, but difficult and messy to eat. 

We had to flag down the waitress to get the steamed rice we ordered and she took her time getting it despite the fact that the restaurant only had a few other customers and our other food had already been served. 

We were unhappy with the service we received at this restaurant and only somewhat satisfied with the food. The floors were dirty, the lace cloth under the glass tabletop was soiled, and there were dried bits of herbs on the crab cracker I was given. 

We will not return.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
"THIS IS SO GOOD"

I kept saying that line over and over again while eating. I don't think I even took breaths or breaks between bites. I just gorged myself on some excellent Hakka cuisine.

Soup: 
Lao Huo Tang (Old Fire House Soup)
Cantonese folks like to make this deep, savory broth from scraps of bone, meats and herbs and render it all day. The broth is a much more flavorful pork version of the broth you get in pho, with mellow Chinese herbs and even red bean. 

Entrees:

Stewed pork belly slices with preserved vegetable and iceberg lettuce. The pork belly was incredible, stewed to almost falling apart, and the flavor from the preserved vegetables infused the pork and sauce completely.

Fried pumpkin with salt duck egg batter. The "HOLY MOLY THIS IS FREAKING DELICIOUS" dish of the evening. If you can imagine the salty goodness from the egg batter paired with the sweetness of the kabocha pumpkin, cut like steak fries and served piping hot....well....I don't need to say any more.

Stir-fried lily bulb with woodear fungus, peppers, cucmber and asparagus. Light and flavorful, with all of the vegetables cooked halfway retaining their freshness and snap.

Half order of the salt baked chicken. This has been talked about thoroughly in other reviews, but what I love about this dish is how simple it seems, but has such difficult components working sublimely and harmoniously. The chicken meat was juicy and tender. The skin was salty/crispy like roast duck skin. The bird used was lean, flavorful and small, reminiscent of wild chicken or yellow feathered chickens. The dipping sauce didn't overpower the flavor of the chicken meat. 

Stir-fried clams with basil. Aromatic and subtle, the sauce is good over steamed rice, and the clams were super plump. I loved that they used serrano chilis as opposed to the more astringent jalapeno to spice it up.

Dessert:

Pumpkin pudding with tapioca pearls. Served warm, with a bright orange glow from the pumpkin, we were stuffed, but couldn't let one drop go to waste. Not overtly sweet, and the tapioca was cooked to perfection.

Total cost: $52 and some change

Takes credit cards. Friday night at 7pm, we didn't have a reservation and were seated immediately. The staff are very friendly and the owner's son was gracious and helpful.

Will be back with family and more friends in tow.
author: May T.

description:
delicious authentic chinese food!

-one of the older female waitresses was the typical non-enthusiastic chinese waitresses, but the other male waiters were great!
author: James M.

description:
Normally I don't really like Chinese food, a lot of the food here was cooked perfectly and I even enjoyed some food that I don't normally like to eat.

Clams are something I am not very fond of, but they have this clam that is stir fried with a sauce and garlic, and it was really good. The honey walnut shrimp here is pretty good too, not because it taste better than other places but because of the freshness of the shrimp and how they cooked it perfectly. The salt and pepper ribs here are also amazing, because it was cooked perfectly, it was hard to chew like other Chinese places.

Now, for the reason why this place did not get a four star. The lettuce wraps were one reason, they are not as good as many other places. Their salt baked chicken was ridiculous scrawny and the portion was small (maybe the chicken was just small.) The soy sauce chow mien was a bit bland. The mapo tofu was NOT spicy at all.

But this place isn't too bad, I don't mind coming back here again.
author: Alicia W.

description: Solid food! The fried pumpkin is exceptional. They even serve the house soup during dinner! Really good Chinese food. I can't get enough of good authentic chinese food. Also had the honey short ribs, very flavorful. The pork belly was fatty and I enjoyed it all, complementing well with the preserved vegetables. The stuffed tofu was good as well. Everything here was pretty good.
author: Arnold W.

description:
Joint:  It's a packed chinese restaurant.  Nothing fancy, nothing special and really loud.  

Food:  OMG!!  I have a new fav place to go!  This may be the new Dragon House.  (I hope the two old ladies who ran Dragon House are enjoying their retirement.)

Service:  Decent but as with all chinese restaurant, you gotta scream at the waiter in cantonese before you can get so much as a napkin.  


Lemme just say, I'm a cantonese chinese girl.  I don't eat that saucy crap from some of those other popular chinese places where only the lemmings go.  I want my noodles in a clear simple broth and I like clean classic traditional flavors that everyone in the family will love for dinner.  All 30+ members came here to celebrate my grandfather's 80th birthday party.  You know how important 80 is!!!  It was a big deal!!!  All the aunts and uncles sprung for the deluxe meal and it was AWESOME.  I can't even remember what we ate because I was too busy eating.  It had been so long since I had food like that.  NOM NOM NOM.  The only reason why this place got 4 instead of 5 stars is the fact that my family has not gone back for a regular meal.  Apparently, my family is SAVING it for big celebrations.  (sigh)  Who's turning 80 next??
author: Marie L.

description: I have only come here for lunch and I get stuffed every time. I find that they are understaffed, but very friendly despite the difficulty in getting their attention for any sort of service. They have a great deal where you order 3 entrees (from a their special menu) and get soup and rice included. I always end up getting a box or 2 or 3 to go due to their generous portions. Their food is cooked to order and made fresh, which may be why service can be a bit slow. Give it a chance but don't expect grade A service - I think the food is worth trying.
author: Jason B.

description:
So THIS is what Hakka Cuisine is supposed to taste like...ahhh so!

I've been making five spice chicken (a traditional Hakka dish) using those packets in the red box that you get at the Asian store for ages. I liked it fine, but tonight I don't think I can ever go back to it. I didn't know what to expect when I walked into here. Hakka food is more "homey" than fancy. This type of food uses a lot of sauces, involves fatty cuts of meat, and incorporates lots of dried oysters (or so I thought, judging from what I've had...and I really don't like dried oysters.)

BUT...this place suited me quite well. It has some serious "wok hay" meaning you can taste the intense flavor that a well oiled, well heated wok can impart to food. Our party included a bunch of Hakka people, and I kept hearing people say, "oh yeah, that is close to what I remember."

Here's a run down of what we had. It's a long list and will make us look like pigs, which we are, but we also had a lot of people. Ok...anyhoo, here goes:

Pineapple Spareribs - a bit crunchy, not fatty, tangy sweet sauce...pretty good rendition.

Beef Ox Tail - tender, good flavor, almost as good as my mom's. 

Chinese Bacon w/Preserved Green - I NEVER touch this stuff. I've had it once in a fast food sort of place where they scoop food into a box; it was nasty. But THIS version was pretty good...despite the fatty cut of meat, I really enjoyed the greens and the whole dish, though I gingerly took very little each time (only reached for it twice). The dish just screams "heart attack!"

House Special Pan Fried Tofu - again, I'm not a fan of stuffed tofu, but I liked this one. It's the silky but firm tofu with a meat center, nicely browned in the pan with a sauce over it.

Salt & Baked Chicken - This is the five spice chicken thing that I mentioned earlier. Light but so flavorful, this chicken is what the Hakka people meant for it to taste like when they invented it. 

Oyster w/Ginger & Scallion - pan fried to a crisp...eat these oysters with some of the copious amounts of scallion that the chef throws into the wok. 

Egg Fu Yong Shrimp - I didn't know Egg Fu Yong was a Hakka tradition. This one was good, but the least of my favorites. 

Satay Chicken Diced w/Eggplant - mmmm, yummy sauce...a bit sweet and kept piping hot in its own clay pot. 

Sauteed Chinese Broccoli w/Rice Wine - a staple in Chinese restaurants....very fresh and stir fried to a crisp.

For those of you watching your carbs, beware! Hakka cuisine is one of those styles of Chinese cooking that makes you fill your rice bowl way too many times. The sauces are just so yummy that you have to have something to absorb all of them.

And yes...we did finish almost all of the food we ordered. Scary but true. Plus two containers of rice. Oh and it was a deal too...$100 for all that food I mentioned. That was enough for nine or ten people.
author: Virg Y.

description: Authentic Chinese food. Not that orange chicken, general tsao chicken, Mongolian beef stuff. Not saying anything is wrong with any of those items but this place is down right yummy-licious authentic Chinese food.
author: Meuy S.

description: I've only had Hakka cuisine in one other location and so cannot declare myself an expert but I do know a bit about food and Hakka Restaurant is a great find and I will return; bring friends and relatives whenever possible.
author: Jay D.

description: Yelp brings me a winner again!  Tasty food, decent service, a warm spot out of the cold after several hours in Golden Gate Park in January.  Excellent!
author: Megan L.

description:
Most Chinese hole in the wall restaurants have a very apathetic waitstaff.  They usually slap down the plates, ignore tea refill requests, and sometimes even hand you the food instead of setting it down on the tables themselves.  As a fellow Chinese, I've grown to accept this.  

Hakka Restaurant surprised me.  In terms of service and food.  The owner who you'll know immediately since he is the cheeriest, most helpful gentlemen there.  He is ABC so he can interpret very well to non-Chinese speakers.  You can tell he has a passion for his restaurant.  He's very diligent at explaining how dishes are prepared and he makes excellent recommondations. Although the past 2 times I went he rec'd the most popular vs his own real preference.  But even so the popular dishes were good all the same.

I've tried several Chef Specials already.  The salt baked chicken we ordered came out a bit dry.  Don't really care to give it a 2nd try.  The braised pork belly w/ preserved greens was very flavorful.  The fatty layers moistened the pork well and added a richness to the sauce.  House clams are prepared with a Thai twist.  It's cooked with thai basil and chili.  It can get spicy after the 5th clam, but the clams itself are fresh and big!  Most other Chinese restaurants offer clams that aren't worth a chew and smell/taste fishy.  These are solid!

I wanted to test out a "mediocre" dish, meaning something that didn't sound special or difficult to make.  So I ordered a very generic sounding pork w/ mushrooms.  They nailed that too!  It was a simple stirfy of sliced pork in a rich gravy sauce with a variety of mushrooms.  I realize they make the sauces here very well... not greasy, doesn't have that corn starch consistency.  And not dousing, over-taking the entire dish.  

Also do try their Chinese broccoli with rice wine.  They said the rice wine offers a sweet note for the otherwise slightly bitter greens.  Well prepared and just cooked to the point wher the stalks are tender and crunchy at the same time.

Great value for your money, especially when they offer complimentary soup and dessert (usually a dessert soup).  Service is attentive and well handled.  A new favorite for me.
author: Chris T.

description: So .. I'm actually pretty impressed with this place. I am not a huge fan of Chinese food... And so I don't eat it as much as probably other San Franciscans do. But yesterday I was actually craving for some so we decided to hit this place up. It was close by and open late. Ordered the pork belly and let me tell you... I do not like Chinese style pork belly.. I have tried it in many restaurants in Chinatown and in sunset and it just doesn't satisfy my taste buds but this time around it was pretty good! We also ordered: salt n pepper fried eggplant w/ fried tofu and also braised green beans with pork. Yum! Both were a win so I was extremely happy. When the bill came it was only $30... Say whaaat huhhhh (problem voice... those of you who don't know problem is a rapper lol). The restaurant is clean, not too shabby but very mom and pops place. What really stood out to me was the fact that they had pics of all their dishes on the wall and in the menu! That really helps especially when you're not familiar with some of their dishes! It made ordering a lot easier. I'll be back... when I am craving Chinese again!
author: Colette P.

description:
My yelp insider tip: Come with a group of people so you can try all the deliciousness at Hakka.

Everything we had (and we had a LOT) was so good, like take one bite and have to stop chewing for a second to say, "o.m.g. this is soooo good" good. Like, "Ssshhh...less talking, more eating" so good. =)

Here's my list of things to try: Stuffed chicken (you have to call ahead to have this made. It's basically cut up pieces of chicken mixed with super good sticky rice topped with perfectly crispy, oh so delectable chicken skin), lamb stew, braised pork, salt and pepper pork chops (so juicy, yet still crispy and not too salty), stir fried pea vines were pretty good, and lobster noodles. 

This goes on my list of places that I absolutely, positively, must go eat at when I go to SF! Thank you Hakka, you make me and my stomach very, very happy. =)

Oh, and another plus, the service is great! Danny helped us; he's awesome.
author: Maple C.

description:
hakka cuisine is different from cantonese cuisine. the hakka people are a unique group of the han people that were originally active in the yellor river area of china and are one of the earliest han settlers in china. hakkas have preserved their cultural heritage, including food, which dates to pre-qin times(2200 years ago).

hakka restaurant is a small, clean restaurant that is designed primarily for  family or large gatherings. only a few small tables present.

sampling:
-lamb with dry bean curd in clay pot(ji jook yang nam bo9.95) very tender falling off the bone lamb,  very greasy with tender fat, with bean curd, lettuce, waterchestnuts. sweet star anise taste. so good but the fat isn't healthy
-braised tofu with mushrooms(hong xiao to fu6.50)large braised tofu with black mushrooms. so so braised tofu just average. nothing special

chinese lessons mandarin

lamb                                                 yang
lion dance                                        wu-shi
to perform lion dance                    shua-shi-zi
to set off firecrackers                     fang-bian-pao

leftovers:
-courteous service, tea given to me while waiting for takeout.
-go for the hakka (chef specialities) items, all others seem average
-many family dinners (wo chai)packages available.
-hakka chicken and other speciality chicken items availabile only during dinner. reason? short shelf life. waiter says unique taste of chicken changes in an hour. not advisable for takeout
-rating 4 stars, hakka cuisine, lamb , others 3 stars.
-most of menu is cantonese/mandarin. hakka is in the chef's speciality.
-food relatively inexpensive.
author: Victor G.

description:
amazing !! this is what Chinese food should taste like  ..its like my mom made me asian dinner .. had a great home cooked taste to it .. delicate and well rounded dishes ... 
we had the pork belly and walnut prawns .. both great .. so was the free soup and dessert of taro tapioca !
author: Micah W.

description:
Forgetting about the ownership change, my family dined here last Saturday evening.  Luckily, we arrived relatively early and snatched the last available table.  After reviewing their ala carte and family dinner menus, we decided to order the three-person family menu ($38.00) and added one dish for the four of us.  Here is the menu:

1) Hakka style chicken (1/2 chicken) - Very similar to the famed Ton Kiang Hakka chicken, served with two separate dipping sauces, one sesame oil based and the other a ginger and oil based one.  The chicken was perfectly cooked to a melt-in-mouth texture; there was no blood from uneven cooking nor any bone scraps, evidence of the chef's chopping skills.  The star of the show.
2) House Soup - Watercress soup served in a small crock.  Tasty and not too salty.
3) Stir fried Pork stomach with green onion and ginger - My father was the only one who enjoys this dish type (organs).  
4) Pork Belly with Sweet Mustard greens - Succulent pieces of pork belly on a bed of sweet mustard greens and lettuce; a mix of fatty and lean pieces.
5) Mixed Mushrooms and Beef - Stir fried fresh button and straw mushrooms with sliced flank steak pieces.
6) Stir Fried Vegetables - Bok Choy stir fried with ginger; was undercooked so requested kitchen to cook a little longer.
7) Beef Stew and Radish Clay Pot (added dish) - A mixture of some tendon pieces and mostly beef stew chunks in a bubbling brown gravy.
8) Sweet Soup - A bright orange house dessert soup.  Couldn't make out the ingredients of this one.

Overall, it was a plentiful and decent meal.  The food quality aside from the chicken is average as were the portions.  If you're in the neighborhood, it's worth a stop.
author: Mike C.

description:
Not my favorite, but fresh and interesting.  We went to Hakka Restaurant after hearing that it was the "Best Chinese in SF."  Hakka cuisine, however, is so far from the types of Chinese food you usually get in America, that I left with my craving still intact.
We were served a complimentary bowl of melon soup.  A flavorful, light pork broth with hunks of sweet melon.  The melon had absorbed the salty pork flavor, and dissolved in sweet strangeness in my mouth.
Next, the famous Pumpkin with Salted Egg Yolk ($7.50).  Strips of pumpkin tempura dotted with what tasted mysteriously like, and looked similar to, the mix that comes in Kraft Macaroni and Cheese. While immediately revolting, there was something strangely satisfying about their saltiness, paired with the crunch of sweet pumpkin.
The Chinese Broccoli in rice wine ($6.95) was pretty standard: crunchy, stem-heavy, chinese broccoli in a thin marinade.  I could actually taste the rice wine, a nice break from the standard garlic on most chinese veggies, and yet, at the end of the day I would have preferred oyster sauce.
My favorite of our dishes was the Fish in House Special Sauce ($8.95).  Spicy, strong sauce over herbs, celery (wha?) and tender fish.
Lastly, the Half Salt Baked Chicken was moist, tender and flavorful, but nothing to write home about.
As an asian alternative, Hakka Restaurant is a good place to try.  If I'm in the mood for Chinese, however, I'll head to Ton Kiang.
author: Laura S.

description:
3rd time here and again a great meal.  Ordered: salted egg pumpkin, chinese bacon, salt baked chicken, short rib with pepper, seafood tofu claypot, snow pea leaves in garlic, fried rice salted fish chicken.  

Service was also very good.  Super reasonable prices for the volume and quality of food you get.

A bit out of the way but this is my new favorite chinese restaurant.
author: Mario S.

description: I never write a negative review but I think I should at least let people know what to expect.  My mom reserves 3 tables for my Dad's bday.  Each table fit about 9 people very tightly with no room to move.  The place is small so not really good to accommodate a large party but since it was near my parents house they wanted to go there.  We were served on plastic plates that were square so it didn't work very well on the lazy susan.  We also had to eat off plastic too.  They ordered from the set menu which I didn't think was very good.  The food was either overly salty or bland and greasy.  The fish and the lobster were under cooked.  I cook lobster better and I'm a horrible cook! Not what I would expect from a set menu that cost $368 a table.  We then ordered a couple of vegetable dishes for each table that was about $7 each.  Only 1 person of the 3 tables ordered 1 beer.  Check came with tip on it almost $500 per table!  I was flabbergasted!  The service was slow, we were seated at 7:30 and since it was a set menu my mom ordered ahead of time, there should not have been a wait!  The food didn't come until 8:30 and we didn't leave until 10!   I don't mind paying for good food and service, but for a place that was like a hole in the wall and smelled of it, I don't expect to pay prices like this.
author: Marilyn W.

description:
I'm not sure exactly how "Hakka" this place actually is, as far as authenticity goes. I've eaten here quite a few times, both dine-in and take-out and the food is for the most part fairly consistent. 

My favorite dishes here:

Frog with salted egg yolk.

Shrimp with salted egg yolk (not on menu, but ask for it!).

Stuffed chicken with sticky rice (best in town?).

Pork belly with preserved mustard greens.

Lamb & bean curd clay pot.

Pumpkin soup.

The whole thing with various dishes using the preserved/salted egg yolks in the manner in which they do is actually pretty innovative as far as I'm concerned. And they pull it off pretty darn well. Also, there are many other "house specials" with nice pictures on the walls. 

Ambience = LOUD.

Parking = Good Luck!

Make an early reservation. Definitely worth trying at least once if you haven't already done so!
author: J C.

description:
came here for dinner with family.  mom recently came here with her friend and liked it, so of course, we all have to go to make sure it's something we can put on the list of places the fam can go.

prices of all the dishes were so reasonable! the food was delishes.  
Dishes to get: 
- pork belly with preserved veggies... really good to eat with rice.  and who says NO to pork belly?
- black bean clams - fatty clams! 
- salted egg frog legs 

those are just my favorites, but you have a huge selection on the menu and with the prices being so reasonable, you can't loose!
author: Kelly H.

description:
I tried this place with my mom yesterday. I didn't get a chance to try a full spread of their dishes since there were only two of us, but what we did try was pretty good. We ordered the quail braised in a clay pot with mushroom and fungus, which was not as big a portion as pictured (which was good for us), but was very delicious. The quail was moist and the fungus was almost buttery tasting to me. It cost $18, which is a bit on the pricey side to me. We also ordered a veggie dish, which included (more) fungus, snap peas, cucumbers, and lily bulb petals. This dish was refreshing and light, yet not at all bland in taste. 

Also, our meal came with soup (yesterday it was melon+pork bone), and dessert (we had papaya and white fungus dessert soup), both of which were so delicious. So much fungus in everything we ordered! But it's ok, because my mom says the dark fungus is good for lowering cholesterol and the white fungus is good for your skin. 

Overall, a nice little find in the Outer Richmond. A tad pricey for a Chinese restaurant, but the food is good and you get good soup and dessert with it. Great for groups.
author: Jessie C.

description: We received the worst service here today. One of our orders was not delivered and they still attempted to charge us for it. Service otherwise was very poor and the waiters were rude. They refused to use multiple cards to pay for the meal until we insisted upon it multiple times.
author: Greg R.

description:
I'm not a food trendee, so I don't run into someplace right after it opens as I want to give the owners and staff time to get it together. When I read Patricia Untermann's review of this place, I had to visit.
Wow-am I glad I did, I just wish that I'd come with more people as there were so many dishes I wanted to try and two people, albeit big eaters, us, could only hold so much. Towards 2PM on a Tuesday we parked and walked in, only to find ourselves almost the only folks there. A waitress brought over menus and then tea but by then we were deep into menu analysis.
What a great menu. Truly wonderful food...Chinese Bacon w/ preserved greens, Clams, Pumpkin w/ salted egg, deep fried oysters, congee w/ frog.....oh my gosh, this is the real deal, this place.
I first had Hakka food in Singapore, and from then was smitten with the suble, delicate flavors, the richness of ingredients, the time this kind of cuisine takes. 
This is quite an amazing restaurant. In talking with our waitress, Bonnie, she told us that some days the place is packed for lunch, others not so, and dinner was picking up clientel. No wonder, given the high degree of preparation and execution the food shows. Did I mention the Beef w/ Black Bean Fried Rice in XO Sauce? Holy moly!

Chinese cuisine is wonderful, and IMO Hakka is the sweetest flowering, and Hakka Restaurant is a very welcome addition to our dining landscape. Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: A nice place to have any meal, however you need to come in during non conventional times like in between lunch or dinner because sitting is very limited and it gets crowded fast. Lucky for us, we had came in after three teams of basketball players where leaving which gave us some available seats. All the dishes where pretty tasty and hot. It was served fast, and plentiful. However, I wouldn't recommend the short ribs because it was like eating a set of bones attach with rubber bands. The taste was lacking because it was too fatty and difficult to eat. As for the fish (black bass), sticky rice, and salted crab, they where all delicious along with some other dishes. The parking situation was very challenging, however the restaurant is on the corner of the block making it easy for you to find. Overall the service was very good because we where only one of two dining parties in the restaurant.
author: Kurt C.

description: Not all that. Ok, we had the kow yook (pork belly) which was delicious-nicely fatty, melt in your mouth heart guilty goodness, piquant preserved veggies over a bed of lettuce. That's probably the best dish of the night. Also had the pumpkin with salted egg which was okay but not all that exciting. Crispy, salty Hom don batter juxtaposed with the sweetness of pumpkin.  Also had the dry fried clams in black beans, garlic & spicy peppers which really was disappointing. The taste was not quite there. Rather flat and a  one note flavor - just salty, and I love salty black beans!!!). There should have been more green onions or other sweetness to balance. We also had the no mai fried in skin whole chicken which was also just okay and actually rather disappointing for the lack of other interesting flavors and super hefty price tag (over $30).  It was missing some good Cha siu, black mushrooms and dried shrimp in enough amounts to be flavorful. The pan fried tofu was good, saucy, pork filled simmering in gravy flavor. The greens with preserved egg was over cooked, mushy, and the egg was rubbery. So sad! Honey walnut shrimp, while succulent, was heavy handed w the mayo sauce and nothing to write home about. If you're in the City I suppose, but not worth a trip across the bridge. All in all, ok but disappointed after reading all the raving reviews.
author: Alittle G.

description:
A small hole in the wall type Chinese restaurant nestled with no major advertising in a neighborhood you'd never expect... the only sign it would be better would be if the waiter was rude! (Which he wasn't)

This time, we actually ordered some Hakkanese food.  I don't know much about Hakkanese cuisine, though I know that I had quite a few dishes that I've never had before, including the fried pumpkin with salted egg.  

What you have here is a restaurant with great prices, great portions and uncharacteristically good service.  Simply put, every dish we ordered (it was a family gathering) treated me well.  I will almost certainly come back here if I'm in the area, and you should too.  That said, the biggest downside is the severe difficulty in finding parking, though that's hardly their fault...
author: John L.

description:
Looked for Taishen and it was apparently replaced by Hakka.  Decided to give it a try and it was great.  Full house and had alittle mix up on seating but service was good and food great.  Pumpkin Salt Egg was a nice surprise.  Had 2 clay pots and were really good.

Came back a week later and the food was execellent!
author: Ray Y.

description: Really like it love the salted yellow yolk on anything it's salty so mix it with something else or share it
author: Dylan S.

description:
great food, different type of cuisine than you would normally get at most chinese restaurants. location isnt the greatest since its in a residential area so parking really sucks. most tables are meant for bigger parties so its recommended to have a party of around 8-10 and make a reservation. its better that way anyways so that you can order more dishes and get to taste different things.

the frog leg and squash is definitely an item to try. the pork belly is nicely made. you cant go wrong with any of their chicken or clam dishes either.

the price is also very good!
author: Alex H.

description: Delicious Chinese food! This place gets packed quick so come early. The line was out the door at 6:30PM. There are pictures of the different dishes on the wall if you like a visual description when ordering. Ordering off the set menu gives you bang for your buck and a good taste of the various dishes. We went with the set menu for 6; ~$100. My favorite dishes were the pork belly and hakka chicken! Everything else was pretty good but I will probably order off the regular menu to get a taste of the other dishes.
author: Donna W.

description:
Came here with my grandmother and parents for dinner. My parents had heard about this place in the newspaper and we wanted to check them out for their grand opening (at least that's what was advertised)

The restaurant is in a fairly quiet area and and it unusual to find one on the corner of 45th and Cabrillo...We walked in and to our surprise there was a full house.

My first observation was their inefficiency, but this is to assume that they're new and is still figuring out their process. All the servers were running around frantic...getting in each others way. Service was not to par, but they're trying and that goes a long way.

The layout was flawed. There were small tables in the corner blocked by 2 large tables. So when the two large tables were occupied , it was nearly impossible to get through to the small table since the walkway was blocked by a person in their chair. The only way was to either ask the person to get up or force your way through. Can you imagine how annoying that is if you're that person blocking the aisle?

We ordered the usual safe dishes (my family aren't the experimental types). I heard about the fried pumpkin outside and wanted to order it, but the majority ruled it out -_-.

Our server was friendly, we wanted to order soup, but he mutters to us that soup will be provided so you could save money by choosing something else on the menu. A point for his honesty (or was it his ploy to earn more tips?) 

The food was ok.  It wasn't bad at all. My father told me that if they can cook noodles well, then it's a good indication that the chef has skills. (Background: He use to be the chef of his own restaurant) I enjoyed the soy sauce noodles. It was crispy, evenly stir-fried to perfection.

The prices are around $8-15+ with most dishes averaging $9. Portions are enough, an order of broccoli beef will be decent for a party of 4.

Another point goes to their dessert. They didn't opt to do the typical Chinese restaurant/Red bean/Green bean/Taro...but offered us sweet pumpkin dessert. Unfortunately, I didn't really like it and it seemed like they added yellow 5 food coloring.

Overall, a surprise to find another decent restaurant out in the outer richmond. No complaints. I would probably go back and try the fried pumpkin (it's what they're known for). Hopefully by then, they would have a solid process.
author: Jason N.

description:
This place is way out in the middle of nowhere a.k.a. outer richmond. So if you're thinking is it really worth leaving my neighborhood for this place? My answer is yes. Great comfort food at affordable prices. 
Pork belly melts in your mouth not in your hands. Deep fried pumpkin was a delightful surprise. The waiter that served us was beyond nice.
author: Sophia C.

description:
bad service, they seated returned customers first even we were waiting for long time, and waiters very rude.

food: high expectation after read good reviews, but its below average.
author: John W.

description:
Came here for a lunch on a Wednesday and only saw Chinese clientele -- a great sign! Mostly Cantonese style food, with maybe 10 chef's specialty Hakka-style dishes. We ordered the tofu with meat stuffed inside (yong tau foo). My family thought it was pretty poor for Hakka food, especially since we had grown accustomed to eating Hakka style dishes in Singapore.

The waiter gave us free soup, and it was delicious! Other dishes were yummy, but I would like to see more ethnic Hakka food. Of course it's always difficult -- restaurants need to cater to the general taste to bring in the business!

I'm still going to back Singapore for some decent Hakka dishes.
author: Eric C.

description:
Nine of us came here tonight to eat for my grandmother's birthday and Mother's Day. Our ohana used to be regulars here when it was Heavenly Ocean, a place we loved to eat at.
However, I wouldn't come back here. The food was pretty good but portions small and the meat dishes salty. One server asked my husband to move over as there was supposed to an aisle from the wall of square tables for four ppl past our big round one. With the way the tables were laid out, uh hello? With one 2-4 seater crammed in the corner behind us? He could have threw in a please. I didn't like how he asked my husband.
We weren't even offered water, our server didn't even check up on us, and we had to ask about our last dish! We had finished up all the other six and the salt and pepper, fried porkchops didn't come.
In addition, my grandmother remembered one woman and told her and the woman just gave her a blank stare. Whoever took down my dad's reservation didn't even get his last name right nor the number of ppl. No one even said good-bye to us nor thanked us for coming. The customer service is lacking in this restaurant. No personality.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
Went here based on Yelp reviews, and they were dead on.

Food was great, the fried pumpkin was tasty but a little too greasy and soggy for my liking. Mongolian beef was perfect, great flavor and the beef was well cooked. Walnut Prawns were awesome, zero complaints.

Only downside was the slightly slow service, but the staff did their best considering the large numbers of big parties in the restaurant.

On a side note, my water glass smelled like rotten milk...no big deal, just drink the tea, hot water kills bacteria!

Will definitely be eating here again.
author: Joe S.

description:
One of my favorites in the city.  Delicious and not expensive (party of six and total bill was $63 including comlimentary soup and fruit for dessert). 

We had -

Baked fish and tofu in claypot
Pumpkin strips in egg yolk
Seafood with noodles
Baked tofu
Spareribs...

Lots of delicious food.  We had a reservation for 6 and they started to seat our party as soon as the first person arrived.  The staff was brisk but nice and efficient.
author: Kelly H.

description: Prices are a bit higher than at other type of Chinese restaurants.  Half chicken @ $11.95 they forgot to bring us the order.  Had to tell them about it, chicken was hard and not that tasty especially for the price.  No apology just said should've ordered a different chicken dish.  Other dishes (noodles and veg.) were okay nothing exceptional, however. Restaurant was quite busy so apparently could care less about if one will be a repeat customer.
author: Luisa T.

description:
Dropped by here for lunch yesterday for a rice clay pot dish not knowing that the Taishan Cafe had closed.  Didn't  and still don't know much about Hakka food, but we were hungry and decided to give it a try anyway.
