From the look of the menu, they still serve mainly Cantonese food with some Hakka dishes mixed in.  Interestingly. one of our waiters was an ABC but spoke both Cantonese and English well and the other was a native Mandarin speaker who spoke Cantonese and English.not as well. 

I was in the mood for jook, so ordered a bowl of pei don gee yuk (preserved duck egg/pork)  jook and the GF ordered the hom yue gee yuk  (dried salted fish/pork) claypot.  Both were pretty good. 

The consistency of the jook was just right (not too thick or runny) and they used lots of pei don and pork.  I was expecting a small portion of shredded pork, but they used big chunks of tender pork instead.  Very nice.  Unfortunately, they don't make yow til (fried bread) to go w/the jook, but that's a minor matter.   Still trying to find another go-to place for jook since the Happy Dragon on Balboa (that IMHO made the BEST  jook) closed.   Hakka's jook didn't come in a clay pot (like it use to be served at Happy Dragon) but it was pipping hot (in fact all of the food was served pipping hot) and was right up there in taste w/Happy Dragon's.  Guess I'll just have to bring my own yow til with me if I want to get my jook-fix in the future.  

The hom yue/gee yuk clay pot was also served pipping hot filled with minced pieces of salted fish and pork mixed in with soft tofu in an delicious gravy.  The tofu was unexpected, but then we were thinking about Taishan's claypot, which is lined w/rice on the bottom, and not the traditional Cantonese style claypot with rice on the side was very good nonetheless, even though my GF missed the "fon jew" (the crispy rice at the bottom of the pot). So, we have to find another place for that too.

We were still hungry and decided to try to order some "real" Hakka dishes.  The waiter recommended the fried pumpkin and hom don (salted egg) dish and the "special" Hakka clam dish.  

The pumpkin dish was ok, but we really couldn't taste the hom don.  The pumpkin is cut into small pieces and then fried.  The hom dom is supposed to be in the coating which I assume was flour or cornstarch w/hom don mixed in, but we just couldn't taste it.  The fried pumpkin was still pretty good and tasted more like yams than pumpkin.  It was a good veggie addition to the meal.  

The clam dish was stellar.  The sauce was made w/basil and red pepper (not too much) and they used large clams (not the small manila clams).  It was GREAT!  It's on the list of Chef's Specials.

We wanted to try some other Hakka dishes, but they were not available for lunch.  So, if you want more of a selection try to drop in for dinner instead.  The Taishan Cafe was good, but I think the Hakka Restuarant that has replaced it is even better.  The room is still filled with large banquet tables and there are only a few tables for couples or parties of 4.  So, you may have to wait for a table unless they're willing to use one of the banquet tables as a "community" table for smaller parties.
author: Martin C.

description:
oh my gooodness!!!!  the food here is DELICIOUS!  i went here for dinner with a bunch of people and we were all very pleased with all the food we ordered.  we met the owners and they were super nice  =)
I definitely would recommend this place to anyone!
author: Angelica Y.

description:
Hakka is a truly outstanding Chinese restaurant.

Hakka is now occupying the space where Taishan Cafe was up until the beginning of this year. I first started going to Hakka several months ago, not long after they hung their yellow Grand Opening sign, which still flies proudly in the front. It's definitely far off the beaten path, as it's in the far Outer Richmond....but well worth the trip.

As much as I love Chinese food, there's only a few dishes I try regularly. Kung Pao chicken, Mongolian beef and General's (often Cho's) chicken are my so-called test dishes to see if a Chinese restaurant is worth patronizing.  Let me put it to you this way: I ate Hakka's Mongolian beef at least twice a week for the better part of my first month going there, it was THAT good. And only $5.40 for a huge plate of it over rice? Wow! With that quality, great portion size and low price, you've got me as a loyal customer for life!

Recently I've become a huge fan of their Salt & Pepper spare ribs over rice. Again, the amazingly unexpected spicy flavor got me hooked. More basic dishes like Kung Pao chicken are also tasty, but since I'm starting to branch out slowly into Hakka's more traditional regional fare I've been more and more impressed by them.

The staff has always been very kind & courteous, if at times overwhelmed by the sheer numbers of people that come in at lunch or dinner time. In fact when I come in these days, they smile at me and ask, "Mongolian beef?" :) I'd definitely recommend calling ahead for pickup, especially if you're just getting takeout during lunchtime. At dinner time Hakka is often filled with large groups of Chinese families who apparently already know what some of us are barely discovering: that Hakka Restaurant is an amazing place to eat.
author: Patricia M.

description: Haven't been here since I was little, but now having re-visit it, I must make more of an effort to come here more often. Their pork belly with preserved vegetables and their salt pepper crab are must haves. The pork belly melts in your mouth and the preserved vegetables give it the crunch factor that compliments the pork belly very well. If you've never had their food, you must go and if you've had their food then you know you must come again. In addition to good food, they also have an awesome wait staff. Our waters were always refilled before they were emptied and our wait staff checked in on us throughout the meal to ensure everything was alright. This is definitely on my list of favorite places to eat.
author: Rosanna N.

description: Just three blocks  away from my house, we decided to drop by and this place does not disappoint if you're looking for great chinese food. Huge portions! The pork belly and salt and pepper spare ribs were my fave. This place is super authentic.
author: Kelly C.

description: Why are all the Chinese restaurants in this area so bad? The food was terribly bland and a little funky. Huge portions though. Decent service. Their lunch specials are minimal. The only thing worse is they hygiene score. Definitely would not go again.
author: Pierre C.

description:
They had me at the soup.

Go there for the exceptional (complimentary!) soup, stay for the good food and great, friendly service.
author: S. T.

description:
This place is great. Authentic and a change-of-pace from the many many Hong Kong style Chinese restaurants SF has. 

Ask about the pre-order specials if you have a big group. These are the dishes that have to be ordered in advance because they are not on the menu.
author: R K.

description:
5 Stars!!  Since this restaurant opened earlier this year, I have been here to try a variety of dishes, visiting individually as well as with groups.

So far, these are a sample of the variety of dishes that I have had here at Hakka Restaurant:

- Pumpkin Strips [slices of kabocha pumpkin squash with a crunchy egg coating]
- Salt Baked Chicken
- Chinese Broccoli in Rice Wine
- Deep Fried Oysters
- House Special Pan Fried Stuffed Tofu
- Special Salt & Pepper Spareribs
- Sauteed Lily Bulbs & Fungus with Green/Red Bell Peppers
- House Special Clams w/Basil
- Braised Beef Stew & Turnips in Clay Pot
- Bean Curd Spareribs in Clay Pot
- Ma Po Tofu
- Chinese Bacon w/Preserved Greens
- Preserved Egg & Pork Congee

I very much appreciate:

- That no MSG is used if requested.

- Every dish is skilfully prepared and cooked just right, utilizing the freshest ingredients, which combine to result in the individual flavor and texture of each item in any dish to be enjoyed.  Seasoning is minimal (only that which is needed), and heavy sauces are generally not used, which tend to mask the true taste of the ingredients.

They can accommodate minor adjustments to their dishes if you have a certain preference.

- A generous selection of dishes.  Just about every category is offered, including congee (great for a hot and filling meal) as well as rice plates at only $4.95, a great value. 

- The "3-for-$19.95" specials are comprised of a large selection of the same high quality.  Note that this special is available for take-out and dine-in Lunch only.

- A variety of set Family Dinners are available, which offer more great values.

(Please view the various menus that I have uploaded for details)

While dining in, my experience has been enhanced in that the staff unobtrusively checks often to see if we need anything, and intuitively refill our teapot, replace bowls/plates without even having to signal our needs to anyone.

- Look for Danny or Raymond.  They provide the very best service,  especially in describing the ingredients of a dish, it's preparation, answering any questions, making recommendations and occasionally translating between Chinese and English. 

Enthusiastic comments are usually overheard amongst fellow diners offering a variety of the most positive comments about the food as well as the service.

As a result, I continue to recommend this restaurant to friends, family and many others.

Oh a few reminders.  A few items, such as Salt-Baked Chicken,  require extended time in preparation and cooking, so Advance ordering/pre-ordering is required.  Also, reservations are a sure way to avoid having to wait for a table, as this restaurant can get really busy during peak days and/or hours.

Give this place a try.  An enlightening adventure in experiencing authentic Hakka cuisine, thanks to Chef Li and staff.

For larger format views of the menus, go to 

http://www.urbanspoon.com/r/6/1517358/restaurant/Richmond/Hakka-Restaurant-San-Francisco
author: David J.

description: Having come from Hakka roots, this is the ultimate place for my kind of comfort food. The braised pork belly is amazing. Probably the best I've had in the bay area. Restaurant is often crowded with large families and noise level is almost unbearable. Anyway, you shouldn't be too concerned about that because you come here to eat, not to conversate.
author: Eric L.

description:
Too salty and oily for me, service was a little slow.  Granted it was tasty at first, but the oil and salt catch up to you.  We left the leftovers on the table.

Tsing Tao on Clement is better. We've been ordering from there for years and thought we'd try something new.  

Oh well.
author: David S.

description: 5 stars for food and service.  Prices are very affordable.  I absolutely love eating here. nuff said now go get you some.
author: Asana T.

description:
I ran across the restaurant by accident. I was looking for parking, which goes to show how serendipity can be such a good thing. Many of the dishes are things that I remember eating growing up since there's a large Hakka population in Taiwan, and therefore the cuisine is prevalent on the island.

The parking in the area is good, it's a bit out of the way, so, if you want a place to walk around afterwards, you may want to drive back Eastwards a bit.

The restaurant is decorated like a standard Chinese restaurant. Nothing fancy, but clean and bright. The waitstaff is above average in politeness for a Chinese restaurant, and very efficient.

Now, let's get to the real reason, well, the only reason you'd come here. It's all about the food. The bottom line? Superb. There's little to compare them with in the city, but, that's in their favor. 

Let's start with the much-yelped-about salt baked chicken. We ordered it ahead of time, based on the reviews, which was a very good suggestion. It came with everything else. Also, since we were only two, they suggested getting a half chicken. Good call, since at a restaurant like this, you want to try as many things as possible, and not fill up on one thing. Overall, it was good. However, didn't turn out to be my favorite, and didn't quite live up to my expectations. A table nearby had the steamed chicken, which is also a hakka favorite. Note to self to get that next time.

Chinese Bacon w/Preserved Greens - perfect! A word of warning, you cannot be afraid of pork fat. It is about the most unhealthy thing to eat. However, my relatives eat fatty pork all the time, and I have a theory that as long as you aren't eating a lot, and are eating a lot of veggies, all is good. Well, that is what I tell myself. Which brings me to some veggies.

Chinese Broccoli in rice wine - perfect! Usually you get it with oyster sauce in many restaurants. However, that's usually goopy and too sweet. The rice wine infuses it with a more subtle flavor. It comes cooked bright green, and delicious.

Fried pumpkin with salt duck egg batter - this seemed to steal the show. It's all deep fried, but remarkably not greasy, and the salt-duck egg is sprinkled about. Very nice.

Then there was a shrimp and squid dish that was good. Can't remember the specifics other than the squid was so tender. Amazing.

Soup is complimentary (we could have loaded up on the soup alone).  Savory broth with bean. (which isn't common at most chinese restaurants in the city) We were sad when they took away the bowl to make room for the food. Noooo. :-)

Didn't get dessert since as you can read above, we were stuffed.

it's definitely the kind of place you want to bring a big group. Beer and Wine license application done. You can BYOB. 

Food is a window into a culture. In many ways, Chinese food ends up being a reflection of where it is at. Chinese food in New York is different than Chinese food in California is different than Chinese food in Sweden is different than Chinese food in India. Those adaptations are beautiful despite being "inauthentic" simply because they too have a history behind them. However, it's also nice to find the food that is as it is in the place of origin (or close, since my Grandfather complains that American chickens don't taste the same as Chinese chickens), and Hakka Restaurant is an excellent window into a place half a world away.
author: Boris C.

description:
Full disclosure, I don't want you to like this place as I hate waiting outside in the foggy Richmond District while watching you or others like you eat a delicious warm Chinese meal. So don't eat here. Promise me. 

But I do have give props to Hakka Restaurant. I found out I am part Hakka in my twenties. Hakka people are the Chinese version of Gypsies, always being driven from place to place, with hardly a region in China to truly call home. And so it might have been why they've learned to make dishes out of some of the least favored ingredients. And I'd say they've perfected the art of cooking these otherwise unpalatable things. Pork belly and preserved vegetables. To die for!

Hakka Restaurant is described by many of my Chinese and non-Chinese friends as the best Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. I agree! The servers are nice, the restaurant seems clean, and the dishes are marvelous. Avoid the typical Chinese-American fare. Bring a friend who can read Chinese so they can order from the wall. That's where they advertise the good stuff. And I highly recommend the chicken stuffed with preserved veggies...but you have to call a day ahead to order it. The fish dishes are awesome. 

But don't eat here. Don't make me wait in line.
author: Jason J.

description:
My girlfriend and I have been eating here a few times and liked it very much. I am a Hakka-nese so I think I'm some what qualified to say that it's not completely authentic but close. Authenticity aside, when it comes to taste, trust the professionals. 

Tonight we brought 6 seniors relatives along, including 2 line cooks with 30 years of experiences combined and a 40 years experienced home-chef!

Ordered 8 courses:

- Fried crab with pumpkin and salted duck egg yolk. Everyone dug in with both hands. The best in the Bay Area. The crab is a bit small, less than 2 pounds. So they comp it with extra pumpkin strips. Loved it!
- House special steamed chicken. Served as an cold app with 2 sauces. All chefs thought it's great. Nit picking: they used food coloring on the skin.
- Honey BBQ short ribs. Super tender and very rich in the unique favor of a super hot work (wok-hey).
- Chinese bacon with preserved green. Different than the Northern Chinese style. Less fatty and less salty. 
- House special pan fried tofu. The last time was better but still not bad.
- House special clams. Essentially, wet fried clams in basil and garlic sauce. Great basil taste! Perfect to go down with white rice. 
- Cat fish in clay pot. Nice texture with sweet sauce. Lots of scallions.
- Sauteed Chinese broccoli with rice wine. Last but not lease!


Comments from our guest:

Cook A ...
- Short ribs. His wife just can't make it in such quality.
- Tofu. A hint of dried fish in the mix of the meat but not to his taste.
Conclusion: Overall, he enjoyed it very much.

Cook B...
- Bacon with preserved green. Different than the usual and he thought the preserved green is very tasty.
- Cat fish. He couldn't stop eating the scallions.

Home-chef...
- Pumpkin. She wanted more and more of it.
- The comp soup. Unique and not lacking of ingredients like other house soup.
- Tofu. I'm sure she can make it better.

The girlfriend...
- Cat fish. Never had cat fish clay pot as good.

EVERYONE...
- The crab is GREAT! Hands down!
- The chicken dish is something you can hardly find in the Bay Area.


In Chinese, it's considered to be impolite to criticize the dishes when you're not the one who's paying the bill. At the end of the meal tonight, everyone was trying to pick their least favorite. That's because we all thought everything was great and we need to "give face" to the home-chef by saying that she can make a better tofu dish at home ;)
author: Rio T.

description: Absolutely delicious...this restaurant is the place for comfort, home-style cooking. The head chef personally made recommendations and boy, so glad we followed his advice! The pineapple spareribs are very flavorful and rich. The egg yolk baked crab was unique and delicious! You can't go wrong with dinner here!
author: Karen L.

description: Not a fan of the food. wont be going back. way out in the sunset. its far from everything.
author: Cindy L.

description:
My friends took me to Hakka recently - I was excited to try authentic Hakka cuisine. Unfortunately, my search will continue because this place did not satisfy. 

We ordered the salt baked chicken, pumpkin strips, and a few other dishes...Question: why do so many SF Chinese restaurants go heavy on the salt and oil and portions at the expense of flavor and authenticity? And why do people think this is an attractive thing? 

Doesn't help that as we were walking to the place, I saw the chef smoking on the greasy sidewalk, with the kitchen door propped open (boxes of food visible on the kitchen floor) and then saw him cooking our food a few minutes later. I love a good hole in the wall and can handle questionable hygiene but the look of this place's kitchen and building, the so-so food, and the line of cars and aggressive customers waiting outside to pick up orders are all good reasons not to return. San Franciscans, look around for better options where the food is the main attraction, and the environment is cleaner.
author: Lily L.

description:
I decided to have a 'kau yuk' t(Chinese Bacon) tasting contest for father's day since it's dad's favorite bad for you type of food. So, we got Hakka's famous kau yuk and pitted it against 2 other competitors kau yuk (Jumbo's & 8 Immortals - all in SF).

We marked all these 1,2 & 3 - had over 12 of us all tasted it. Over all we had 8 votes for #1, 3 for #2, and only 1 for #3. Although everyone agreed that #1 (Hakka's) was best in texture - it was extra fatty, flavors were mild, but not enough mu choy, and the price was the highest of the 3 - hence the 3 star only. 

#2 was Jumbo, for the price, it wasn't bad at all. Flavors in the 8 Immortal one was too strong for all of us - over powered the meat itself. Both were leaner so not as 'melt in your mouth' texture needed for this dish. 

It was just a fun event to do for Father's Day :) Had a fun time doing it, but can only do this once a year...this stuff will kill yah if you eat too much of it - but I would recommend it. It's just never as good as my aunt makes it....wish I learned how to make it from her...
author: Min Min S.

description:
Let me start off and say this place is crazy busy. If you're a large party and don't have reservations, please don't come here. My party was for 10 people. They plan for the exact time and hope you're all there when you're going to be seated. While waiting for the table watching people walk around it was like this place was chaos. Now for the review.

I had a family dinner here last Friday. We had made reservations which helped. We were seated by the door. That wasn't too bad even though it was a cooler day. We practically had to flag down the waiter to take our order. We tried to flag down any waiter to check on our order and that was pretty much impossible. One of the waiters was pretty nice and brought us stuff after he set down the food. We ordered the $168 set menu and added a couple of dishes. When we were waiting for our food, we asked about one of the add on dishes. We never got an answer and finally when we did it came. It seemed like those that ordered off the menu instead of a set menu got their food faster. 

Overall the food at times seemed like it would be a couple of dishes and then all of them at once. The food was OK in my opinion. Nothing special. After we finally finished dinner we told the waiter that the one dish was kind of bad. It looked good, but the vegetable wasn't that great. The waiter explained if we told them earlier they would remake the dish. At that point we were ready to pay the bill and leave. 

You wouldn't think this restaurant had a upstairs, but it does. The crowd died down after about 8.00pm. There seems to be this rush to eat at a certain time and then it's empty and silent at about 9.00pm. This place isn't in an area with a lot of restaurants and if you didn't know it was here you probably wouldn't go here. 

Would I come here again? Probably not.
author: Jen C.

description:
Chinese restaurants tend to be inconsistent when service and quality of food is considered. Usually, the reason is because of over-worked waiting staff and under-appreciated cooks. For this reason, I prefer to avoid rating Chinese restaurants, but this one was deserving some good praise from unexpected surprises.

One big thing that stood out is the service. Under the usual Chinese restaurant norm, you get the basic service of refilling tea pots, clearing plates and ordering food. I think this place took an extra step by taking the initiative to make sure everything is okay, conversing with you and making sure everything that needs to be filled is filled. Now it could be the fact that we were there earlier than the main dinner crowd, so they had time, but these guys are friendly regardless.

The food itself was well made. We got the Yong Tau Foo (Something tofu...), Ginger and Onion Crab, Muy Choi Kao Yok (Braised Pork?), Garlic Stir-fried Kailan and some sort of Spicy Eggplant. The pork is something I would recommend! My mom makes it a certain way where the pork is diced, but the way they did it was sliced. All I can say is try it! 

Again, low rating because it might not say great for long. The food is great, but that's only if the cooks are consistently working there and not planning to switch jobs. I would still recommend you to give it a shot especially the Muy Choi Kao Yok.
author: Jeremy L.

description: One of the best authentic Chinese foods in the city.  I say that because some Chinese restaurants serve up a pile of grease and call it dinner.  Always packed with large tables and families hungrily chowing down.  A must try when in the Richmond district.  My favorite is the salted egg pumpkin dish - YUM.
author: S. D.

description:
Been to this place several times with friends and family.  Can't go wrong -- just order the specials which are posted, with big pictures, on the wall.  We have tried all of them and they are all excellent.

Definitely need reservation as the restaurant fills up quickly.
author: M H.

description:
Loved the place.
Fabulous minced pork lettuce wraps.
Friendly young waitress.
Goldilocks sized  - not too big place, not too small a place - just right.

Looking to return and sample more.

East Bay Visitor
author: Blake M.

description:
My family and I went to this restaurant on Mother's Day, and that was the first time we tried this restaurant. We loved the free soup that was provided. The quality of the soup was really good, and the dishes were great as well! Their prices are inexpensive, and we ordered like five dishes (as I remember), it was less than $60. Moreover, I'm satisified with their customer's service. Although all staff were extremely busy with their tasks, they did provide great service, and were very polite.

The only issues are that we live far apart from their location so we can't always try their food.
author: A C.

description:
I signed up for YELP just to warn patrons of this restaurant!

 Me and my family ate here, the next morning we got food posioning - it lasted for 8 days.

;(


Please be careful!
author: ian D.

description: Delicious food.  We had the pork belly, empress chicken, honey/ black pepper short ribs, lamb claypot, egg yolk crab, and garlic sauteed cong xin cai.  My father is Hakka and loved the pork belly.  Only complaint of the night was that the lamb was too "gamey" and tough which led us to think it was actually goat.  The crab also was super rich and smelled like lots of butter was used.  Other than that, we had a great time and service was adequate.  The servers left us alone for the most part.  I would return to try some of the other dishes.
author: Ren C.

description: YUMMY is all I have to say for this place. Not just great bang for your buck but the customer service is excellent. We have always had a great experience and great food when coming here. ENJOY
author: Maria L.

description:
We celebrated the Chinese New Years here on Sunday, Superbowl Sunday and had a great time.  One table had six hungry teenage boys (one, actually a "has an appetitie like a teen" adult) and the other table had the "adults".  Rarely is all the food consumed with everyone stuffed to the gills.  

We had a lot of different varieties of dishes which included two different kinds of soups ("westlake beef" and "fish maw w/chicken"), a crab dish and a lobster dish, steamed fish, two dishes of just vegetable greens, a lamb claypot, the salt baked chicken, lettuce wrap with a seafood stuffing, a seafood and vegetable dish, a Korean beef rib style dish, fried rice wrapped in lotus leaves (the leaves use for joong...chinese tamales)....I'm sure I'm missing one or two dishes.

We "brought in" desert as it was my wife's birthday.  The moment our waiter saw the two bakery boxes on the table, he immediately brought out a pitcher of water with a knife in it and clean plates with forks, not knowing I had paper plates and plastic forks waiting.  I call that service.

Needless to say we thought all of the dishes were great as well as the service.
author: Glenn N.

description: Went to dinner here with my parents and my sister's in-laws. Awesome, great tasting dishes. We tried most of the dishes that had pics of dishes on the wall. 1 of 6 dishes was just ok and was expensive. The chicken was not meaty and it cost $25+ for a whole chicken! I could've bought 4 chicks at Safeway or Costco, boiled and eat it with Oyster sauce. I would've been happy with that. The lo-mei fan, eggplant and house soup was delish.
author: Marcus Y.

description: Love the pork belly with preserved vegetables and the salted egg yolk pumpkin strips! They were generous with their portion and being a lover of the preserved vegetables, that totally made my day! I had the same dish at Hong Kong Lounge just a little over 2 weeks ago and their portion was about two-thirds of what Hakka served and for a more expensive price as well! Two thumbs up for Hakka :) It is definitely a place for big groups and family-style dinner.
author: Felicia P.

description: This is my 2nd review of this restaurant. Our 6th time here and it is still serving up fresh, well-prepared, and fairly priced Hakka cuisine. Ordered some of the specialties: egg yolk pumpkin (their star dish), fish and tofu clay pot, pea pods with garlic, sticky rice in leaf (a bit dry...could be stickier and more moist in texture), and Peking spare ribs. We left feeling warm, comfy, and fulfilled...AGAIN!
author: H E.

description: Gotta support the only Hakka restaurant in the bay area. Decent food, not really the same as what my parents make, but the waiter is very friendly and prices are good.
author: chet l.

description:
food=3 star, parking=1 additonal star. 
not bad, very friendly parking. they have someone actually help and look for spots for you.
the food was ok, the egg yolk frog taste great however, the pumpkin is out of porpotion, the whole dish consists of 2/3 pumpkin and 1/3 frog.
final thoughts $95 for 5 person is reasonable.
author: Thomas L.

description:
warning. no beer and wine license as of 5/28/2010...they do let you byob for now.

i am compelled to write this the morning after i try the place.

awhile ago, when talking about a shitty bar on geary that is no longer there, a friend said, if euge doesnt like a bar, theres something really wrong with it. 

on that note, if euge likes a place that doesnt serve beer or wine (yet) theres something really good about it.

a table of eight comprised of people ive known since the high school days tried out a feast of dishes. we were lucky to have 

http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=JVcyzABtBNK5T0taFqf45w

with us to do all the ordering. *shameless plug* go visit her blog

http://cookwitheva.com/

anyways, right to it. HOLY CRAP. the salt egg batter crab with fried pumkin!!!! dude. that thing was awesome. i just wanted to suck off all the fried batter off the crab parts and go to town. it was really REALLY good. the salt baked chicken? yeah. just order it. we ordered a shitton more plates, but really... just go, before it gets too packed and theres a line out the door. the servers were friendly enough and seemed to really believe in their food. thats a huge plus. they will give you the ins on whats good. our waiter did try to upsell us to two crab dishes, but then again, that was before eva finished our orders. 

one small hiccup would be the dirty water for their live tank. the live crab looked pretty sad in the dirty water tank. 

when it came down to it for me, everything was just plain good. the type of place you take the familia and it wont break the bank and everyone will enjoy their meal. 

return visit? im trying to think of some reason to gather up a group of friends to have dinner as i type this.
author: Euge L.

description: Very solid! Loved the Fish Fillet with House Sauce and the Eggplant with Garlic. Nothing too greasy or fatty. Looking forward to going back and trying more dishes.
author: David B.

description:
After my first visit, I was dreaming of the salted egg fried pumpkin.

I've grown up with Cantonese cuisine, but never had Hakka.
I had a friend in town who is from the province/people?, and she was looking forward to some home dishes.

+ pork belly was tender, but definitely not for the healthy at heart ;)
+/-Hakka Chicken, good, but according to my friend, not quite traditional (tasted like good baked chinese chicken) 
++ fried frog & pumpkin with salted egg- never had it, but was an immediate FAN! If you don't like salted egg yolk.... pass on this. The pumpkin pieces gave is a nice contrast and sweetness amongest the frog.

Two days later I HAD to get the pumpkin dish alone... still delcious, but it's 
better as a compliment to the frog.

The only reason I'm docking a star is for the SLOW service (20+ mins to take our order & another 20+ trying to actively get our check) so be prepared for a leisurely time. The rest of the dishes are decent :].
author: Angel L.

description:
This is a hole in the wall chinese restaurant out on a lonely street corner in Outer Mission.  But the food is so so so good for its price.  Its packed every time we go there for dinner, even on weekdays.  Really good and really cheap.  And the staff is extremely friendly.

My favorites are the crispy pumpkin fries and pork belly.  

If you're looking for some posh asian-fusion new-age california fancy dishes, then this is not the place.  But if you want good ole' Chinese food family style at an affordable price, this is the place to go.

If you plan on going on a busy day like Saturday, then you should make reservations.  This place can get packed.
author: Yvonne H.

description: One of the unique finds in San Francisco, and quite authentic Hakka restaurants (yes, not all Chinese restaurants are just "Chinese"). The salted egg pumpkin, lotus rice, braised pork were all excellent choices.  Just wished that I took pictures to share.
author: Stan L.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants in SF. It's totally worth the drive to outer Richmond. Definitely get the signature salt baked chicken, fried pumpkin, stuffed tofu.
author: Cindy W.

description: Got the family special for $88 and substituted the crab dish for the egg yolk crab for just a little bit more, which is a pretty good deal as this egg yolk crab dish was the standout dish of the night. The saltiness of the egg yolk in the batter really compliments the sweetness of the pumpkin and crab. Be prepared to wait in line on the weekend.
author: E. C.

description: This place is not for everyone, but hey.. It's very good.  Their veggies are top notch and the customer service (I've been 3 times now) has always been fantastic.  The chicken that you read about on here is very good, but if you don't want the chicken head staring back at you from your plate, you better ask them to leave it back in the kitchen.
author: David H.

description: Never been a huge fan of Asian food, I never really know what I'm gonna get.  But this place is off the charts.  They don't bring you everything at once and thank god cause the amount of food you get is rediulous.  Be prepared for a doggy bag or 4.  The people are so nice and will help you out where they can.  I'm sure for most, the pictures on the menu feel more like Denny's but for a guy who dosn't know sriracha from Sri Lanka, it helps a ton.  I'll be there again soon.
author: Mat F.

description: I can't give them my highest ranking yet as I don't think I got to taste their staple food.  Last night, this place was packed but luckily we had reservation for 11.  We got there early so there were plenty of parking space and no line yet.  But as the evening went on, people kept coming and coming.... thus I am assuming this is a great place to dine.  We had basic food like fried rice, chicken chow fun, westlake soup, fried tofu, pork tofu w/ salted fish, sweet and sour chicken, mu- shu pork, minced lettuce wrap pork, braised beef clay pot with turnip and some other dishes I can't recall (overall 11 different dishes).  Food tasted good but nothing to rave about.  Price is quite affordable.  It is basically your everyday type of food.  I will still come back to try their specialty dish though.  If you are hungry and want some good food, this is one of the great place to visit.  I just didn't care for the tofu pork with salted fish as much I wanted but I am a big critic because I have tasted the best salted fish ever and nothing can compare to it (because salted fish from Raiatea (French Polynesia) are the best).  I grew up on that dish being part hakka myself.  But for the average person, I am sure it will be just fine.  Don't get me wrong, I still recommend this place, that one dish will not stop me.  I just won't order that :)
author: Ro C.

description: I am a white guy married to a Chinese woman.  I eat a lot of Chinese food.  I have been to Hong Kong and other parts of Asia, so I think I have a pretty good idea about what good Chinese food should taste like.  The restaurant is close to my in laws',  so we eat there fairly often.  The food and service are outstanding.  The place is crowded and noisy.  Even when the place is packed, the service is excellent.  Attentive and accurate.  My last time I ate there, the food was too good.  I did not want to get full.  If you are not Asian, be sure and be brave and order things a bit unusual.  The food is geared strictly to the Chinese palate.  The more adventurous you are, the more you will broaden your taste buds, and be very pleased.  I can not wait to go back.
author: Tom B.

description:
Great little place.  Totally worth it.  I'll kill a place if it sucks and will heap praise where it is deserved.

Nice folks, Great food, very reasonable prices.  No frills (just like it's supposed to be).  Did I say great food?

I'll be back.  Hakka, you make San Francisco worth it to me.
author: Steve F.

description:
Good Hakka Specialties. Nice to have so many Hakka dishes available, especially since they are offered in english as well as chinese. 

We had the hakka home-style frog...frog with celery, ginger, and basil. this was a very light, very fresh dish. Excellent. Also the salt-baked chicken, which was every bit as good as Ton Kiang in it's prime.

Look forward to going back and trying more of the dishes.

Service was friendly and well-informed.

Atmosphere? Typical chinese hakka - ie no atmosphere...but clean.

Highly recommended for families and adventurous eaters.
author: J M.

description: It was one of the only restaurants open on Christmas Day outside of Chinatown, which is why we ordered take out from here.  We had chow mien (veg), lamb with ginger / scallion, Mongolian beef and chow fun w black bean sauce.  Flavors were okay but the food was remarkably greasy and somewhat underspiced.  Perhaps they were feeling rushed on the holiday.
author: Mohita M.

description:
We went last weekend for dinner and thoroughly enjoy our meal.   What we ordered:

- salt baked chicken.  This was a bit of disappointment for us since we had such high hopes.  We did like the chicken itself, which was tasty, with fresh and tender chicken.  However, the flavor is far more muted than what authentic "Dong Jiang salt baked chicken" taste like.

- pork belly with preserved cabbage.  Very good rendition of the dish, with top quality pork belly and excellent execution.  The result is melting, succulent, flavorful chunks of pork.  The preserved cabbage, which is tender and flavorful without tasting like wet paper as is usually the case, is just as good.

- braised tofu.  This is a simple braised tofu dish that can be found in every cantonese restaurant, but the execution here is above average.  Fresh tofu and snap peas without globs of sauce overpowering the ingredients. 

- Deep fried pumpkin with salted egg.  This was a pleasant surprise as we were originally going to cancel this dish.  The waiter suggest that we give it a shot and we loved it.  The pumpkins are cut into small carrot stick sizes, fried in a batter sprinkled with salted egg yoke.  The sweetness of the pumpkin is amazing with the savory batter.  Not sure if this is the chef's creation or a new trend in chinese restaurants.  But either way, it's a winner.  The waiter also told us at the end of the meal that this was one of the most popular dishes at the restaurant. 

- Salt and pepper spare ribs.  Very forgettable rendition of a popular dish in chinese restaurant.  Though it was not bad, compare to the quality of other dishes, it's not worth mentioning.  Won't be ordering this again. 

- XO sauce fried rice.  Very flavorful fried rice, not a bad deal by itself.

At the beginning of the dinner, we were served a soup with snow ear and a porky, clear broth.  At the end of the meal, we were served a sweet dessert soup with pumpkin.  Both were complimentary of the meal.   I think there was also a 10% Grand Opening discount, which is plastered on the front window.  Though I didn't check my bill carefully enough to see if we got it. 

Overall, we would definitely go back.  For the price, Hakka is by far the best Chinese in the Bay Area I have had.  Just judging by the quality of the food, it would still easily rank in top 3 Bay Area chinese restaurant on my list.
author: Leon W.

description: good food, good customer service, and good price. i don't feel they put much MSG into the food which i love it. my family enjoy it... if u have a big group,  better make reservation.
author: B B.

description:
Great food, great service and just plain good value. 
We had the pepper and salt pork chops, Chinese broccoli with rice wine, shrimp egg foo young, and deep fried pumpkin strips. 
Large servings so we had leftovers for the next day. 

Excellent service with the waiter taking so much pride in describing the menu. Nice and clean with white table cloths. 

Hakka cuisine is clean and not greasy. I really hope the service stands the test of time becuase they have really started out on a good foot. I will definitely visit again.

My husband is very sensitive to MSG and he  did not detect that they used MSG.
author: Katrena M.

description:
Prices are good.
Foods good.
Service is good.
You can't beat that.
i always eat here and sometimes get take out.
They are very friendly people.One of the best restaurants ever.
author: Carmen H.

description:
The chefs here really rock! Some of the Hakka dishes here are a little closer to their roots. Been here 9-10 times and would recommend any of the deep fried items, squab and lettuce wrap, any recommended fresh vegatable dish.

Place is noisy, crowded on some nights. Tasty tasty dishes!
author: w l.

description: worth a frequent visit for decent kind of Hakka.
author: T W.

description: All the plates came of with fresh ingredients and all of it tasted great and had a clean healthy feel to it. Pricing is very cheap for what you get. Get a lot of rice, mix it with the dishes and you have a $75 dinner for 9. Ill be back. All in all, good food and price.
author: Keit K.

description:
This place has totally decent Chinese food out in the middle of no-wheres-ville (outer Richmond). I wouldn't make a special trip out to the boonies to eat here again (although I would like to go back with a big group to try more items) but if I was in the nabe, I'd eat here again. There were just two of us and this is what we ordered. 

PUMPKIN STRIPS WITH SALTY  EGG: They have pictures of a lot of their dishes on the wall and menu and this looked deep fried (thus, delish). I didn't know what the salty egg business was about but it turns out the egg yolk is sprinkled on the pumpkin strips after (?) they are deep fried. The pumpkin strips were nice and tender but the coating seemed like it could have been crisper. Maybe the oil wasn't hot enough or something but the exterior wasn't as crunchy as I wanted it to be. Also, the egg yolk adds a weirdly subtle smell as you bring the pumpkin strip to your nose. It smells vaguely of crotch. We had just gone running and I kept thinking I was smelling my own armpits or something everytime I lifted my chopsticks up to my mouth. Don't be afraid of it though, surprisingly, the whiff of dirty crotch adds a complexity to the flavor that is kind of interesting. Who knew...crotch is umami.

CHINESE BACON WITH PRESERVED VEGGIES: This is big slabs of pork belly on a bed of finely minced brown veggies. I'm not wild about the preserved veggies but didn't hate it either. I enjoy fatty pork belly so I liked this dish but I feel like I've had better versions of this.

OYSTERS IN BLACK BEAN SAUCE: Giant plump oysters with your standard veggies (bell peppers in various colors and onions). I enjoyed this dish a lot. A little on the greasy side, but nice flavor and nice plump fresh tasting oysters. 

We also ordered one orange soda and steamed rice and I think the bill came to $33--so $40 including tip. The service was fine. Your basic Chinese restaurant casual/indifferent. The patrons eating there were all Asian when we were there. Would be interested to return and try more Hakkanese dishes and just a greater variety of dishes.
author: meehee o.

description: Went in for lunch with positive expectations due to all the reviews here, but it was one of the least enjoyable meals I've had in recent memory. The waitstaff acted nearly angry that we were there and basically cold shouldered us most of the time, even with a half empty restaurant. That aside, the food was really nothing to write home about. Soggy bokchoy SOAKED with grease, over-cooked crispy chicken, and they were sold out of the pork belly (the one dish on here that everyone raves about). Maybe I just caught them on a bad day, but it will be awhile before I think about trying this place again.
author: Sebastian A.

description: drove all the way out here based on the reviews.  i'm hakka so i know what good hakka food should taste like.  this place served up very mediocre quality and had very few seating for table of 4 or less.  in fact we were only 3 and we had to set at the ends of the table.   never coming back!
author: Gene H.

description: I will start by saying that the only thing keeping me from giving this place a five-star rating is the relatively high prices. Everything else is perfect. Aside from the fact that the food is stunningly delicious, the portions are huge, the staff is friendly, the atmosphere is great, and the service is timely, the entrées and hors d'œuvres alike are very unique among the typical selection of Chinese cuisines found in North America, as many of them are prepared from the Hakka culinary canon.
author: Andrew P.

description: Out-a of control busy on a Saturday night, better get a reservation or be prepared to wait an hour or even longer before you get a table if you don't have a reservation. 3 star food quality and lose a star for salty taste makes this a so so choice when looking for Asian flair in the Richmond with zero dining  frills. The place is very small and is a noisy and crowded fishbowl dining room with little room if any between to move comfortably in the establishment. Canned sardines comes to mind for me.. Defiantly not the best food I have eaten but not the worst either.
author: David O.

description: I give this place 3.5 stars, yes I like my half stars! I've eaten at alot of Chinese family style dinners and this place had real good food. I know when it's good when I forget to take photos of each dish for yelp when they come out cuss I'm too busy staring down at my plate and licking my fingers. My family got the $128 Family Dinner Set Menu and everything was good, also ordered a few extra dishes on top of it. I'm not going to go down the list but you can see my photos. Let me tell you my favorites and least favorites instead. Favorites: Fried Tofu/Eggplant bites so good!, Crab yum!, Blackbean steamed catfish this was one of the best I've had, shortribs were so flavorfu but some pieces were a little tough. Meh dishes: The Tapioca Taro Dessert at the end, wow lets talk cheap! this stuff tasted straight up like water because they tried to make more by adding more water and cornstarch, YUCK! The famous salty chicken, not that great and it's a tiny little chicken which I didn't mind since chickens shouldn't be huge and plump naturally. Honey pepper oysters, don't do it not all that. I thought it was baked and served in the oyster shell, I was wrong. I think the oysters came out of a jar.
author: Karen T.

description:
Fantastic! Probably one of the better Chinese dinners I've had recently. Everything we ordered came out hot and delicious! For 8 people, we paid around $80 for 7 dishes. Here were the most memorable dishes:

-Fried Kabocha Squash (Pumpkin) with Salted Egg Batter
So delicious! Their salted egg batter was not too salty and went with the sweetness of the squash so well! It stayed crispy from the first to the last piece. This must be tried if you like salted egg!

-Stewed Pork Belly with Lettuce
If you like this dish, you must try Hakka Restaurant's version! I've eaten this at quite a few restaurants, and HR's is one of the best! The pork is super tender, with a certain sweetness that not all restaurants can get right.

-Some kind of sliced tofu cooked with pork meatballs on top with brown sauce
This was good. The meatball was very tender and the sauce had pieces of salted dried fish in it. I like salted dried fish, so I liked it a lot. But not everyone likes it.

Dessert was on the house and was a sweet soup made from kabocha squash and tapioca. To the reviewer who asserted that this soup must have food coloring because it was so yellow: do you even know what kabocha squash is? There's no need to add any food coloring!  

Everything was so good I definitely want to go back! I have to laugh when I see all the 100 something reviews of the Hunan Cafe place across the street from this place. If you like real Chinese food, and not some kind of Panda Express wannabe, Hakka Restaurant is where it's at.
author: Crystal L.

description: Great values! The braised pork belly melts in your mouth and is so flavorful! It pares well with the preserved vegetables. That much pork belly for just 10 dollars? It's a GREAT deal, especially considering if you ordered braised pork belly at a fancy restaurant, you would only get 1/16th the amount they serve here. A new fave restaurant!
author: Annie Y.

description:
How How Sit ! Hakka tou gah heh choi Fui Zhou loi soh yi kiah geh Moy Choy Q Nyuk  heh jui jin jong.

Translation:
 Very very good. The hakka boss is from Hui Zhou (100% hakka county in China) so that's why his Moy Choy Q Nyuk is the most authentic.
author: Set Y.

description: As I am writing this review, I am experiencing a major headache and thirst.  They use too much MSG.  Food taste good, but please hold the MSG.
author: susan g.

description: We have a lot of Chinese restaurants in SF, but surprisingly it's very hard to find one that's consistently good and one that doesn't use a lot of MSG in the dishes. I go to Hakka almost weekly to get my minced pork with string beans in XO sauce fix. It has so much flavor and texture; they do it right here. Other dishes that I've tried and that are good include: preserved pork belly (very authentic), pumpkin with salted egg, sticky rice, pea shoots with garlic, spicy eggplant, steamed tofu, fish and tofu clay pot, deep fried tofu or the deep fried eggplant/tofu combo, yang chow fried rice, beef with two kinds of mushrooms, and westlake minced beef soup (ask for less cornstarch). You can get a decent banquet meal for 10 people with everyone chipping in $15. Parking is okay before 7PM. The restaurant gets very crowded after 7PM, especially from Fridays - Sundays.
author: A L.

description: From the two dishes that i tried for take out, the food was ok, but with so many chinese restaurants in the area, it wouldn't be my first choice. The portions i got were small for takeout compared to the pictures here on yelp, the fried crab with salted egg yolk and the honey shortribs. The shortribs were really oily(more so than how restaurant chinese food typically is) and the crab was overcooked. I've definitely had better versions of these dishes elsewhere. That said, some of their other specials do look good and i might be willing to give those a try if i were too busy to cook myself.  Overall, not impressed, but willing to give it a second chance.
author: Iknowasianfood C.

description:
This restaurant is a converted two story house in a residential area. Arrived here with a party of four at 5:30 on Saturday and had to wait
about 1/2 hr. There are about 10 tables (5 ten top and 5 smaller tables). Once we ordered the food arrived quickly. 
Dishes we ordered:
- House soup (complimentary): clear and light and flavorful  
- Braised pork belly over preserved veg and  (menu says mustard greens but we got lettuce). I typically may have one piece of the meat because I prefer the veges and sauce over rice but the pork was so tender and literally just melted in your mouth. It was fantastic.
- House special 1/2 chicken: came out slightly chilled with a side of ginger scallion oil sauce. Had great taste and texture. 
- Stuffed tofu:  I have had better. Tofu was browned nicely on outside and soft inside.  A little too much white pepper in the sauce. Meat stuffing was small, mushy and tasted odd. I know they mix the meat with preserved salted fish (which is how my family makes it) so that was not the reason.

Looking forward to eating here again and trying more dishes!
author: Monica C.

description: I love the chow fun here!!  I frequent Hakka on my lunch hour and they are always fast to get my order ready and its always good.  I have sampled a good portion of their menu now and it's always been awesome.
author: rocky b.

description: The food was unique and definitely better than what average Chinese restaurant has to offer.
author: Jun W.

description:
I was here last week on wednesday night and the place was packed so  we waited for about 10 minutes. Most tables are pretty big suitable for family dining. 

I ordered the special tofu dish, egg foo young, and lettuce wraps. I never had lettuce wraps before but I thought it was excellent. Definitely the best item we ordered. Egg foo young was salty but the hakka tofu was good. 

Service was great. Everything came out in acceptable time considering the place was full and there were only 2-3 servers. Our server was friendly and suggestive, didn't feel like it was in a hurry. 

Since they were still in Grand Opening mode, we got 10% off so it was a good deal.
author: Hans S.

description: Came by for a late lunch. Ordered the Pork Belly with the Pickled Cabbage and the House Special Sauce Lamb. Both were delicious! Pork Belly had right amount of fat to meat. Pickled cabbage was very tasty. Loved the Lamb; uses a XO sauce. Would have preferred a little more heat on the lamb, but excellent flavor. Didn't care too much for the house soup.
author: David Y.

description: Like most places in SF, it's a little crammed. But, that's okay. The food is decent. Not a date place, but perfect for family parties. A lot of people raved about the pork belly. Personally, I didn't touch it. I'm sure it's good but I can see it going straight to my arteries. I want to live another few decades. So no, thanks.
author: Emma T.

description: My friend waved about this house special chicken (hakka style, i guess) from this place  Finally got to try it last night.  It was very good.  We also had a few other dishes.  The pumpkin fries, pork belly with fermented vegetables were very good also.  The mapo tofu and salt and pepper frog, clams with spicy salt and black beans were okay.  All in all, they were very good food, the chicken is definitely something i want to come back for.
author: e c.

description:
The place is pretty clean and quiet on a Saturday afternoon.  We ordered the pork belly with fermented veggies, sauteed vegetables, fish and veggies, lamb clay pot.
Overall, the food is oily and salty even though we requested for less salt, no msg and less oil.  
the pork belly was on the sweeter side, the traditional dish would be less sweet and crispier skin.  
the clay pot was the tastiest of all the dishes we ordered.  
service was excellent, though.
author: Yolanda Y.

description:
First of all, the service was exceptional! The waiter was extremely helpful, attentive and also informative.

Everything we had was good... better than other bay area chinese restaurants we've tried before. The dishes in those restaurants usually taste similar.. but not this one!
We recommend the chicken (OMG! Heavenly!!), pan fried tofu (the square pieces are still intact and it has pork on top of it) and the oysters (fried w/ peppers and black bean sauce).

Prices were okay... Worth the quality and the portions of the food.
We really recommend this restaurant!!!!
But wish they have a special dessert menu.. When that happens, you will see us there everyday!
author: Roland R.

description: This was hella good! we ate kau yuk (fatty ass pork), some hella good clam/oyster diah, salt baked chicken, and dau miew. Everything arrived hot, fast, fresh and tasty. On the way to the bathroom I saw something delicious looking, some kind of meat patty, must try next time. And they gave us toy gawn soup and some mung bean dessert thing too. Very good, would go totally go back.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description: As close as I can get to Malaysian chinese! I am so happy! Pork belly was great. Beans fragrant and perfect - not too oily.
author: Yu N.

description:
Third time's a charm. I headed from downtown out to the Richmond for dinner. First I tried to eat at To Hyang, but they were closed Mondays. Next I tried to eat at Namu, but they turned the music way up as I was sitting there waiting to order. So I hopped back onto Muni and shlepped all the way out to 45th and Cabrillo and landed in the land of the Hakka. Restaurant, that is.

The first floor was jammed, with only one table available, and it was right by the kitchen entrance. Oh, well, I thought, I came all this way. I entered and asked for a table for one. They said I could sit there or go upstairs. Ah, they have an upstairs. So we went upstairs and I got a table.

I specifically said I wanted to try some Hakka dishes and the waiter helpfully described some dishes to me. I decided on the fried squash with salted eggs and a half salt-baked chicken. (The waiter said their salt-baked chicken actually was salt-baked; apparently some other places take a shortcut of steaming.) 

I ordered the chicken in Cantonese (wasn't sure if I could use that, after all it's Hakka Restaurant, not Cantonese Restaurant, but apparently they do speak Cantonese there). As a reward, I got the long-cooked soup of the day, watercress in a pork-bone broth. It was yummy.

Then the squash arrived and it was yummy and slightly crunchy and just a bit salty. And the salt-baked chicken arrived and the flesh was tender and tasty and definitely yummy and not excessively salty.

But apparently my speaking Cantonese wasn't enough as I got the fortune cookie for the Westerner instead of the dessert soup. Oh well. (In all fairness, I rarely get rewarded with the tong seui dessert soup no matter how much Cantonese I use. Not sure what the secret is to Westerners getting the tong seui. Or maybe I have to remember not to show off my Cantonese by saying "sik baau laak" (I'm full). Maybe I'm full=no tong seui.)

Anyway, the service was friendly and quick and the food was consistently yummy. I'd definitely make the trek again as well as bring friends here.

Just so you know, the salt-baked chicken is served cold, chopped with the bones in and has the head on. If you get the half salt-baked chicken, you get half a head. Not sure why, since the idea of having the head is to have the whole chicken, but if you halve the whole chicken, it's no longer whole. But anyway, I have now eaten Chicken brain. Or half a chicken brain. The half-portion is also smaller than their other entree dishes, but it's still a decent portion of both light and dark meat.

I like frog so will have to come back and try the frog dishes.
author: Charles B.

description: Good chinese village food. Fast and friendly. Great variety. Easy to find parking.
author: Roger R.

description: Before taking a seat to eat here look around the outside of the place. Garbage and grease on the sidewalks? If they don't sweep the sidewalk around the restaurant I can only imagine what goes on in the kitchen. The communities complaints about their employees parking on sidewalks, and using the rear easement as their private parking lot, and blocking driveways have falling on deaf ears. Do the Outer Richmond a favor and skip this disrespectful establishment.
author: Steven C.

description: I brought my family along with my god-parents from out of town here to eat last month. It was wonderful and did not disappoint. Both my dad and god-father are Hakka so they know their food. My dad is a big critic of food so when he's not complaining, I'm just so happy. My family is a picky eater and I usually hear more complaints and criticism than seeing smiles after eating out. Boy was I glad this place put those smiles on them. The only thing my dad complained was the chicken. He said something like it's not suppose to be baked. I liked it though. There were so much food. Parking did suck. It's in the middle of a residential area so the street parking was very limited. We all go lucky though. The restaurant was quite small. I would recommend people to come here though. Please try it out. There were folks from San Jose to try this restaurant.
author: Annie L.

description: Good Chinese food in a place where you can enjoy being the only white guy in the room.  There is a little too much focus on pork as an ingredient, but careful ordering can navigate around that.  The oyster with ginger and scallions is very well executed here (ginger fried to a golden brown but scallions still crunchy and fresh tasting).
author: Richard P.

description: not bad. At first I thought it would be a small cheap dirty but it was not. I will definitely come back here. I really liked the chicken fried rice. It sounds common but there is something about it. Also the chicken baked with salt. That was delicious!
author: aryana c.

description:
This restaurant is BRILLIANT! =)!

I love the salty egg yolk sprinkled on top of fried crab! =D YUM!! Everything there was delicious and very unique. I love the food! 

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU TO TRY IT FOR YOURSELF. =) I am normally a very picky eater as well. I love the taro sago with tiny water chestnuts dessert at the very end :)! PERFECT ENDING =)!
author: Phoenix C.

description: The chicken eggplant clay pot was great. Will have to try more of their entree's. So far the restaurant is very convenient (walking distance to where I live.) The seafood won ton soup wasn't all that good so that one's crossed out of my list. Beef here is really tender and that could just be the Hong Kong style or just the restaurant itself.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: we were here last year and it had disappointed us then, and due to their intense ad in KTSF26 we decided to give them a second chance, but this time they further downgrade their foods and service,
author: Mike D.

description: If I could give this place more stars I totally would!!!  This is my most fav restaurant for Chinese Family Style cuisine!!!  The service is excellent and food is very high quality!!  My fav dishes are the clams with the thai basil, salt n pepper prok chops, salt n pepper tofu/eggplant, pineapple spareribs, and the pork/mustard greens, clay pot!!  Everything is always fresh, hot and super delish!!!
author: Tee S.

description: If you like Hakka food, this place has a fantastic Mui Choy Kau Yuk and Steam Tofu. The service here is pretty good, unless your upstairs (service is little slower because of the stairs interfering) Price is fair but overall the food here taste great. If you want to try something else beside Hong Kong Style, try Hakka. It's similar but different ( in a good way ).
author: William C.

description: I went to Hakka Rstaurant on last Sunday. The food was nice but the service was OK. when I asked the waiter for a glass of water, it took 20 min to arriver.
author: march c.

description: I do like this place, I haven't had a bad experience here.  The staff are very friendly, the place is clean and comfortable.  I liked their veggies cooked in wine sauce, fried pumpkin was good, sort of like fries, but pumpkin salty and semi sweet.   I ordered a pork stomach lunch special once, it was not bad.  My friend ordered the filet lunch special rice plate and it was better than my pork stomach dish, it looked very fresh with fresh greens and white fresh fish, so that was a good deal for that dish.  A good restaurant in the outer richmond
author: John L.

description: Delicious, not too oily, flavorful.. and just oh so good. Recommend the house special clams, green beans with minced pork and xo sauce, pumpkin strips with salted egg yolk, house special bacon (PORK BELLY DELICIOUSNESS).. mm all delicious. Love this place.
author: Jeannette L.

description: This is the real deal.  It's affordable, it's packed, and it's authentic.  I am a fan of the special seafood noodles with red chili flakes and basil, and the pumpkin strips.  Yes, it's a trek to the Outer Richmond, but there's some serious good eats out there people!  I'd dare to say that district is the city's best kept secret.
author: Steve J.

description: Went here with my girlfriend and her cousin last Sunday night due to all the high reviews for this place. The place looks kind of sketchy from the outside since it seems to be in the middle of a residential area but when we walked it, it was pretty packed. Luckily they have a second story where they sat us down right away. We ended up getting the half salt baked chicken, house special tofu, the pork belly (it's called chinese bacon on the menu), and the salt and pepper pork chops. The food seemed normal and pretty ehhh. The half chicken seemed kind of expensive for around $12 from what I remember and it just tasted normal. The soup they brought out to us was complimentary but that tasted ehh as well. We all took a vote at the table and basically agreed we would give this place two stars and it kind of describes the place perfectly: "meh. i've experienced better." San Francisco has so many restaurants to choose from and I'm pretty sure we will never be going back here due to the food being nothing special.
author: Richard H.

description: Read reviews her on Yelp and was eager to try this new gem on unassuming, mostly residential Cabrillo.!  This is some of the best Hakka cuisine in the city and southern Chinese cooking is my first love.!  I love the nice interior with friendly service and lots of Chinese patrons alike.  The pot stickers are crispy golden and not doughy with a wonderful ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect with a little soy sauce.  The beef stew with turnips in clay pot is excellent with tender brisquette marinaded in five spices with fresh turnips; granted there are some fatty pieces in which you have to carefully chew or take off the meat which ever comes first, but it is well worth it.  The house special seafood yee noodles are sublime with fresh prawns, fish, and squid in  an xo sauce that just the right kick; the noodles are just right and not gummy.!  The steamed rice is firm not soggy.  The complimentary pork and vegetable soup is excellent with tender pork and free vegetables in a lightly seasoned broth.  The red bean soup is a perfect way to end the meal and is naturally sweet, not overpowering.!  The tea is perfectly brewed and flavored.  So, for excellent Hakka cuisine at reasonable prices with friendly service in a clean atmosphere, Hakka cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.
